242	1054	Closely related fields in theoretical computer science are analysis of algorithms and computability theory.
242	1055	A key distinction between analysis of algorithms and computational complexity theory is that the former is devoted to analyzing the amount of resources needed by a particular algorithm to solve a problem, whereas the latter asks a more general question about all possible algorithms that could be used to solve the same problem.
242	1056	More precisely, it tries to classify problems that can or cannot be solved with appropriately restricted resources.
242	1057	In turn, imposing restrictions on the available resources is what distinguishes computational complexity from computability theory: the latter theory asks what kind of problems can, in principle, be solved algorithmically.
243	1058	A computational problem can be viewed as an infinite collection of instances together with a solution for every instance.
243	1059	The input string for a computational problem is referred to as a problem instance, and should not be confused with the problem itself.
243	1060	In computational complexity theory, a problem refers to the abstract question to be solved.
243	1061	In contrast, an instance of this problem is a rather concrete utterance, which can serve as the input for a decision problem.
243	1062	For example, consider the problem of primality testing.
243	1063	The instance is a number (e.g.
243	1064	15) and the solution is "yes" if the number is prime and "no" otherwise (in this case "no").
243	1065	Stated another way, the instance is a particular input to the problem, and the solution is the output corresponding to the given input.
244	1066	To further highlight the difference between a problem and an instance, consider the following instance of the decision version of the traveling salesman problem: Is there a route of at most 2000 kilometres passing through all of Germany's 15 largest cities?
244	1067	The quantitative answer to this particular problem instance is of little use for solving other instances of the problem, such as asking for a round trip through all sites in Milan whose total length is at most 10 km.
244	1068	For this reason, complexity theory addresses computational problems and not particular problem instances.
245	1069	When considering computational problems, a problem instance is a string over an alphabet.
245	1070	Usually, the alphabet is taken to be the binary alphabet (i.e., the set {0,1}), and thus the strings are bitstrings.
245	1071	As in a real-world computer, mathematical objects other than bitstrings must be suitably encoded.
245	1072	For example, integers can be represented in binary notation, and graphs can be encoded directly via their adjacency matrices, or by encoding their adjacency lists in binary.
246	1073	Decision problems are one of the central objects of study in computational complexity theory.
246	1074	A decision problem is a special type of computational problem whose answer is either yes or no, or alternately either 1 or 0.
246	1075	A decision problem can be viewed as a formal language, where the members of the language are instances whose output is yes, and the non-members are those instances whose output is no.
246	1076	The objective is to decide, with the aid of an algorithm, whether a given input string is a member of the formal language under consideration.
246	1077	If the algorithm deciding this problem returns the answer yes, the algorithm is said to accept the input string, otherwise it is said to reject the input.
247	1078	An example of a decision problem is the following.
247	1079	The input is an arbitrary graph.
247	1080	The problem consists in deciding whether the given graph is connected, or not.
247	1081	The formal language associated with this decision problem is then the set of all connected graphs—of course, to obtain a precise definition of this language, one has to decide how graphs are encoded as binary strings.
248	1082	A function problem is a computational problem where a single output (of a total function) is expected for every input, but the output is more complex than that of a decision problem, that is, it isn't just yes or no.
248	1083	Notable examples include the traveling salesman problem and the integer factorization problem.
249	1084	It is tempting to think that the notion of function problems is much richer than the notion of decision problems.
249	1085	However, this is not really the case, since function problems can be recast as decision problems.
249	1086	For example, the multiplication of two integers can be expressed as the set of triples (a, b, c) such that the relation a × b = c holds.
249	1087	Deciding whether a given triple is a member of this set corresponds to solving the problem of multiplying two numbers.
250	1088	To measure the difficulty of solving a computational problem, one may wish to see how much time the best algorithm requires to solve the problem.
250	1089	However, the running time may, in general, depend on the instance.
250	1090	In particular, larger instances will require more time to solve.
250	1091	Thus the time required to solve a problem (or the space required, or any measure of complexity) is calculated as a function of the size of the instance.
250	1092	This is usually taken to be the size of the input in bits.
250	1093	Complexity theory is interested in how algorithms scale with an increase in the input size.
250	1094	For instance, in the problem of finding whether a graph is connected, how much more time does it take to solve a problem for a graph with 2n vertices compared to the time taken for a graph with n vertices?
251	1095	If the input size is n, the time taken can be expressed as a function of n. Since the time taken on different inputs of the same size can be different, the worst-case time complexity T(n) is defined to be the maximum time taken over all inputs of size n. If T(n) is a polynomial in n, then the algorithm is said to be a polynomial time algorithm.
251	1096	Cobham's thesis says that a problem can be solved with a feasible amount of resources if it admits a polynomial time algorithm.
252	1097	A Turing machine is a mathematical model of a general computing machine.
252	1098	It is a theoretical device that manipulates symbols contained on a strip of tape.
252	1099	Turing machines are not intended as a practical computing technology, but rather as a thought experiment representing a computing machine—anything from an advanced supercomputer to a mathematician with a pencil and paper.
252	1100	It is believed that if a problem can be solved by an algorithm, there exists a Turing machine that solves the problem.
252	1101	Indeed, this is the statement of the Church–Turing thesis.
252	1102	Furthermore, it is known that everything that can be computed on other models of computation known to us today, such as a RAM machine, Conway's Game of Life, cellular automata or any programming language can be computed on a Turing machine.
252	1103	Since Turing machines are easy to analyze mathematically, and are believed to be as powerful as any other model of computation, the Turing machine is the most commonly used model in complexity theory.
253	1104	A deterministic Turing machine is the most basic Turing machine, which uses a fixed set of rules to determine its future actions.
253	1105	A probabilistic Turing machine is a deterministic Turing machine with an extra supply of random bits.
253	1106	The ability to make probabilistic decisions often helps algorithms solve problems more efficiently.
253	1107	Algorithms that use random bits are called randomized algorithms.
253	1108	A non-deterministic Turing machine is a deterministic Turing machine with an added feature of non-determinism, which allows a Turing machine to have multiple possible future actions from a given state.
253	1109	One way to view non-determinism is that the Turing machine branches into many possible computational paths at each step, and if it solves the problem in any of these branches, it is said to have solved the problem.
253	1110	Clearly, this model is not meant to be a physically realizable model, it is just a theoretically interesting abstract machine that gives rise to particularly interesting complexity classes.
254	1111	Many types of Turing machines are used to define complexity classes, such as deterministic Turing machines, probabilistic Turing machines, non-deterministic Turing machines, quantum Turing machines, symmetric Turing machines and alternating Turing machines.
254	1112	They are all equally powerful in principle, but when resources (such as time or space) are bounded, some of these may be more powerful than others.
255	1113	Many machine models different from the standard multi-tape Turing machines have been proposed in the literature, for example random access machines.
255	1114	Perhaps surprisingly, each of these models can be converted to another without providing any extra computational power.
255	1115	The time and memory consumption of these alternate models may vary.
255	1116	What all these models have in common is that the machines operate deterministically.
256	1117	However, some computational problems are easier to analyze in terms of more unusual resources.
256	1118	For example, a non-deterministic Turing machine is a computational model that is allowed to branch out to check many different possibilities at once.
256	1119	The non-deterministic Turing machine has very little to do with how we physically want to compute algorithms, but its branching exactly captures many of the mathematical models we want to analyze, so that non-deterministic time is a very important resource in analyzing computational problems.
257	1120	For a precise definition of what it means to solve a problem using a given amount of time and space, a computational model such as the deterministic Turing machine is used.
257	1121	The time required by a deterministic Turing machine M on input x is the total number of state transitions, or steps, the machine makes before it halts and outputs the answer ("yes" or "no").
257	1122	A Turing machine M is said to operate within time f(n), if the time required by M on each input of length n is at most f(n).
257	1123	A decision problem A can be solved in time f(n) if there exists a Turing machine operating in time f(n) that solves the problem.
257	1124	Since complexity theory is interested in classifying problems based on their difficulty, one defines sets of problems based on some criteria.
257	1125	For instance, the set of problems solvable within time f(n) on a deterministic Turing machine is then denoted by DTIME(f(n)).
258	1126	Analogous definitions can be made for space requirements.
258	1127	Although time and space are the most well-known complexity resources, any complexity measure can be viewed as a computational resource.
258	1128	Complexity measures are very generally defined by the Blum complexity axioms.
258	1129	Other complexity measures used in complexity theory include communication complexity, circuit complexity, and decision tree complexity.
259	1130	The best, worst and average case complexity refer to three different ways of measuring the time complexity (or any other complexity measure) of different inputs of the same size.
259	1131	Since some inputs of size n may be faster to solve than others, we define the following complexities:
260	1132	For example, consider the deterministic sorting algorithm quicksort.
260	1133	This solves the problem of sorting a list of integers that is given as the input.
260	1134	The worst-case is when the input is sorted or sorted in reverse order, and the algorithm takes time O(n2) for this case.
260	1135	If we assume that all possible permutations of the input list are equally likely, the average time taken for sorting is O(n log n).
260	1136	The best case occurs when each pivoting divides the list in half, also needing O(n log n) time.
261	1137	To classify the computation time (or similar resources, such as space consumption), one is interested in proving upper and lower bounds on the minimum amount of time required by the most efficient algorithm solving a given problem.
261	1138	The complexity of an algorithm is usually taken to be its worst-case complexity, unless specified otherwise.
261	1139	Analyzing a particular algorithm falls under the field of analysis of algorithms.
261	1140	To show an upper bound T(n) on the time complexity of a problem, one needs to show only that there is a particular algorithm with running time at most T(n).
261	1141	However, proving lower bounds is much more difficult, since lower bounds make a statement about all possible algorithms that solve a given problem.
261	1142	The phrase "all possible algorithms" includes not just the algorithms known today, but any algorithm that might be discovered in the future.
261	1143	To show a lower bound of T(n) for a problem requires showing that no algorithm can have time complexity lower than T(n).
262	1144	Upper and lower bounds are usually stated using the big O notation, which hides constant factors and smaller terms.
262	1145	This makes the bounds independent of the specific details of the computational model used.
262	1146	For instance, if T(n) = 7n2 + 15n + 40, in big O notation one would write T(n) = O(n2).
263	1147	Of course, some complexity classes have complicated definitions that do not fit into this framework.
263	1148	Thus, a typical complexity class has a definition like the following:
264	1149	But bounding the computation time above by some concrete function f(n) often yields complexity classes that depend on the chosen machine model.
264	1150	For instance, the language {xx | x is any binary string} can be solved in linear time on a multi-tape Turing machine, but necessarily requires quadratic time in the model of single-tape Turing machines.
264	1151	If we allow polynomial variations in running time, Cobham-Edmonds thesis states that "the time complexities in any two reasonable and general models of computation are polynomially related" (Goldreich 2008, Chapter 1.2).
264	1152	This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the set of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine within polynomial time.
264	1153	The corresponding set of function problems is FP.
265	1154	Many important complexity classes can be defined by bounding the time or space used by the algorithm.
265	1155	Some important complexity classes of decision problems defined in this manner are the following:
266	1156	Other important complexity classes include BPP, ZPP and RP, which are defined using probabilistic Turing machines; AC and NC, which are defined using Boolean circuits; and BQP and QMA, which are defined using quantum Turing machines.
266	1157	#P is an important complexity class of counting problems (not decision problems).
266	1158	Classes like IP and AM are defined using Interactive proof systems.
266	1159	ALL is the class of all decision problems.
267	1160	For the complexity classes defined in this way, it is desirable to prove that relaxing the requirements on (say) computation time indeed defines a bigger set of problems.
267	1161	In particular, although DTIME(n) is contained in DTIME(n2), it would be interesting to know if the inclusion is strict.
267	1162	For time and space requirements, the answer to such questions is given by the time and space hierarchy theorems respectively.
267	1163	They are called hierarchy theorems because they induce a proper hierarchy on the classes defined by constraining the respective resources.
267	1164	Thus there are pairs of complexity classes such that one is properly included in the other.
267	1165	Having deduced such proper set inclusions, we can proceed to make quantitative statements about how much more additional time or space is needed in order to increase the number of problems that can be solved.
268	1166	The time and space hierarchy theorems form the basis for most separation results of complexity classes.
268	1167	For instance, the time hierarchy theorem tells us that P is strictly contained in EXPTIME, and the space hierarchy theorem tells us that L is strictly contained in PSPACE.
269	1168	Many complexity classes are defined using the concept of a reduction.
269	1169	A reduction is a transformation of one problem into another problem.
269	1170	It captures the informal notion of a problem being at least as difficult as another problem.
269	1171	For instance, if a problem X can be solved using an algorithm for Y, X is no more difficult than Y, and we say that X reduces to Y.
269	1172	There are many different types of reductions, based on the method of reduction, such as Cook reductions, Karp reductions and Levin reductions, and the bound on the complexity of reductions, such as polynomial-time reductions or log-space reductions.
270	1173	The most commonly used reduction is a polynomial-time reduction.
270	1174	This means that the reduction process takes polynomial time.
270	1175	For example, the problem of squaring an integer can be reduced to the problem of multiplying two integers.
270	1176	This means an algorithm for multiplying two integers can be used to square an integer.
270	1177	Indeed, this can be done by giving the same input to both inputs of the multiplication algorithm.
270	1178	Thus we see that squaring is not more difficult than multiplication, since squaring can be reduced to multiplication.
271	1179	This motivates the concept of a problem being hard for a complexity class.
271	1180	A problem X is hard for a class of problems C if every problem in C can be reduced to X.
271	1181	Thus no problem in C is harder than X, since an algorithm for X allows us to solve any problem in C. Of course, the notion of hard problems depends on the type of reduction being used.
271	1182	For complexity classes larger than P, polynomial-time reductions are commonly used.
271	1183	In particular, the set of problems that are hard for NP is the set of NP-hard problems.
272	1184	This is because a polynomial-time solution to Π1 would yield a polynomial-time solution to Π2.
272	1185	Similarly, because all NP problems can be reduced to the set, finding an NP-complete problem that can be solved in polynomial time would mean that P = NP.
273	1186	The complexity class P is often seen as a mathematical abstraction modeling those computational tasks that admit an efficient algorithm.
273	1187	This hypothesis is called the Cobham–Edmonds thesis.
273	1188	The complexity class NP, on the other hand, contains many problems that people would like to solve efficiently, but for which no efficient algorithm is known, such as the Boolean satisfiability problem, the Hamiltonian path problem and the vertex cover problem.
273	1189	Since deterministic Turing machines are special non-deterministic Turing machines, it is easily observed that each problem in P is also member of the class NP.
274	1190	The question of whether P equals NP is one of the most important open questions in theoretical computer science because of the wide implications of a solution.
274	1191	If the answer is yes, many important problems can be shown to have more efficient solutions.
274	1192	These include various types of integer programming problems in operations research, many problems in logistics, protein structure prediction in biology, and the ability to find formal proofs of pure mathematics theorems.
274	1193	The P versus NP problem is one of the Millennium Prize Problems proposed by the Clay Mathematics Institute.
274	1194	There is a US$1,000,000 prize for resolving the problem.
275	1195	It was shown by Ladner that if P ≠ NP then there exist problems in NP that are neither in P nor NP-complete.
275	1196	Such problems are called NP-intermediate problems.
275	1197	The graph isomorphism problem, the discrete logarithm problem and the integer factorization problem are examples of problems believed to be NP-intermediate.
275	1198	They are some of the very few NP problems not known to be in P or to be NP-complete.
276	1199	The graph isomorphism problem is the computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are isomorphic.
276	1200	An important unsolved problem in complexity theory is whether the graph isomorphism problem is in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate.
276	1201	The answer is not known, but it is believed that the problem is at least not NP-complete.
276	1202	If graph isomorphism is NP-complete, the polynomial time hierarchy collapses to its second level.
276	1203	Since it is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level, it is believed that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete.
276	1204	The best algorithm for this problem, due to Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks has run time 2O(√(n log(n))) for graphs with n vertices.
277	1205	The integer factorization problem is the computational problem of determining the prime factorization of a given integer.
277	1206	Phrased as a decision problem, it is the problem of deciding whether the input has a factor less than k. No efficient integer factorization algorithm is known, and this fact forms the basis of several modern cryptographic systems, such as the RSA algorithm.
277	1207	The integer factorization problem is in NP and in co-NP (and even in UP and co-UP).
277	1208	If the problem is NP-complete, the polynomial time hierarchy will collapse to its first level (i.e., NP will equal co-NP).
277	1209	The best known algorithm for integer factorization is the general number field sieve, which takes time O(e(64/9)1/3(n.log 2)1/3(log (n.log 2))2/3) to factor an n-bit integer.
277	1210	However, the best known quantum algorithm for this problem, Shor's algorithm, does run in polynomial time.
277	1211	Unfortunately, this fact doesn't say much about where the problem lies with respect to non-quantum complexity classes.
278	1212	Many known complexity classes are suspected to be unequal, but this has not been proved.
278	1213	For instance P ⊆ NP ⊆ PP ⊆ PSPACE, but it is possible that P = PSPACE.
278	1214	If P is not equal to NP, then P is not equal to PSPACE either.
278	1215	Since there are many known complexity classes between P and PSPACE, such as RP, BPP, PP, BQP, MA, PH, etc., it is possible that all these complexity classes collapse to one class.
278	1216	Proving that any of these classes are unequal would be a major breakthrough in complexity theory.
279	1217	Along the same lines, co-NP is the class containing the complement problems (i.e.
279	1218	problems with the yes/no answers reversed) of NP problems.
279	1219	It is believed that NP is not equal to co-NP; however, it has not yet been proven.
279	1220	It has been shown that if these two complexity classes are not equal then P is not equal to NP.
280	1221	Similarly, it is not known if L (the set of all problems that can be solved in logarithmic space) is strictly contained in P or equal to P. Again, there are many complexity classes between the two, such as NL and NC, and it is not known if they are distinct or equal classes.
281	1222	Problems that can be solved in theory (e.g., given large but finite time), but which in practice take too long for their solutions to be useful, are known as intractable problems.
281	1223	In complexity theory, problems that lack polynomial-time solutions are considered to be intractable for more than the smallest inputs.
281	1224	In fact, the Cobham–Edmonds thesis states that only those problems that can be solved in polynomial time can be feasibly computed on some computational device.
281	1225	Problems that are known to be intractable in this sense include those that are EXPTIME-hard.
281	1226	If NP is not the same as P, then the NP-complete problems are also intractable in this sense.
281	1227	To see why exponential-time algorithms might be unusable in practice, consider a program that makes 2n operations before halting.
281	1228	For small n, say 100, and assuming for the sake of example that the computer does 1012 operations each second, the program would run for about 4 × 1010 years, which is the same order of magnitude as the age of the universe.
281	1229	Even with a much faster computer, the program would only be useful for very small instances and in that sense the intractability of a problem is somewhat independent of technological progress.
281	1230	Nevertheless, a polynomial time algorithm is not always practical.
281	1231	If its running time is, say, n15, it is unreasonable to consider it efficient and it is still useless except on small instances.
282	1232	What intractability means in practice is open to debate.
282	1233	Saying that a problem is not in P does not imply that all large cases of the problem are hard or even that most of them are.
282	1234	For example, the decision problem in Presburger arithmetic has been shown not to be in P, yet algorithms have been written that solve the problem in reasonable times in most cases.
282	1235	Similarly, algorithms can solve the NP-complete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes in less than quadratic time and SAT solvers routinely handle large instances of the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem.
283	1236	Before the actual research explicitly devoted to the complexity of algorithmic problems started off, numerous foundations were laid out by various researchers.
283	1237	Most influential among these was the definition of Turing machines by Alan Turing in 1936, which turned out to be a very robust and flexible simplification of a computer.
284	1238	As Fortnow & Homer (2003) point out, the beginning of systematic studies in computational complexity is attributed to the seminal paper "On the Computational Complexity of Algorithms" by Juris Hartmanis and Richard Stearns (1965), which laid out the definitions of time and space complexity and proved the hierarchy theorems.
284	1239	Also, in 1965 Edmonds defined a "good" algorithm as one with running time bounded by a polynomial of the input size.
285	1240	Earlier papers studying problems solvable by Turing machines with specific bounded resources include  John Myhill's definition of linear bounded automata (Myhill 1960), Raymond Smullyan's study of rudimentary sets (1961), as well as Hisao Yamada's paper on real-time computations (1962).
285	1241	Somewhat earlier, Boris Trakhtenbrot (1956), a pioneer in the field from the USSR, studied another specific complexity measure.
286	1242	Even though some proofs of complexity-theoretic theorems regularly assume some concrete choice of input encoding, one tries to keep the discussion abstract enough to be independent of the choice of encoding.
286	1243	This can be achieved by ensuring that different representations can be transformed into each other efficiently.
287	1244	In 1967, Manuel Blum developed an axiomatic complexity theory based on his axioms and proved an important result, the so-called, speed-up theorem.
287	1245	The field really began to flourish in 1971 when the US researcher Stephen Cook and, working independently, Leonid Levin in the USSR, proved that there exist practically relevant problems that are NP-complete.
287	1246	In 1972, Richard Karp took this idea a leap forward with his landmark paper, "Reducibility Among Combinatorial Problems", in which he showed that 21 diverse combinatorial and graph theoretical problems, each infamous for its computational intractability, are NP-complete.
288	1247	The role of teacher is often formal and ongoing, carried out at a school or other place of formal education.
288	1248	In many countries, a person who wishes to become a teacher must first obtain specified professional qualifications or credentials from a university or college.
288	1249	These professional qualifications may include the study of pedagogy, the science of teaching.
288	1250	Teachers, like other professionals, may have to continue their education after they qualify, a process known as continuing professional development.
288	1251	Teachers may use a lesson plan to facilitate student learning, providing a course of study which is called the curriculum.
289	1252	A teacher's role may vary among cultures.
289	1253	Teachers may provide instruction in literacy and numeracy, craftsmanship or vocational training, the arts, religion, civics, community roles, or life skills.
290	1254	In some countries, formal education can take place through home schooling.
290	1255	Informal learning may be assisted by a teacher occupying a transient or ongoing role, such as a family member, or by anyone with knowledge or skills in the wider community setting.
291	1256	Religious and spiritual teachers, such as gurus, mullahs, rabbis, pastors/youth pastors and lamas, may teach religious texts such as the Quran, Torah or Bible.
292	1257	Teaching may be carried out informally, within the family, which is called homeschooling, or in the wider community.
292	1258	Formal teaching may be carried out by paid professionals.
292	1259	Such professionals enjoy a status in some societies on a par with physicians, lawyers, engineers, and accountants (Chartered or CPA).
293	1260	A teacher's professional duties may extend beyond formal teaching.
293	1261	Outside of the classroom teachers may accompany students on field trips, supervise study halls, help with the organization of school functions, and serve as supervisors for extracurricular activities.
293	1262	In some education systems, teachers may have responsibility for student discipline.
294	1263	There are a variety of bodies designed to instill, preserve and update the knowledge and professional standing of teachers.
294	1264	Around the world many governments operate teacher's colleges, which are generally established to serve and protect the public interest through certifying, governing and enforcing the standards of practice for the teaching profession.
295	1265	The functions of the teacher's colleges may include setting out clear standards of practice, providing for the ongoing education of teachers, investigating complaints involving members, conducting hearings into allegations of professional misconduct and taking appropriate disciplinary action and accrediting teacher education programs.
295	1266	In many situations teachers in publicly funded schools must be members in good standing with the college, and private schools may also require their teachers to be college peoples.
295	1267	In other areas these roles may belong to the State Board of Education, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, the State Education Agency or other governmental bodies.
295	1268	In still other areas Teaching Unions may be responsible for some or all of these duties.
296	1269	In education, teachers facilitate student learning, often in a school or academy or perhaps in another environment such as outdoors.
296	1270	A teacher who teaches on an individual basis may be described as a tutor.
297	1271	The objective is typically accomplished through either an informal or formal approach to learning, including a course of study and lesson plan that teaches skills, knowledge and/or thinking skills.
297	1272	Different ways to teach are often referred to as pedagogy.
297	1273	When deciding what teaching method to use teachers consider students' background knowledge, environment, and their learning goals as well as standardized curricula as determined by the relevant authority.
297	1274	Many times, teachers assist in learning outside of the classroom by accompanying students on field trips.
297	1275	The increasing use of technology, specifically the rise of the internet over the past decade, has begun to shape the way teachers approach their roles in the classroom.
298	1276	The objective is typically a course of study, lesson plan, or a practical skill.
298	1277	A teacher may follow standardized curricula as determined by the relevant authority.
298	1278	The teacher may interact with students of different ages, from infants to adults, students with different abilities and students with learning disabilities.
299	1279	Teaching using pedagogy also involve assessing the educational levels of the students on particular skills.
299	1280	Understanding the pedagogy of the students in a classroom involves using differentiated instruction as well as supervision to meet the needs of all students in the classroom.
299	1281	Pedagogy can be thought of in two manners.
299	1282	First, teaching itself can be taught in many different ways, hence, using a pedagogy of teaching styles.
299	1283	Second, the pedagogy of the learners comes into play when a teacher assesses the pedagogic diversity of his/her students and differentiates for the individual students accordingly.
299	1284	For example, an experienced teacher and parent described the place of a teacher in learning as follows: "The real bulk of learning takes place in self-study and problem solving with a lot of feedback around that loop.
299	1285	The function of the teacher is to pressure the lazy, inspire the bored, deflate the cocky, encourage the timid, detect and correct individual flaws, and broaden the viewpoint of all.
299	1286	This function looks like that of a coach using the whole gamut of psychology to get each new class of rookies off the bench and into the game."
300	1287	Perhaps the most significant difference between primary school and secondary school teaching is the relationship between teachers and children.
300	1288	In primary schools each class has a teacher who stays with them for most of the week and will teach them the whole curriculum.
300	1289	In secondary schools they will be taught by different subject specialists each session during the week and may have ten or more different teachers.
300	1290	The relationship between children and their teachers tends to be closer in the primary school where they act as form tutor, specialist teacher and surrogate parent during the course of the day.
301	1291	This is true throughout most of the United States as well.
301	1292	However, alternative approaches for primary education do exist.
301	1293	One of these, sometimes referred to as a "platoon" system, involves placing a group of students together in one class that moves from one specialist to another for every subject.
301	1294	The advantage here is that students learn from teachers who specialize in one subject and who tend to be more knowledgeable in that one area than a teacher who teaches many subjects.
301	1295	Students still derive a strong sense of security by staying with the same group of peers for all classes.
302	1296	Co-teaching has also become a new trend amongst educational institutions.
302	1297	Co-teaching is defined as two or more teachers working harmoniously to fulfill the needs of every student in the classroom.
302	1298	Co-teaching focuses the student on learning by providing a social networking support that allows them to reach their full cognitive potential.
302	1299	Co-teachers work in sync with one another to create a climate of learning.
303	1300	Throughout the history of education the most common form of school discipline was corporal punishment.
303	1301	While a child was in school, a teacher was expected to act as a substitute parent, with all the normal forms of parental discipline open to them.
304	1302	In past times, corporal punishment (spanking or paddling or caning or strapping or birching the student in order to cause physical pain) was one of the most common forms of school discipline throughout much of the world.
304	1303	Most Western countries, and some others, have now banned it, but it remains lawful in the United States following a US Supreme Court decision in 1977 which held that paddling did not violate the US Constitution.
305	1304	30 US states have banned corporal punishment, the others (mostly in the South) have not.
305	1305	It is still used to a significant (though declining) degree in some public schools in Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas.
305	1306	Private schools in these and most other states may also use it.
305	1307	Corporal punishment in American schools is administered to the seat of the student's trousers or skirt with a specially made wooden paddle.
305	1308	This often used to take place in the classroom or hallway, but nowadays the punishment is usually given privately in the principal's office.
306	1309	Official corporal punishment, often by caning, remains commonplace in schools in some Asian, African and Caribbean countries.
306	1310	For details of individual countries see School corporal punishment.
307	1311	Currently detention is one of the most common punishments in schools in the United States, the UK, Ireland, Singapore and other countries.
307	1312	It requires the pupil to remain in school at a given time in the school day (such as lunch, recess or after school); or even to attend school on a non-school day, e.g.
307	1313	"Saturday detention" held at some schools.
307	1314	During detention, students normally have to sit in a classroom and do work, write lines or a punishment essay, or sit quietly.
308	1315	A modern example of school discipline in North America and Western Europe relies upon the idea of an assertive teacher who is prepared to impose their will upon a class.
308	1316	Positive reinforcement is balanced with immediate and fair punishment for misbehavior and firm, clear boundaries define what is appropriate and inappropriate behavior.
308	1317	Teachers are expected to respect their students; sarcasm and attempts to humiliate pupils are seen as falling outside of what constitutes reasonable discipline.
309	1318	Whilst this is the consensus viewpoint amongst the majority of academics, some teachers and parents advocate a more assertive and confrontational style of discipline.
309	1319	[citation needed] Such individuals claim that many problems with modern schooling stem from the weakness in school discipline and if teachers exercised firm control over the classroom they would be able to teach more efficiently.
309	1320	This viewpoint is supported by the educational attainment of countries—in East Asia for instance—that combine strict discipline with high standards of education.
310	1321	It's not clear, however that this stereotypical view reflects the reality of East Asian classrooms or that the educational goals in these countries are commensurable with those in Western countries.
310	1322	In Japan, for example, although average attainment on standardized tests may exceed those in Western countries, classroom discipline and behavior is highly problematic.
310	1323	Although, officially, schools have extremely rigid codes of behavior, in practice many teachers find the students unmanageable and do not enforce discipline at all.
311	1324	Where school class sizes are typically 40 to 50 students, maintaining order in the classroom can divert the teacher from instruction, leaving little opportunity for concentration and focus on what is being taught.
311	1325	In response, teachers may concentrate their attention on motivated students, ignoring attention-seeking and disruptive students.
311	1326	The result of this is that motivated students, facing demanding university entrance examinations, receive disproportionate resources.
311	1327	Given the emphasis on attainment of university places, administrators and governors may regard this policy as appropriate.
312	1328	Sudbury model democratic schools claim that popularly based authority can maintain order more effectively than dictatorial authority for governments and schools alike.
312	1329	They also claim that in these schools the preservation of public order is easier and more efficient than anywhere else.
312	1330	Primarily because rules and regulations are made by the community as a whole, thence the school atmosphere is one of persuasion and negotiation, rather than confrontation since there is no one to confront.
312	1331	Sudbury model democratic schools' proponents argue that a school that has good, clear laws, fairly and democratically passed by the entire school community, and a good judicial system for enforcing these laws, is a school in which community discipline prevails, and in which an increasingly sophisticated concept of law and order develops, against other schools today, where rules are arbitrary, authority is absolute, punishment is capricious, and due process of law is unknown.
313	1332	Since teachers can affect how students perceive the course materials, it has been found that teachers who showed enthusiasm towards the course materials and students can affect a positive learning experience towards the course materials.
313	1333	On teacher/course evaluations, it was found that teachers who have a positive disposition towards the course content tend to transfer their passion to receptive students.
313	1334	These teachers do not teach by rote but attempt to find new invigoration for the course materials on a daily basis.
313	1335	One of the difficulties in this approach is that teachers may have repeatedly covered a curriculum until they begin to feel bored with the subject which in turn bores the students as well.
313	1336	Students who had enthusiastic teachers tend to rate them higher than teachers who didn't show much enthusiasm for the course materials.
314	1337	Teachers that exhibit enthusiasm can lead to students who are more likely to be engaged, interested, energetic, and curious about learning the subject matter.
314	1338	Recent research has found a correlation between teacher enthusiasm and students' intrinsic motivation to learn and vitality in the classroom.
314	1339	Controlled, experimental studies exploring intrinsic motivation of college students has shown that nonverbal expressions of enthusiasm, such as demonstrative gesturing, dramatic movements which are varied, and emotional facial expressions, result in college students reporting higher levels of intrinsic motivation to learn.
314	1340	Students who experienced a very enthusiastic teacher were more likely to read lecture material outside of the classroom.
315	1341	There are various mechanisms by which teacher enthusiasm may facilitate higher levels of intrinsic motivation.
315	1342	Teacher enthusiasm may contribute to a classroom atmosphere full of energy and enthusiasm which feed student interest and excitement in learning the subject matter.
315	1343	Enthusiastic teachers may also lead to students becoming more self-determined in their own learning process.
315	1344	The concept of mere exposure indicates that the teacher's enthusiasm may contribute to the student's expectations about intrinsic motivation in the context of learning.
315	1345	Also, enthusiasm may act as a "motivational embellishment"; increasing a student's interest by the variety, novelty, and surprise of the enthusiastic teacher's presentation of the material.
315	1346	Finally, the concept of emotional contagion, may also apply.
315	1347	Students may become more intrinsically motivated by catching onto the enthusiasm and energy of the teacher.
316	1348	Research shows that student motivation and attitudes towards school are closely linked to student-teacher relationships.
316	1349	Enthusiastic teachers are particularly good at creating beneficial relations with their students.
316	1350	Their ability to create effective learning environments that foster student achievement depends on the kind of relationship they build with their students.
316	1351	Useful teacher-to-student interactions are crucial in linking academic success with personal achievement.
316	1352	Here, personal success is a student's internal goal of improving himself, whereas academic success includes the goals he receives from his superior.
316	1353	A teacher must guide his student in aligning his personal goals with his academic goals.
316	1354	Students who receive this positive influence show stronger self-confidence and greater personal and academic success than those without these teacher interactions.
317	1355	Students are likely to build stronger relations with teachers who are friendly and supportive and will show more interest in courses taught by these teachers.
317	1356	Teachers that spend more time interacting and working directly with students are perceived as supportive and effective teachers.
317	1357	Effective teachers have been shown to invite student participation and decision making, allow humor into their classroom, and demonstrate a willingness to play.
318	1358	The way a teacher promotes the course they are teaching, the more the student will get out of the subject matter.
318	1359	The three most important aspects of teacher enthusiasm are enthusiasm about teaching, enthusiasm about the students, and enthusiasm about the subject matter.
318	1360	If they do not enjoy what they are doing, the students will be able to tell.
318	1361	They also must enjoy being around their students.
318	1362	A teacher who cares for their students is going to help that individual succeed in their life in the future.
318	1363	The teacher also needs to be enthusiastic about the subject matter they are teaching.
318	1364	For example, a teacher talking about chemistry needs to enjoy the art of chemistry and show that to their students.
318	1365	A spark in the teacher may create a spark of excitement in the student as well.
318	1366	An enthusiastic teacher has the ability to be very influential in the young students life.
319	1367	Misconduct by teachers, especially sexual misconduct, has been getting increased scrutiny from the media and the courts.
319	1368	A study by the American Association of University Women reported that 9.6% of students in the United States claim to have received unwanted sexual attention from an adult associated with education; be they a volunteer, bus driver, teacher, administrator or other adult; sometime during their educational career.
320	1369	A study in England showed a 0.3% prevalence of sexual abuse by any professional, a group that included priests, religious leaders, and case workers as well as teachers.
320	1370	It is important to note, however, that the British study referenced above is the only one of its kind and consisted of "a random ... probability sample of 2,869 young people between the ages of 18 and 24 in a computer-assisted study" and that the questions referred to "sexual abuse with a professional," not necessarily a teacher.
320	1371	It is therefore logical to conclude that information on the percentage of abuses by teachers in the United Kingdom is not explicitly available and therefore not necessarily reliable.
320	1372	The AAUW study, however, posed questions about fourteen types of sexual harassment and various degrees of frequency and included only abuses by teachers.
320	1373	"The sample was drawn from a list of 80,000 schools to create a stratified two-stage sample design of 2,065 8th to 11th grade students"Its reliability was gauged at 95% with a 4% margin of error.
321	1374	In the United States especially, several high-profile cases such as Debra LaFave, Pamela Rogers, and Mary Kay Letourneau have caused increased scrutiny on teacher misconduct.
322	1375	Chris Keates, the general secretary of National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said that teachers who have sex with pupils over the age of consent should not be placed on the sex offenders register and that prosecution for statutory rape "is a real anomaly in the law that we are concerned about."
322	1376	This has led to outrage from child protection and parental rights groups.
322	1377	Fears of being labelled a pedophile or hebephile has led to several men who enjoy teaching avoiding the profession.
322	1378	This has in some jurisdictions reportedly led to a shortage of male teachers.
323	1379	Teachers face several occupational hazards in their line of work, including occupational stress, which can negatively impact teachers' mental and physical health, productivity, and students' performance.
323	1380	Stress can be caused by organizational change, relationships with students, fellow teachers, and administrative personnel, working environment, expectations to substitute, long hours with a heavy workload, and inspections.
323	1381	Teachers are also at high risk for occupational burnout.
324	1382	A 2000 study found that 42% of UK teachers experienced occupational stress, twice the figure for the average profession.
324	1383	A 2012 study found that teachers experienced double the rate of anxiety, depression, and stress than average workers.
325	1384	There are several ways to mitigate the occupational hazards of teaching.
325	1385	Organizational interventions, like changing teachers' schedules, providing support networks and mentoring, changing the work environment, and offering promotions and bonuses, may be effective in helping to reduce occupational stress among teachers.
325	1386	Individual-level interventions, including stress-management training and counseling, are also used to relieve occupational stress among teachers.
326	1387	There are many similarities and differences among teachers around the world.
326	1388	In almost all countries teachers are educated in a university or college.
326	1389	Governments may require certification by a recognized body before they can teach in a school.
326	1390	In many countries, elementary school education certificate is earned after completion of high school.
326	1391	The high school student follows an education specialty track, obtain the prerequisite "student-teaching" time, and receive a special diploma to begin teaching after graduation.
326	1392	In addition to certification, many educational institutions especially within the US, require that prospective teachers pass a background check and psychiatric evaluation to be able to teach in classroom.
326	1393	This is not always the case with adult further learning institutions but is fast becoming the norm in many countries as security concerns grow.
327	1394	Education in Australia is primarily the responsibility of the individual states and territories.
327	1395	Generally, education in Australia follows the three-tier model which includes primary education (primary schools), followed by secondary education (secondary schools/high schools) and tertiary education (universities and/or TAFE colleges).
328	1396	Teaching in Canada requires a post-secondary degree Bachelor's Degree.
328	1397	In most provinces a second Bachelor's Degree such as a Bachelor of Education is required to become a qualified teacher.
328	1398	Salary ranges from $40,000/year to $90,000/yr.
328	1399	Teachers have the option to teach for a public school which is funded by the provincial government or teaching in a private school which is funded by the private sector, businesses and sponsors.
329	1400	In Germany, teachers are mainly civil servants recruited in special university classes, called Lehramtstudien (Teaching Education Studies).
329	1401	There are many differences between the teachers for elementary schools (Grundschule), lower secondary schools (Hauptschule), middle level secondary schools (Realschule) and higher level secondary schools (Gymnasium).

330	1403	Salaries for primary teachers in Ireland depend mainly on seniority (i.e.

330	1405	Extra pay is also given for teaching through the Irish language, in a Gaeltacht area or on an island.
330	1406	The basic pay for a starting teacher is €27,814 p.a., rising incrementally to €53,423 for a teacher with 25 years service.
330	1407	A principal of a large school with many years experience and several qualifications (M.A., H.Dip., etc.)
331	1408	Teachers are required to be registered with the Teaching Council; under Section 30 of the Teaching Council Act 2001, a person employed in any capacity in a recognised teaching post - who is not registered with the Teaching Council - may not be paid from Oireachtas funds.
332	1409	From 2006 Garda vetting has been introduced for new entrants to the teaching profession.

332	1411	Existing staff will be vetted on a phased basis.
333	1412	Salaries for Nursery, Primary and Secondary School teachers ranged from £20,133 to £41,004 in September 2007, although some salaries can go much higher depending on experience and extra responsibilities.
333	1413	Preschool teachers may earn £20,980 annually.
333	1414	[citation needed] Teachers in state schools must have at least a bachelor's degree, complete an approved teacher education program, and be licensed.
334	1415	Many counties offer alternative licensing programs to attract people into teaching, especially for hard-to-fill positions.
334	1416	Excellent job opportunities are expected as retirements, especially among secondary school teachers, outweigh slowing enrollment growth; opportunities will vary by geographic area and subject taught.
335	1417	In Scotland, anyone wishing to teach must be registered with the General Teaching Council for Scotland (GTCS).
335	1418	Teaching in Scotland is an all graduate profession and the normal route for graduates wishing to teach is to complete a programme of Initial Teacher Education (ITE) at one of the seven Scottish Universities who offer these courses.
335	1419	Once successfully completed, "Provisional Registration" is given by the GTCS which is raised to "Full Registration" status after a year if there is sufficient evidence to show that the "Standard for Full Registration" has been met.
336	1420	For the salary year beginning April 2008, unpromoted teachers in Scotland earned from £20,427 for a Probationer, up to £32,583 after 6 years teaching, but could then go on to earn up to £39,942 as they complete the modules to earn Chartered Teacher Status (requiring at least 6 years at up to two modules per year.)
336	1421	Promotion to Principal Teacher positions attracts a salary of between £34,566 and £44,616; Deputy Head, and Head teachers earn from £40,290 to £78,642.
336	1422	Teachers in Scotland can be registered members of trade unions with the main ones being the Educational Institute of Scotland and the Scottish Secondary Teachers' Association.
337	1423	Education in Wales differs in certain respects from education elsewhere in the United Kingdom.
337	1424	For example, a significant number of students all over Wales are educated either wholly or largely through the medium of Welsh: in 2008/09, 22 per cent of classes in maintained primary schools used Welsh as the sole or main medium of instruction.
337	1425	Welsh medium education is available to all age groups through nurseries, schools, colleges and universities and in adult education; lessons in the language itself are compulsory for all pupils until the age of 16.
338	1426	Teachers in Wales can be registered members of trade unions such as ATL, NUT or NASUWT and reports in recent years suggest that the average age of teachers in Wales is falling with teachers being younger than in previous years.
338	1427	A growing cause of concern are that attacks on teachers in Welsh schools which reached an all-time high between 2005 and 2010.
339	1428	In the United States, each state determines the requirements for getting a license to teach in public schools.
339	1429	Teaching certification generally lasts three years, but teachers can receive certificates that last as long as ten years.
339	1430	Public school teachers are required to have a bachelor's degree and the majority must be certified by the state in which they teach.
339	1431	Many charter schools do not require that their teachers be certified, provided they meet the standards to be highly qualified as set by No Child Left Behind.
339	1432	Additionally, the requirements for substitute/temporary teachers are generally not as rigorous as those for full-time professionals.
339	1433	The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that there are 1.4 million elementary school teachers, 674,000 middle school teachers, and 1 million secondary school teachers employed in the U.S.
340	1434	In the past, teachers have been paid relatively low salaries.
340	1435	However, average teacher salaries have improved rapidly in recent years.
340	1436	US teachers are generally paid on graduated scales, with income depending on experience.
340	1437	Teachers with more experience and higher education earn more than those with a standard bachelor's degree and certificate.
340	1438	Salaries vary greatly depending on state, relative cost of living, and grade taught.
340	1439	Salaries also vary within states where wealthy suburban school districts generally have higher salary schedules than other districts.
340	1440	The median salary for all primary and secondary teachers was $46,000 in 2004, with the average entry salary for a teacher with a bachelor's degree being an estimated $32,000.
340	1441	Median salaries for preschool teachers, however, were less than half the national median for secondary teachers, clock in at an estimated $21,000 in 2004.
340	1442	For high school teachers, median salaries in 2007 ranged from $35,000 in South Dakota to $71,000 in New York, with a national median of $52,000.
340	1443	Some contracts may include long-term disability insurance, life insurance, emergency/personal leave and investment options.
340	1444	The American Federation of Teachers' teacher salary survey for the 2006-07 school year found that the average teacher salary was $51,009.
340	1445	In a salary survey report for K-12 teachers, elementary school teachers had the lowest median salary earning $39,259.
340	1446	High school teachers had the highest median salary earning $41,855.
340	1447	Many teachers take advantage of the opportunity to increase their income by supervising after-school programs and other extracurricular activities.
340	1448	In addition to monetary compensation, public school teachers may also enjoy greater benefits (like health insurance) compared to other occupations.
340	1449	Merit pay systems are on the rise for teachers, paying teachers extra money based on excellent classroom evaluations, high test scores and for high success at their overall school.
340	1450	Also, with the advent of the internet, many teachers are now selling their lesson plans to other teachers through the web in order to earn supplemental income, most notably on TeachersPayTeachers.com.
341	1451	There are many forms of spiritual or religious teachers in Christianity, across all three major traditions - (Roman) Catholic, (Eastern) Orthodox Catholic, and Protestant/Non-Denominational, with a stronger tradition of spiritual formation in the more historic and authoritarian/hierarchical Christian traditions with a long tradition of "discernment of spirits", of vocations, and other aspects of spiritual life, especially the Roman and Orthodox Catholic Churches.
341	1452	In keeping with the individualistic nature of most Protestant denominations, the emphasis on being guided in spiritual development is small, with a heavy emphasis placed on heavy reading and personal, Spirit-enlightened interpretation of the Holy Bible.
342	1453	In The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church), the teacher is an office in the Aaronic priesthood, generally conferred on young boys or recent converts, and has little in common with the "spiritual teacher" archetype.
342	1454	The role of "spiritual teacher" may be filled by many individuals in the LDS Church, often a trusted friend, who may hold any office, from Elder to Bishop, or no office at all.
342	1455	The emphasis on spiritual mentorship in the LDS Church is similar to that in the more "low-church" traditions of Protestantism, with a stronger emphasis placed on the husband and father of a family to provide spiritual guidance for all of his family, ideally in consultation with his wife, even if the husband is not a member of the LDS Church, based on interpretatios of certain Biblical texts which proclaim the spiritual authority of husbands in marriage.
342	1456	Even Priesthood representatives are expected to defer to the father of the house when in his home.
342	1457	Further, additional spiritual guidance is offered by those holding the office of Patriarch, which is supposed by Latter-day Saints to grant certain gifts of the Spirit, such as the ability to prophesy, to its holders.
342	1458	This guidance is generally offered during a ceremony called the patriarchal blessing.
343	1459	In Hinduism the spiritual teacher is known as a guru, and, in many traditions of Hinduism - especially those common in the West - the emphasis on spiritual mentorship is extremely high, with gurus often exercising a great deal of control over the lives of their disciples.
344	1460	In Tibetan Buddhism the teachers of Dharma in Tibet are most commonly called a Lama.
344	1461	A Lama who has through phowa and siddhi consciously determined to be reborn, often many times, in order to continue their Bodhisattva vow is called a Tulku.
345	1462	There are many concepts of teachers in Islam, ranging from mullahs (the teachers at madrassas) to ulemas, who teach of the laws of Islam for the proper way of Islamic living according to the Sunnah and Ahadith, and can render legal verdicts upon matters of Islamic law in accordance with the teaching of one of the Four Schools of Jurisprudence.
345	1463	In the more spiritual or mystical Islamic tradition of Sufism, the position of spiritual teacher and an esoteric (as opposed to exoteric, or actions-oriented, e.g.
345	1464	the Five Pillars of Islam) spirituality and spiritual knowledge takes on a more important dimension, with emphasis on learning from living saints - the highest of which is a Qutb - and of traditions passed down from initiate to initiate, and traceable back to the founder of the order.
346	1465	Martin Luther (/ˈluːθər/ or /ˈluːðər/; German: [ˈmaɐ̯tiːn ˈlʊtɐ] ( listen); 10 November 1483 – 18 February 1546) was a German professor of theology, composer, priest, former monk and a seminal figure in the Protestant Reformation.
346	1466	Luther came to reject several teachings and practices of the Late Medieval Catholic Church.
346	1467	He strongly disputed the claim that freedom from God's punishment for sin could be purchased with money.
346	1468	He proposed an academic discussion of the power and usefulness of indulgences in his Ninety-Five Theses of 1517.
346	1469	His refusal to retract all of his writings at the demand of Pope Leo X in 1520 and the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V at the Diet of Worms in 1521 resulted in his excommunication by the Pope and condemnation as an outlaw by the Emperor.
347	1470	Luther taught that salvation and subsequently eternal life is not earned by good deeds but is received only as a free gift of God's grace through faith in Jesus Christ as redeemer from sin.
347	1471	His theology challenged the authority and office of the Pope by teaching that the Bible is the only source of divinely revealed knowledge from God and opposed sacerdotalism by considering all baptized Christians to be a holy priesthood.
347	1472	Those who identify with these, and all of Luther's wider teachings, are called Lutherans even though Luther insisted on Christian or Evangelical as the only acceptable names for individuals who professed Christ.
348	1473	His translation of the Bible into the vernacular (instead of Latin) made it more accessible, which had a tremendous impact on the church and German culture.
348	1474	It fostered the development of a standard version of the German language, added several principles to the art of translation, and influenced the writing of an English translation, the Tyndale Bible.
348	1475	His hymns influenced the development of singing in churches.
348	1476	His marriage to Katharina von Bora set a model for the practice of clerical marriage, allowing Protestant clergy to marry.
349	1477	Martin Luther was born to Hans Luder (or Ludher, later Luther) and his wife Margarethe (née Lindemann) on 10 November 1483 in Eisleben, Saxony, then part of the Holy Roman Empire.
349	1478	He was baptized as a Catholic the next morning on the feast day of St. Martin of Tours.
349	1479	His family moved to Mansfeld in 1484, where his father was a leaseholder of copper mines and smelters and served as one of four citizen representatives on the local council.
349	1480	The religious scholar Martin Marty describes Luther's mother as a hard-working woman of "trading-class stock and middling means" and notes that Luther's enemies later wrongly described her as a whore and bath attendant.
349	1481	He had several brothers and sisters, and is known to have been close to one of them, Jacob.
349	1482	Hans Luther was ambitious for himself and his family, and he was determined to see Martin, his eldest son, become a lawyer.
349	1483	He sent Martin to Latin schools in Mansfeld, then Magdeburg in 1497, where he attended a school operated by a lay group called the Brethren of the Common Life, and Eisenach in 1498.
349	1484	The three schools focused on the so-called "trivium": grammar, rhetoric, and logic.
349	1485	Luther later compared his education there to purgatory and hell.
350	1486	In 1501, at the age of 19, he entered the University of Erfurt, which he later described as a beerhouse and whorehouse.
350	1487	He was made to wake at four every morning for what has been described as "a day of rote learning and often wearying spiritual exercises."
350	1488	He received his master's degree in 1505.
351	1489	In accordance with his father's wishes, Luther enrolled in law school at the same university that year but dropped out almost immediately, believing that law represented uncertainty.
351	1490	Luther sought assurances about life and was drawn to theology and philosophy, expressing particular interest in Aristotle, William of Ockham, and Gabriel Biel.
351	1491	He was deeply influenced by two tutors, Bartholomaeus Arnoldi von Usingen and Jodocus Trutfetter, who taught him to be suspicious of even the greatest thinkers and to test everything himself by experience.
351	1492	Philosophy proved to be unsatisfying, offering assurance about the use of reason but none about loving God, which to Luther was more important.
351	1493	Reason could not lead men to God, he felt, and he thereafter developed a love-hate relationship with Aristotle over the latter's emphasis on reason.
351	1494	For Luther, reason could be used to question men and institutions, but not God.
351	1495	Human beings could learn about God only through divine revelation, he believed, and Scripture therefore became increasingly important to him.
352	1496	He later attributed his decision to an event: on 2 July 1505, he was returning to university on horseback after a trip home.
352	1497	During a thunderstorm, a lightning bolt struck near him.
352	1498	Later telling his father he was terrified of death and divine judgment, he cried out, "Help!
352	1499	Saint Anna, I will become a monk!"
352	1500	He came to view his cry for help as a vow he could never break.
352	1501	He left law school, sold his books, and entered a closed Augustinian cloister in Erfurt on 17 July 1505.
352	1502	One friend blamed the decision on Luther's sadness over the deaths of two friends.
352	1503	Luther himself seemed saddened by the move.
352	1504	Those who attended a farewell supper walked him to the door of the Black Cloister.
352	1505	"This day you see me, and then, not ever again," he said.
352	1506	His father was furious over what he saw as a waste of Luther's education.
353	1507	Luther dedicated himself to the Augustinian order, devoting himself to fasting, long hours in prayer, pilgrimage, and frequent confession.
353	1508	Luther described this period of his life as one of deep spiritual despair.
353	1509	He said, "I lost touch with Christ the Savior and Comforter, and made of him the jailer and hangman of my poor soul."
353	1510	Johann von Staupitz, his superior, pointed Luther's mind away from continual reflection upon his sins toward the merits of Christ.
353	1511	He taught that true repentance does not involve self-inflicted penances and punishments but rather a change of heart.
354	1512	In 1507, he was ordained to the priesthood, and in 1508, von Staupitz, first dean of the newly founded University of Wittenberg, sent for Luther, to teach theology.
354	1513	He received a bachelor's degree in Biblical studies on 9 March 1508, and another bachelor's degree in the Sentences by Peter Lombard in 1509.
355	1514	On 19 October 1512, he was awarded his Doctor of Theology and, on 21 October 1512, was received into the senate of the theological faculty of the University of Wittenberg, having been called to the position of Doctor in Bible.
355	1515	He spent the rest of his career in this position at the University of Wittenberg.
356	1516	In 1516, Johann Tetzel, a Dominican friar and papal commissioner for indulgences, was sent to Germany by the Roman Catholic Church to sell indulgences to raise money to rebuild St. Peter's Basilica in Rome.
356	1517	Roman Catholic theology stated that faith alone, whether fiduciary or dogmatic, cannot justify man; justification rather depends only on such faith as is active in charity and good works (fides caritate formata).
356	1518	The benefits of good works could be obtained by donating money to the church.
357	1519	On 31 October 1517, Luther wrote to his bishop, Albert of Mainz, protesting the sale of indulgences.
357	1520	He enclosed in his letter a copy of his "Disputation of Martin Luther on the Power and Efficacy of Indulgences", which came to be known as The Ninety-Five Theses.
357	1521	Hans Hillerbrand writes that Luther had no intention of confronting the church, but saw his disputation as a scholarly objection to church practices, and the tone of the writing is accordingly "searching, rather than doctrinaire."
357	1522	Hillerbrand writes that there is nevertheless an undercurrent of challenge in several of the theses, particularly in Thesis 86, which asks: "Why does the pope, whose wealth today is greater than the wealth of the richest Crassus, build the basilica of St. Peter with the money of poor believers rather than with his own money?"
358	1523	Luther objected to a saying attributed to Johann Tetzel that "As soon as the coin in the coffer rings, the soul from purgatory (also attested as 'into heaven') springs."
359	1524	He insisted that, since forgiveness was God's alone to grant, those who claimed that indulgences absolved buyers from all punishments and granted them salvation were in error.
359	1525	Christians, he said, must not slacken in following Christ on account of such false assurances.
360	1526	However, this oft-quoted saying of Tetzel was by no means representative of contemporary Catholic teaching on indulgences, but rather a reflection of his capacity to exaggerate.
360	1527	Yet if Tetzel overstated the matter in regard to indulgences for the dead, his teaching on indulgences for the living was in line with Catholic dogma of the time.
361	1528	According to scholars Walter Krämer, Götz Trenkler, Gerhard Ritter, and Gerhard Prause, the story of the posting on the door, even though it has settled as one of the pillars of history, has little foundation in truth.
361	1529	The story is based on comments made by Philipp Melanchthon, though it is thought that he was not in Wittenberg at the time.
362	1530	It was not until January 1518 that friends of Luther translated the 95 Theses from Latin into German and printed and widely copied them, making the controversy one of the first in history to be aided by the printing press.
362	1531	Within two weeks, copies of the theses had spread throughout Germany; within two months, they had spread throughout Europe.
363	1532	Luther's writings circulated widely, reaching France, England, and Italy as early as 1519.
363	1533	Students thronged to Wittenberg to hear Luther speak.
363	1534	He published a short commentary on Galatians and his Work on the Psalms.
363	1535	This early part of Luther's career was one of his most creative and productive.
363	1536	Three of his best-known works were published in 1520: To the Christian Nobility of the German Nation, On the Babylonian Captivity of the Church, and On the Freedom of a Christian.
364	1537	From 1510 to 1520, Luther lectured on the Psalms, the books of Hebrews, Romans, and Galatians.
364	1538	As he studied these portions of the Bible, he came to view the use of terms such as penance and righteousness by the Catholic Church in new ways.
364	1539	He became convinced that the church was corrupt in its ways and had lost sight of what he saw as several of the central truths of Christianity.
364	1540	The most important for Luther was the doctrine of justification – God's act of declaring a sinner righteous – by faith alone through God's grace.
364	1541	He began to teach that salvation or redemption is a gift of God's grace, attainable only through faith in Jesus as the Messiah.
364	1542	"This one and firm rock, which we call the doctrine of justification," he wrote, "is the chief article of the whole Christian doctrine, which comprehends the understanding of all godliness."
365	1543	Luther came to understand justification as entirely the work of God.
365	1544	This teaching by Luther was clearly expressed in his 1525 publication On the Bondage of the Will, which was written in response to On Free Will by Desiderius Erasmus (1524).
365	1545	Luther based his position on predestination on St. Paul's epistle to the Ephesians 2:8–10.
365	1546	Against the teaching of his day that the righteous acts of believers are performed in cooperation with God, Luther wrote that Christians receive such righteousness entirely from outside themselves; that righteousness not only comes from Christ but actually is the righteousness of Christ, imputed to Christians (rather than infused into them) through faith.
365	1547	"That is why faith alone makes someone just and fulfills the law," he wrote.
365	1548	"Faith is that which brings the Holy Spirit through the merits of Christ."
365	1549	Faith, for Luther, was a gift from God; the experience of being justified by faith was "as though I had been born again."
365	1550	His entry into Paradise, no less, was a discovery about "the righteousness of God" – a discovery that "the just person" of whom the Bible speaks (as in Romans 1:17) lives by faith.
365	1551	He explained his concept of "justification" in the Smalcald Articles:
366	1552	Luther's rediscovery of "Christ and His salvation" was the first of two points that became the foundation for the Reformation.
366	1553	His railing against the sale of indulgences was based on it.
367	1554	Archbishop Albrecht of Mainz and Magdeburg did not reply to Luther's letter containing the 95 Theses.
367	1555	He had the theses checked for heresy and in December 1517 forwarded them to Rome.
367	1556	He needed the revenue from the indulgences to pay off a papal dispensation for his tenure of more than one bishopric.
367	1557	As Luther later noted, "the pope had a finger in the pie as well, because one half was to go to the building of St Peter's Church in Rome".
368	1558	Pope Leo X was used to reformers and heretics, and he responded slowly, "with great care as is proper."
368	1559	Over the next three years he deployed a series of papal theologians and envoys against Luther, which served only to harden the reformer's anti-papal theology.
368	1560	First, the Dominican theologian Sylvester Mazzolini drafted a heresy case against Luther, whom Leo then summoned to Rome.
368	1561	The Elector Frederick persuaded the pope to have Luther examined at Augsburg, where the Imperial Diet was held.
368	1562	There, in October 1518, under questioning by papal legate Cardinal Cajetan Luther stated that he did not consider the papacy part of the biblical Church because historistical interpretation of Bible prophecy concluded that the papacy was the Antichrist.
368	1563	The prophecies concerning the Antichrist soon became the center of controversy.
368	1564	The hearings degenerated into a shouting match.
368	1565	More than his writing the 95 Theses, Luther's confrontation with the church cast him as an enemy of the pope.
368	1566	Cajetan's original instructions had been to arrest Luther if he failed to recant, but the legate desisted from doing so.
368	1567	Luther slipped out of the city at night, unbeknownst to Cajetan.
369	1568	In January 1519, at Altenburg in Saxony, the papal nuncio Karl von Miltitz adopted a more conciliatory approach.
369	1569	Luther made certain concessions to the Saxon, who was a relative of the Elector, and promised to remain silent if his opponents did.
369	1570	The theologian Johann Eck, however, was determined to expose Luther's doctrine in a public forum.
369	1571	In June and July 1519, he staged a disputation with Luther's colleague Andreas Karlstadt at Leipzig and invited Luther to speak.
369	1572	Luther's boldest assertion in the debate was that Matthew 16:18 does not confer on popes the exclusive right to interpret scripture, and that therefore neither popes nor church councils were infallible.
369	1573	For this, Eck branded Luther a new Jan Hus, referring to the Czech reformer and heretic burned at the stake in 1415.
369	1574	From that moment, he devoted himself to Luther's defeat.
370	1575	On 15 June 1520, the Pope warned Luther with the papal bull (edict) Exsurge Domine that he risked excommunication unless he recanted 41 sentences drawn from his writings, including the 95 Theses, within 60 days.
370	1576	That autumn, Johann Eck proclaimed the bull in Meissen and other towns.
370	1577	Karl von Miltitz, a papal nuncio, attempted to broker a solution, but Luther, who had sent the Pope a copy of On the Freedom of a Christian in October, publicly set fire to the bull and decretals at Wittenberg on 10 December 1520, an act he defended in Why the Pope and his Recent Book are Burned and Assertions Concerning All Articles.
370	1578	As a consequence, Luther was excommunicated by Pope Leo X on 3 January 1521, in the bull Decet Romanum Pontificem.
371	1579	The enforcement of the ban on the 95 Theses fell to the secular authorities.
371	1580	On 18 April 1521, Luther appeared as ordered before the Diet of Worms.
371	1581	This was a general assembly of the estates of the Holy Roman Empire that took place in Worms, a town on the Rhine.
371	1582	It was conducted from 28 January to 25 May 1521, with Emperor Charles V presiding.
371	1583	Prince Frederick III, Elector of Saxony, obtained a safe conduct for Luther to and from the meeting.
372	1584	Johann Eck, speaking on behalf of the Empire as assistant of the Archbishop of Trier, presented Luther with copies of his writings laid out on a table and asked him if the books were his, and whether he stood by their contents.
372	1585	Luther confirmed he was their author, but requested time to think about the answer to the second question.
372	1586	He prayed, consulted friends, and gave his response the next day:
373	1587	At the end of this speech, Luther raised his arm "in the traditional salute of a knight winning a bout."
373	1588	Michael Mullett considers this speech as a "world classic of epoch-making oratory."
374	1589	Luther refused to recant his writings.
374	1590	He is sometimes also quoted as saying: "Here I stand.
374	1591	Recent scholars consider the evidence for these words to be unreliable, since they were inserted before "May God help me" only in later versions of the speech and not recorded in witness accounts of the proceedings.
374	1592	However, Mullett suggests that given his nature, "we are free to believe that Luther would tend to select the more dramatic form of words."
375	1593	Over the next five days, private conferences were held to determine Luther's fate.
375	1594	The Emperor presented the final draft of the Edict of Worms on 25 May 1521, declaring Luther an outlaw, banning his literature, and requiring his arrest: "We want him to be apprehended and punished as a notorious heretic."
