491	2066	Sky UK Limited (formerly British Sky Broadcasting or BSkyB) is a British telecommunications company which serves the United Kingdom.
491	2067	Sky provides television and broadband internet services and fixed line telephone services to consumers and businesses in the United Kingdom.
491	2068	It is the UK's largest pay-TV broadcaster with 11 million customers as of 2015.
491	2069	It was the UK's most popular digital TV service until it was overtaken by Freeview in April 2007.
491	2070	Its corporate headquarters are based in Isleworth.
492	2071	On 18 November 2015, Sky announced Sky Q, a range of products and services to be available in 2016.
492	2072	The Sky Q range consists of three set top boxes (Sky Q, Sky Q Silver and Sky Q Mini), a broadband router (Sky Q Hub) and mobile applications.
492	2073	The Sky Q set top boxes introduce a new user interface, Wi-Fi hotspot functionality, Power-line and Bluetooth connectivity and a new touch-sensitive remote control.
492	2074	The Sky Q Mini set top boxes connect to the Sky Q Silver set top boxes with a Wi-Fi or Power-line connection rather than receive their own satellite feeds.
492	2075	This allows all set top boxes in a household to share recordings and other media.
492	2076	The Sky Q Silver set top box is capable of receiving and displaying UHD broadcasts, which Sky will introduce later in 2016.
493	2077	BSkyB's standard definition broadcasts are in DVB-compliant MPEG-2, with the Sky Movies and Sky Box Office channels including optional Dolby Digital soundtracks for recent films, although these are only accessible with a Sky+ box.
493	2078	Sky+ HD material is broadcast using MPEG-4 and most of the HD material uses the DVB-S2 standard.
493	2079	Interactive services and 7-day EPG use the proprietary OpenTV system, with set-top boxes including modems for a return path.
493	2080	Sky News, amongst other channels, provides a pseudo-video on demand interactive service by broadcasting looping video streams.
494	2081	When Sky Digital was launched in 1998 the new service used the Astra 2A satellite which was located at the 28.5°E orbital position, unlike the analogue service which was broadcast from 19.2°E.
494	2082	This was subsequently followed by more Astra satellites as well as Eutelsat's Eurobird 1 (now Eutelsat 33C) at 28.5°E), enabled the company to launch a new all-digital service, Sky, with the potential to carry hundreds of television and radio channels.
494	2083	The old position was shared with broadcasters from several European countries, while the new position at 28.5°E came to be used almost exclusively for channels that broadcast to the United Kingdom.
495	2084	BSkyB launched its HDTV service, Sky+ HD, on 22 May 2006.
495	2085	Prior to its launch, BSkyB claimed that 40,000 people had registered to receive the HD service.
495	2086	In the week before the launch, rumours started to surface that BSkyB was having supply issues with its set top box (STB) from manufacturer Thomson.
495	2087	On Thursday 18 May 2006, and continuing through the weekend before launch, people were reporting that BSkyB had either cancelled or rescheduled its installation.
495	2088	Finally, the BBC reported that 17,000 customers had yet to receive the service due to failed deliveries.
495	2089	On 31 March 2012, Sky announced the total number of homes with Sky+HD was 4,222,000.
496	2090	On 8 February 2007, BSkyB announced its intention to replace its three free-to-air digital terrestrial channels with four subscription channels.
496	2091	It was proposed that these channels would offer a range of content from the BSkyB portfolio including sport (including English Premier League Football), films, entertainment and news.
496	2092	The announcement came a day after Setanta Sports confirmed that it would launch in March as a subscription service on the digital terrestrial platform, and on the same day that NTL's services re-branded as Virgin Media.
496	2093	However, industry sources believe BSkyB will be forced to shelve plans to withdraw its channels from Freeview and replace them with subscription channels, due to possible lost advertising revenue.
497	2094	Provided is a universal Ku band LNB (9.75/10.600 GHz) which is fitted at the end of the dish and pointed at the correct satellite constellation; most digital receivers will receive the free to air channels.
497	2095	Some broadcasts are free-to-air and unencrypted, some are encrypted but do not require a monthly subscription (known as free-to-view), some are encrypted and require a monthly subscription, and some are pay-per-view services.
497	2096	To view the encrypted content a VideoGuard UK equipped receiver (all of which are dedicated to the Sky service, and cannot be used to decrypt other services) needs to be used.
497	2097	Unofficial CAMs are now available to view the service, although use of them breaks the user's contract with Sky and invalidates the user's rights to use the card.
498	2098	In the autumn of 1991, talks were held for the broadcast rights for Premier League for a five-year period, from the 1992 season.
498	2099	ITV were the current rights holders, and fought hard to retain the new rights.
498	2100	ITV had increased its offer from £18m to £34m per year to keep control of the rights.
498	2101	BSkyB joined forces with the BBC to make a counter bid.

499	2107	BSkyB has no veto over the presence of channels on their EPG, with open access being an enforced part of their operating licence from Ofcom.
499	2108	Any channel which can get carriage on a suitable beam of a satellite at 28° East is entitled to access to BSkyB's EPG for a fee, ranging from £15–100,000.
499	2109	Third-party channels which opt for encryption receive discounts ranging from reduced price to free EPG entries, free carriage on a BSkyB leased transponder, or actual payment for being carried.
499	2110	However, even in this case, BSkyB does not carry any control over the channel's content or carriage issues such as picture quality.

505	2129	The economy of Victoria is highly diversified: service sectors including financial and property services, health, education, wholesale, retail, hospitality and manufacturing constitute the majority of employment.
505	2130	Victoria's total gross state product (GSP) is ranked second in Australia, although Victoria is ranked fourth in terms of GSP per capita because of its limited mining activity.
505	2131	Culturally, Melbourne is home to a number of museums, art galleries and theatres and is also described as the "sporting capital of Australia".
505	2132	The Melbourne Cricket Ground is the largest stadium in Australia, and the host of the 1956 Summer Olympics and the 2006 Commonwealth Games.
505	2133	The ground is also considered the "spiritual home" of Australian cricket and Australian rules football, and hosts the grand final of the Australian Football League (AFL) each year, usually drawing crowds of over 95,000 people.
505	2134	Victoria includes eight public universities, with the oldest, the University of Melbourne, having been founded in 1853.
506	2135	Immigrants arrived from all over the world to search for gold, especially from Ireland and China.
506	2136	Many Chinese miners worked in Victoria, and their legacy is particularly strong in Bendigo and its environs.
506	2137	Although there was some racism directed at them, there was not the level of anti-Chinese violence that was seen at the Lambing Flat riots in New South Wales.
506	2138	However, there was a riot at Buckland Valley near Bright in 1857.
506	2139	Conditions on the gold fields were cramped and unsanitary; an outbreak of typhoid at Buckland Valley in 1854 killed over 1,000 miners.
507	2140	In November 2006, the Victorian Legislative Council elections were held under a new multi-member proportional representation system.
507	2141	The State of Victoria was divided into eight electorates with each electorate represented by five representatives elected by Single Transferable Vote.
507	2142	The total number of upper house members was reduced from 44 to 40 and their term of office is now the same as the lower house members—four years.
507	2143	Elections for the Victorian Parliament are now fixed and occur in November every four years.
507	2144	Prior to the 2006 election, the Legislative Council consisted of 44 members elected to eight-year terms from 22 two-member electorates.
508	2145	The centre-left Australian Labor Party (ALP), the centre-right Liberal Party of Australia, the rural-based National Party of Australia, and the environmentalist Australian Greens are Victoria's main political parties.
508	2146	Traditionally, Labor is strongest in Melbourne's working class western and northern suburbs, and the regional cities of Ballarat, Bendigo and Geelong.
508	2147	The Liberals' main support lies in Melbourne's more affluent eastern and outer suburbs, and some rural and regional centres.
508	2148	The Nationals are strongest in Victoria's North Western and Eastern rural regional areas.
508	2149	The Greens, who won their first lower house seats in 2014, are strongest in inner Melbourne.
509	2150	About 61.1% of Victorians describe themselves as Christian.
509	2151	Roman Catholics form the single largest religious group in the state with 26.7% of the Victorian population, followed by Anglicans and members of the Uniting Church.
509	2152	Buddhism is the state's largest non-Christian religion, with 168,637 members as of the most recent census.
509	2153	Victoria is also home of 152,775 Muslims and 45,150 Jews.
509	2154	Hinduism is the fastest growing religion.
509	2155	Around 20% of Victorians claim no religion.
509	2156	Amongst those who declare a religious affiliation, church attendance is low.
510	2157	Victoria (abbreviated as Vic) is a state in the south-east of Australia.
510	2158	Victoria is Australia's most densely populated state and its second-most populous state overall.
510	2159	Most of its population is concentrated in the area surrounding Port Phillip Bay, which includes the metropolitan area of its capital and largest city, Melbourne, which is Australia's second-largest city.
510	2160	Geographically the smallest state on the Australian mainland, Victoria is bordered by Bass Strait and Tasmania to the south,[note 1] New South Wales to the north, the Tasman Sea to the east, and South Australia to the west.
511	2161	Prior to European settlement, the area now constituting Victoria was inhabited by a large number of Aboriginal peoples, collectively known as the Koori.
511	2162	With Great Britain having claimed the entire Australian continent east of the 135th meridian east in 1788, Victoria was included in the wider colony of New South Wales.
511	2163	The first settlement in the area occurred in 1803 at Sullivan Bay, and much of what is now Victoria was included in the Port Phillip District in 1836, an administrative division of New South Wales.
511	2164	Victoria was officially created a separate colony in 1851, and achieved self-government in 1855.
511	2165	The Victorian gold rush in the 1850s and 1860s significantly increased both the population and wealth of the colony, and by the Federation of Australia in 1901, Melbourne had become the largest city and leading financial centre in Australasia.
511	2166	Melbourne also served as capital of Australia until the construction of Canberra in 1927, with the Federal Parliament meeting in Melbourne's Parliament House and all principal offices of the federal government being based in Melbourne.
512	2167	More than 26,000 square kilometres (10,000 sq mi) of Victorian farmland are sown for grain, mostly in the state's west.
512	2168	More than 50% of this area is sown for wheat, 33% for barley and 7% for oats.
512	2169	A further 6,000 square kilometres (2,300 sq mi) is sown for hay.
512	2170	In 2003–04, Victorian farmers produced more than 3 million tonnes of wheat and 2 million tonnes of barley.
512	2171	Victorian farms produce nearly 90% of Australian pears and third of apples.
512	2172	It is also a leader in stone fruit production.
512	2173	The main vegetable crops include asparagus, broccoli, carrots, potatoes and tomatoes.
512	2174	Last year, 121,200 tonnes of pears and 270,000 tonnes of tomatoes were produced.
513	2175	Victoria has a written constitution enacted in 1975, but based on the 1855 colonial constitution, passed by the United Kingdom Parliament as the Victoria Constitution Act 1855, which establishes the Parliament as the state's law-making body for matters coming under state responsibility.
513	2176	The Victorian Constitution can be amended by the Parliament of Victoria, except for certain "entrenched" provisions that require either an absolute majority in both houses, a three-fifths majority in both houses, or the approval of the Victorian people in a referendum, depending on the provision.
514	2177	The Mallee and upper Wimmera are Victoria's warmest regions with hot winds blowing from nearby semi-deserts.
514	2178	Average temperatures exceed 32 °C (90 °F) during summer and 15 °C (59 °F) in winter.
514	2179	Except at cool mountain elevations, the inland monthly temperatures are 2–7 °C (4–13 °F) warmer than around Melbourne (see chart).
514	2180	Victoria's highest maximum temperature since World War II, of 48.8 °C (119.8 °F) was recorded in Hopetoun on 7 February 2009, during the 2009 southeastern Australia heat wave.
515	2181	Victorian schools are either publicly or privately funded.
515	2182	Public schools, also known as state or government schools, are funded and run directly by the Victoria Department of Education .
515	2183	Students do not pay tuition fees, but some extra costs are levied.
515	2184	Private fee-paying schools include parish schools run by the Roman Catholic Church and independent schools similar to British public schools.
515	2185	Independent schools are usually affiliated with Protestant churches.
515	2186	Victoria also has several private Jewish and Islamic primary and secondary schools.
515	2187	Private schools also receive some public funding.
515	2188	All schools must comply with government-set curriculum standards.
515	2189	In addition, Victoria has four government selective schools, Melbourne High School for boys, MacRobertson Girls' High School for girls, the coeducational schools John Monash Science School, Nossal High School and Suzanne Cory High School, and The Victorian College of the Arts Secondary School.
515	2190	Students at these schools are exclusively admitted on the basis of an academic selective entry test.
516	2191	Historically, Victoria has been the base for the manufacturing plants of the major car brands Ford, Toyota and Holden; however, closure announcements by all three companies in the 21st century will mean that Australia will no longer be a base for the global car industry, with Toyota's statement in February 2014 outlining a closure year of 2017.
516	2192	Holden's announcement occurred in May 2013, followed by Ford's decision in December of the same year (Ford's Victorian plants—in Broadmeadows and Geelong—will close in October 2016).
517	2193	Victoria contains many topographically, geologically and climatically diverse areas, ranging from the wet, temperate climate of Gippsland in the southeast to the snow-covered Victorian alpine areas which rise to almost 2,000 m (6,600 ft), with Mount Bogong the highest peak at 1,986 m (6,516 ft).
517	2194	There are extensive semi-arid plains to the west and northwest.
517	2195	There is an extensive series of river systems in Victoria.
517	2196	Most notable is the Murray River system.
517	2197	Other rivers include: Ovens River, Goulburn River, Patterson River, King River, Campaspe River, Loddon River, Wimmera River, Elgin River, Barwon River, Thomson River, Snowy River, Latrobe River, Yarra River, Maribyrnong River, Mitta River, Hopkins River, Merri River and Kiewa River.
517	2198	The state symbols include the pink heath (state flower), Leadbeater's possum (state animal) and the helmeted honeyeater (state bird).
518	2199	The Victorian Alps in the northeast are the coldest part of Victoria.
518	2200	The Alps are part of the Great Dividing Range mountain system extending east-west through the centre of Victoria.
518	2201	Average temperatures are less than 9 °C (48 °F) in winter and below 0 °C (32 °F) in the highest parts of the ranges.
518	2202	The state's lowest minimum temperature of −11.7 °C (10.9 °F) was recorded at Omeo on 13 June 1965, and again at Falls Creek on 3 July 1970.
518	2203	Temperature extremes for the state are listed in the table below:
519	2204	Rail transport in Victoria is provided by several private and public railway operators who operate over government-owned lines.
519	2205	Major operators include: Metro Trains Melbourne which runs an extensive, electrified, passenger system throughout Melbourne and suburbs; V/Line which is now owned by the Victorian Government, operates a concentrated service to major regional centres, as well as long distance services on other lines; Pacific National, CFCL Australia which operate freight services; Great Southern Rail which operates The Overland Melbourne—Adelaide; and NSW TrainLink which operates XPTs Melbourne—Sydney.
520	2206	Politically, Victoria has 37 seats in the Australian House of Representatives and 12 seats in the Australian Senate.
520	2207	At state level, the Parliament of Victoria consists of the Legislative Assembly (the lower house) and the Legislative Council (the upper house).
520	2208	Victoria is currently governed by the Labor Party, with Daniel Andrews the current Premier.
520	2209	The personal representative of the Queen of Australia in the state is the Governor of Victoria, currently Linda Dessau.
520	2210	Local government is concentrated in 79 municipal districts, including 33 cities, although a number of unincorporated areas still exist, which are administered directly by the state.
521	2211	On 1 July 1851, writs were issued for the election of the first Victorian Legislative Council, and the absolute independence of Victoria from New South Wales was established proclaiming a new Colony of Victoria.
521	2212	Days later, still in 1851 gold was discovered near Ballarat, and subsequently at Bendigo.
521	2213	Later discoveries occurred at many sites across Victoria.
521	2214	This triggered one of the largest gold rushes the world has ever seen.
521	2215	The colony grew rapidly in both population and economic power.
521	2216	In ten years the population of Victoria increased sevenfold from 76,000 to 540,000.
521	2217	All sorts of gold records were produced including the "richest shallow alluvial goldfield in the world" and the largest gold nugget.
521	2218	Victoria produced in the decade 1851–1860 20 million ounces of gold, one third of the world's output[citation needed].
522	2219	As of August 2010, Victoria had 1,548 public schools, 489 Catholic schools and 214 independent schools.
522	2220	Just under 540,800 students were enrolled in public schools, and just over 311,800 in private schools.
522	2221	Over 61 per cent of private students attend Catholic schools.
522	2222	More than 462,000 students were enrolled in primary schools and more than 390,000 in secondary schools.
522	2223	Retention rates for the final two years of secondary school were 77 per cent for public school students and 90 per cent for private school students.
522	2224	Victoria has about 63,519 full-time teachers.
523	2225	Victoria is the centre of dairy farming in Australia.
523	2226	It is home to 60% of Australia's 3 million dairy cattle and produces nearly two-thirds of the nation's milk, almost 6.4 billion litres.
523	2227	The state also has 2.4 million beef cattle, with more than 2.2 million cattle and calves slaughtered each year.
523	2228	In 2003–04, Victorian commercial fishing crews and aquaculture industry produced 11,634 tonnes of seafood valued at nearly A$109 million.
523	2229	Blacklipped abalone is the mainstay of the catch, bringing in A$46 million, followed by southern rock lobster worth A$13.7 million.
523	2230	Most abalone and rock lobster is exported to Asia.
524	2231	There are also several smaller freight operators and numerous tourist railways operating over lines which were once parts of a state-owned system.
524	2232	Victorian lines mainly use the 1,600 mm (5 ft 3 in) broad gauge.
524	2233	However, the interstate trunk routes, as well as a number of branch lines in the west of the state have been converted to 1,435 mm (4 ft 8 1⁄2 in) standard gauge.
524	2234	Two tourist railways operate over 760 mm (2 ft 6 in) narrow gauge lines, which are the remnants of five formerly government-owned lines which were built in mountainous areas.
525	2235	After the founding of the colony of New South Wales in 1788, Australia was divided into an eastern half named New South Wales and a western half named New Holland, under the administration of the colonial government in Sydney.
525	2236	The first European settlement in the area later known as Victoria was established in October 1803 under Lieutenant-Governor David Collins at Sullivan Bay on Port Phillip.
525	2237	It consisted of 402 people (5 Government officials, 9 officers of marines, 2 drummers, and 39 privates, 5 soldiers' wives, and a child, 307 convicts, 17 convicts' wives, and 7 children).
525	2238	They had been sent from England in HMS Calcutta under the command of Captain Daniel Woodriff, principally out of fear that the French, who had been exploring the area, might establish their own settlement and thereby challenge British rights to the continent.
526	2239	In 1854 at Ballarat there was an armed rebellion against the government of Victoria by miners protesting against mining taxes (the "Eureka Stockade").
526	2240	This was crushed by British troops, but the discontents prompted colonial authorities to reform the administration (particularly reducing the hated mining licence fees) and extend the franchise.
526	2241	Within a short time, the Imperial Parliament granted Victoria responsible government with the passage of the Colony of Victoria Act 1855.
526	2242	Some of the leaders of the Eureka rebellion went on to become members of the Victorian Parliament.
527	2243	The Premier of Victoria is the leader of the political party or coalition with the most seats in the Legislative Assembly.
527	2244	The Premier is the public face of government and, with cabinet, sets the legislative and political agenda.
527	2245	Cabinet consists of representatives elected to either house of parliament.
527	2246	It is responsible for managing areas of government that are not exclusively the Commonwealth's, by the Australian Constitution, such as education, health and law enforcement.
527	2247	The current Premier of Victoria is Daniel Andrews.
528	2248	During 2003–04, the gross value of Victorian agricultural production increased by 17% to $8.7 billion.
528	2249	This represented 24% of national agricultural production total gross value.
528	2250	As of 2004, an estimated 32,463 farms occupied around 136,000 square kilometres (52,500 sq mi) of Victorian land.
528	2251	This comprises more than 60% of the state's total land surface.
528	2252	Victorian farms range from small horticultural outfits to large-scale livestock and grain productions.
528	2253	A quarter of farmland is used to grow consumable crops.
529	2254	Major events also play a big part in tourism in Victoria, particularly cultural tourism and sports tourism.
529	2255	Most of these events are centred on Melbourne, but others occur in regional cities, such as the V8 Supercars and Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix at Phillip Island, the Grand Annual Steeplechase at Warrnambool and the Australian International Airshow at Geelong and numerous local festivals such as the popular Port Fairy Folk Festival, Queenscliff Music Festival, Bells Beach SurfClassic and the Bright Autumn Festival.
530	2256	Huguenot numbers peaked near an estimated two million by 1562, concentrated mainly in the southern and central parts of France, about one-eighth the number of French Catholics.
530	2257	As Huguenots gained influence and more openly displayed their faith, Catholic hostility grew, in spite of increasingly liberal political concessions and edicts of toleration from the French crown.
530	2258	A series of religious conflicts followed, known as the Wars of Religion, fought intermittently from 1562 to 1598.
530	2259	The wars finally ended with the granting of the Edict of Nantes, which granted the Huguenots substantial religious, political and military autonomy.
531	2260	A term used originally in derision, Huguenot has unclear origins.
531	2261	The nickname may have been a combined reference to the Swiss politician Besançon Hugues (died 1532) and the religiously conflicted nature of Swiss republicanism in his time, using a clever derogatory pun on the name Hugues by way of the Dutch word Huisgenoten (literally housemates), referring to the connotations of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse (Confederates as in "a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss Confederacy").
531	2262	Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement.
531	2263	In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party", so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation.
531	2264	The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France to those conspirators (all of them aristocratic members of the Reformed Church) involved in the Amboise plot of 1560: a foiled attempt to wrest power in France from the influential House of Guise.
531	2265	The move would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss.
531	2266	Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating the Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.
532	2267	The availability of the Bible in vernacular languages was important to the spread of the Protestant movement and development of the Reformed church in France.
532	2268	The country had a long history of struggles with the papacy by the time the Protestant Reformation finally arrived.
532	2269	Around 1294, a French version of the Scriptures was prepared by the Roman Catholic priest, Guyard de Moulin.
532	2270	A two-volume illustrated folio paraphrase version based on his manuscript, by Jean de Rély, was printed in Paris in 1487.
533	2271	Montpellier was among the most important of the 66 "villes de sûreté" that the Edict of 1598 granted to the Huguenots.
533	2272	The city's political institutions and the university were all handed over to the Huguenots.
533	2273	Tension with Paris led to a siege by the royal army in 1622.
533	2274	Peace terms called for the dismantling of the city's fortifications.
533	2275	A royal citadel was built and the university and consulate were taken over by the Catholic party.
533	2276	Even before the Edict of Alès (1629), Protestant rule was dead and the ville de sûreté was no more.
534	2277	Individual Huguenots settled at the Cape of Good Hope from as early as 1671 with the arrival of François Villion (Viljoen).
534	2278	The first Huguenot to arrive at the Cape of Good Hope was however Maria de la Queillerie, wife of commander Jan van Riebeeck (and daughter of a Walloon church minister), who arrived on 6 April 1652 to establish a settlement at what is today Cape Town.
534	2279	The couple left for the Far East ten years later.
534	2280	On 31 December 1687 the first organised group of Huguenots set sail from the Netherlands to the Dutch East India Company post at the Cape of Good Hope.
534	2281	The largest portion of the Huguenots to settle in the Cape arrived between 1688 and 1689 in seven ships as part of the organised migration, but quite a few arrived as late as 1700; thereafter, the numbers declined and only small groups arrived at a time.
535	2282	Barred by the government from settling in New France, Huguenots led by Jessé de Forest, sailed to North America in 1624 and settled instead in the Dutch colony of New Netherland (later incorporated into New York and New Jersey); as well as Great Britain's colonies, including Nova Scotia.
535	2283	A number of New Amsterdam's families were of Huguenot origin, often having emigrated as refugees to the Netherlands in the previous century.
535	2284	In 1628 the Huguenots established a congregation as L'Église française à la Nouvelle-Amsterdam (the French church in New Amsterdam).
535	2285	This parish continues today as L'Eglise du Saint-Esprit, part of the Episcopal (Anglican) communion, and welcomes Francophone New Yorkers from all over the world.
535	2286	Upon their arrival in New Amsterdam, Huguenots were offered land directly across from Manhattan on Long Island for a permanent settlement and chose the harbor at the end of Newtown Creek, becoming the first Europeans to live in Brooklyn, then known as Boschwick, in the neighborhood now known as Bushwick.
536	2287	In the early years, many Huguenots also settled in the area of present-day Charleston, South Carolina.
536	2288	Elie Prioleau from the town of Pons in France, was among the first to settle there.
536	2289	He became pastor of the first Huguenot church in North America in that city.
536	2290	After the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, several Huguenot families of Norman and Carolingian nobility and descent, including Edmund Bohun of Suffolk England from the Humphrey de Bohun line of French royalty descended from Charlemagne, Jean Postell of Dieppe France, Alexander Pepin, Antoine Poitevin of Orsement France, and Jacques de Bordeaux of Grenoble, immigrated to the Charleston Orange district.
536	2291	They were very successful at marriage and property speculation.
536	2292	After petitioning the British Crown in 1697 for the right to own land in the Baronies, they prospered as slave owners on the Cooper, Ashepoo, Ashley and Santee River plantations they purchased from the British Landgrave Edmund Bellinger.
536	2293	Some of their descendants moved into the Deep South and Texas, where they developed new plantations.
537	2294	Stadtholder William III of Orange, who later became King of England, emerged as the strongest opponent of king Louis XIV after the French attacked the Dutch Republic in 1672.
537	2295	William formed the League of Augsburg as a coalition to oppose Louis and the French state.
537	2296	Consequently, many Huguenots considered the wealthy and Calvinist Dutch Republic, which led the opposition to Louis XIV, as the most attractive country for exile after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes.
537	2297	They also found many French-speaking Calvinist churches there.
538	2298	Renewed religious warfare in the 1620s caused the political and military privileges of the Huguenots to be abolished following their defeat.
538	2299	They retained the religious provisions of the Edict of Nantes until the rule of Louis XIV, who progressively increased persecution of them until he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau (1685), which abolished all legal recognition of Protestantism in France, and forced the Huguenots to convert.
538	2300	While nearly three-quarters eventually were killed  or submitted, roughly 500,000 Huguenots had fled France by the early 18th century[citation needed].
539	2301	The Catholic Church in France and many of its members opposed the Huguenots.
539	2302	Some Huguenot preachers and congregants were attacked as they attempted to meet for worship.
539	2303	The height of this persecution was the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre when 5,000 to 30,000 were killed, although there were also underlying political reasons for this as well, as some of the Huguenots were nobles trying to establish separate centers of power in southern France.
539	2304	Retaliating against the French Catholics, the Huguenots had their own militia.
540	2305	By 1620 the Huguenots were on the defensive, and the government increasingly applied pressure.
540	2306	A series of three small civil wars known as the Huguenot rebellions broke out, mainly in southwestern France, between 1621 and 1629. revolted against royal authority.
540	2307	The uprising occurred a decade following the death of Henry IV, a Huguenot before converting to Catholicism, who had protected Protestants through the Edict of Nantes.
540	2308	His successor Louis XIII, under the regency of his Italian Catholic mother Marie de' Medici, became more intolerant of Protestantism.
540	2309	The Huguenots respond by establishing independent political and military structures, establishing diplomatic contacts with foreign powers, and openly revolting against central power.
540	2310	The rebellions were implacably suppressed by the French Crown.
541	2311	Approximately one million Protestants in modern France represent some 2% of its population.
541	2312	Most are concentrated in Alsace in northeast France and the Cévennes mountain region in the south, who still regard themselves as Huguenots to this day.
541	2313	[citation needed] A diaspora of French Australians still considers itself Huguenot, even after centuries of exile.
541	2314	Long integrated into Australian society, it is encouraged by the Huguenot Society of Australia to embrace and conserve its cultural heritage, aided by the Society's genealogical research services.
542	2315	Huguenot immigrants did not disperse or settle in different parts of the country, but rather, formed three societies or congregations; one in the city of New York, another 21 miles north of New York in a town which they named New Rochelle, and a third further upstate in New Paltz.
542	2316	The "Huguenot Street Historic District" in New Paltz has been designated a National Historic Landmark site and contains the oldest street in the United States of America.
542	2317	A small group of Huguenots also settled on the south shore of Staten Island along the New York Harbor, for which the current neighborhood of Huguenot was named.
543	2318	After the revocation of the Edict of Nantes, the Dutch Republic received the largest group of Huguenot refugees, an estimated total of 75,000 to 100,000 people.
543	2319	Many came from the region of the Cévennes, for instance, the village of Fraissinet-de-Lozère.
543	2320	This was a huge influx as the entire population of the Dutch Republic amounted to ca.
543	2321	Around 1700, it is estimated that nearly 25% of the Amsterdam population was Huguenot.
543	2322	[citation needed] In 1705, Amsterdam and the area of West Frisia were the first areas to provide full citizens rights to Huguenot immigrants, followed by the Dutch Republic in 1715.
543	2323	Huguenots intermarried with Dutch from the outset.
544	2324	In this last connection, the name could suggest the derogatory inference of superstitious worship; popular fancy held that Huguon, the gate of King Hugo, was haunted by the ghost of le roi Huguet (regarded by Roman Catholics as an infamous scoundrel) and other spirits, who instead of being in Purgatory came back to harm the living at night.
544	2325	It was in this place in Tours that the prétendus réformés ("these supposedly 'reformed'") habitually gathered at night, both for political purposes, and for prayer and singing psalms.
544	2326	Such explanations have been traced to the contemporary, Reguier de la Plancha (d. 1560), who in De l'Estat de France offered the following account as to the origin of the name, as cited by The Cape Monthly:
545	2327	Other evidence of the Walloons and Huguenots in Canterbury includes a block of houses in Turnagain Lane, where weavers' windows survive on the top floor, as many Huguenots worked as weavers.
545	2328	The Weavers, a half-timbered house by the river, was the site of a weaving school from the late 16th century to about 1830.
545	2329	(It has been adapted as a restaurant—see illustration above.
545	2330	The house derives its name from a weaving school which was moved there in the last years of the 19th century, reviving an earlier use.)
545	2331	Others refugees practised the variety of occupations necessary to sustain the community as distinct from the indigenous population.
545	2332	Such economic separation was the condition of the refugees' initial acceptance in the City.
545	2333	They also settled elsewhere in Kent, particularly Sandwich, Faversham and Maidstone—towns in which there used to be refugee churches.
546	2334	A number of Huguenots served as mayors in Dublin, Cork, Youghal and Waterford in the 17th and 18th centuries.
546	2335	Numerous signs of Huguenot presence can still be seen with names still in use, and with areas of the main towns and cities named after the people who settled there.
546	2336	Examples include the Huguenot District and French Church Street in Cork City; and D'Olier Street in Dublin, named after a High Sheriff and one of the founders of the Bank of Ireland.
546	2337	A French church in Portarlington dates back to 1696, and was built to serve the significant new Huguenot community in the town.
546	2338	At the time, they constituted the majority of the townspeople.
547	2339	The exodus of Huguenots from France created a brain drain, as many Huguenots had occupied important places in society.
547	2340	The kingdom did not fully recover for years.
547	2341	The French crown's refusal to allow non-Catholics to settle in New France may help to explain that colony's slow rate of population growth compared to that of the neighbouring British colonies, which opened settlement to religious dissenters.
547	2342	By the time of the French and Indian War (the North American front of the Seven Years' War), a sizeable population of Huguenot descent lived in the British colonies, and many participated in the British defeat of New France in 1759-60.
548	2343	The pattern of warfare, followed by brief periods of peace, continued for nearly another quarter-century.
548	2344	The warfare was definitively quelled in 1598, when Henry of Navarre, having succeeded to the French throne as Henry IV, and having recanted Protestantism in favour of Roman Catholicism, issued the Edict of Nantes.
548	2345	The Edict reaffirmed Catholicism as the state religion of France, but granted the Protestants equality with Catholics under the throne and a degree of religious and political freedom within their domains.
548	2346	The Edict simultaneously protected Catholic interests by discouraging the founding of new Protestant churches in Catholic-controlled regions.
549	2347	The revocation forbade Protestant services, required education of children as Catholics, and prohibited emigration.
549	2348	It proved disastrous to the Huguenots and costly for France.
549	2349	It precipitated civil bloodshed, ruined commerce, and resulted in the illegal flight from the country of hundreds of thousands of Protestants, many of whom became intellectuals, doctors and business leaders in Britain as well as Holland, Prussia, and South Africa.
549	2350	Four thousand emigrated to the North American colonies, where they settled in New York and Virginia, especially.
549	2351	The English welcomed the French refugees, providing money from both government and private agencies to aid their relocation.
549	2352	Those Huguenots who stayed in France became Catholics and were called "new converts".
550	2353	The first Huguenots to leave France sought freedom from persecution in Switzerland and the Netherlands.
550	2354	[citation needed] A group of Huguenots was part of the French colonisers who arrived in Brazil in 1555 to found France Antarctique.
550	2355	A couple of ships with around 500 people arrived at the Guanabara Bay, present-day Rio de Janeiro, and settled in a small island.
550	2356	A fort, named Fort Coligny, was built to protect them from attack from the Portuguese troops and Brazilian Native Americans.
550	2357	It was an attempt to establish a French colony in South America.
550	2358	The fort was destroyed in 1560 by the Portuguese, who captured part of the Huguenots.
550	2359	The Portuguese threatened the prisoners with death if they did not convert to Catholicism.
550	2360	The Huguenots of Guanabara, as they are now known, produced a declaration of faith to express their beliefs to the Portuguese.
550	2361	This document, the Guanabara Confession of Faith, became the first Protestant confession of faith in the whole of the Americas.
551	2362	Many of the farms in the Western Cape province in South Africa still bear French names.
551	2363	Many families, today mostly Afrikaans-speaking, have surnames indicating their French Huguenot ancestry.
551	2364	Examples include: Blignaut, Cilliers, de Klerk (Le Clercq), de Villiers, du Plessis, Du Preez (Des Pres), du Randt (Durand), du Toit, Duvenhage(Du Vinage), Franck, Fouche, Fourie (Fleurit), Gervais, Giliomee (Guilliaume), Gous/Gouws (Gauch), Hugo, Jordaan (Jourdan), Joubert, Kriek, Labuschagne (la Buscagne), le Roux, Lombard, Malan, Malherbe, Marais, Maree, Minnaar (Mesnard), Nel (Nell),Naude', Nortje (Nortier), Pienaar (Pinard), Retief (Retif), Rossouw (Rousseau), Taljaard (Taillard), TerBlanche, Theron, Viljoen (Villion) and Visagie (Visage).
551	2365	The wine industry in South Africa owes a significant debt to the Huguenots, some of whom had vineyards in France, or were brandy distillers, and used their skills in their new home.
552	2366	Paul Revere was descended from Huguenot refugees, as was Henry Laurens, who signed the Articles of Confederation for South Carolina; Jack Jouett, who made the ride from Cuckoo Tavern to warn Thomas Jefferson and others that Tarleton and his men were on their way to arrest him for crimes against the king; Francis Marion, and a number of other leaders of the American Revolution and later statesmen.
552	2367	The last active Huguenot congregation in North America worships in Charleston, South Carolina, at a church that dates to 1844.
552	2368	The Huguenot Society of America maintains Manakin Episcopal Church in Virginia as an historic shrine with occasional services.
552	2369	The Society has chapters in numerous states, with the one in Texas being the largest.
553	2370	Some Huguenots settled in Bedfordshire, one of the main centres of the British lace industry at the time.
553	2371	Although 19th century sources have asserted that some of these refugees were lacemakers and contributed to the East Midlands lace industry, this is contentious.
553	2372	The only reference to immigrant lacemakers in this period is of twenty-five widows who settled in Dover, and there is no contemporary documentation to support there being Huguenot lacemakers in Bedfordshire.
553	2373	The implication that the style of lace known as 'Bucks Point' demonstrates a Huguenot influence, being a "combination of Mechlin patterns on Lille ground", is fallacious: what is now known as Mechlin lace did not develop until first half of the eighteenth century and lace with Mechlin patterns and Lille ground did not appear until the end of the 18th century, when it was widely copied throughout Europe.
554	2374	In Berlin, the Huguenots created two new neighbourhoods: Dorotheenstadt and Friedrichstadt.
554	2375	By 1700, one-fifth of the city's population was French speaking.
554	2376	The Berlin Huguenots preserved the French language in their church services for nearly a century.
554	2377	They ultimately decided to switch to German in protest against the occupation of Prussia by Napoleon in 1806-07.
554	2378	Many of their descendents rose to positions of prominence.
554	2379	Several congregations were founded, such as those of Fredericia (Denmark), Berlin, Stockholm, Hamburg, Frankfurt, Helsinki, and Emden.
555	2380	After this, Huguenots (with estimates ranging from 200,000 to 1,000,000) fled to surrounding Protestant countries: England, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Norway, Denmark, and Prussia — whose Calvinist Great Elector Frederick William welcomed them to help rebuild his war-ravaged and underpopulated country.
555	2381	Following this exodus, Huguenots remained in large numbers in only one region of France: the rugged Cévennes region in the south.
555	2382	In the early 18th century, a regional group known as the Camisards who were Huguenots rioted against the Catholic Church in the region, burning churches and killing clergy.
555	2383	It took French troops years to hunt down and destroy all the bands of Camisards, between 1702 and 1709.
556	2384	In 1564 a group of Norman Huguenots under the leadership of Jean Ribault established the small colony of Fort Caroline on the banks of the St. Johns River in what is today Jacksonville, Florida.
556	2385	The effort was the first at any permanent European settlement in the present-day continental United States, but survived only a short time.
556	2386	A September 1565 French naval attack against the new Spanish colony at St. Augustine failed when its ships were hit by a hurricane on their way to the Spanish encampment at Fort Matanzas.
556	2387	Hundreds of French soldiers were stranded and surrendered to the numerically inferior Spanish forces led by Pedro Menendez.
556	2388	Menendez proceeded to massacre the defenseless Huguenots, after which he wiped out the Fort Caroline garrison.
557	2389	French Huguenots made two attempts to establish a haven in North America.
557	2390	In 1562, naval officer Jean Ribault led an expedition that explored Florida and the present-day Southeastern U.S., and founded the outpost of Charlesfort on Parris Island, South Carolina.
557	2391	The Wars of Religion precluded a return voyage, and the outpost was abandoned.
557	2392	In 1564, Ribault's former lieutenant René Goulaine de Laudonnière launched a second voyage to build a colony; he established Fort Caroline in what is now Jacksonville, Florida.
557	2393	War at home again precluded a resupply mission, and the colony struggled.
557	2394	In 1565 the Spanish decided to enforce their claim to La Florida, and sent Pedro Menéndez de Avilés, who established the settlement of St. Augustine near Fort Caroline.
557	2395	Menéndez' forces routed the French and executed most of the Protestant captives.
558	2396	In 1700 several hundred French Huguenots migrated from England to the colony of Virginia, where the English Crown had promised them land grants in Lower Norfolk County.
558	2397	When they arrived, colonial authorities offered them instead land 20 miles above the falls of the James River, at the abandoned Monacan village known as Manakin Town, now in Powhatan County.
558	2398	Some settlers landed in present-day Chesterfield County.
558	2399	On 12 May 1705, the Virginia General Assembly passed an act to naturalise the 148 Huguenots still resident at Manakintown.
558	2400	Of the original 390 settlers in the isolated settlement, many had died; others lived outside town on farms in the English style; and others moved to different areas.
558	2401	Gradually they intermarried with their English neighbors.
558	2402	Through the 18th and 19th centuries, descendants of the French migrated west into the Piedmont, and across the Appalachian Mountains into the West of what became Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, and other states.
558	2403	In the Manakintown area, the Huguenot Memorial Bridge across the James River and Huguenot Road were named in their honor, as were many local features, including several schools, including Huguenot High School.
559	2404	Some Huguenots fought in the Low Countries alongside the Dutch against Spain during the first years of the Dutch Revolt (1568–1609).
559	2405	The Dutch Republic rapidly became a destination for Huguenot exiles.
559	2406	Early ties were already visible in the "Apologie" of William the Silent, condemning the Spanish Inquisition, which was written by his court minister, the Huguenot Pierre L'Oyseleur, lord of Villiers.
559	2407	Louise de Coligny, daughter of the murdered Huguenot leader Gaspard de Coligny, married William the Silent, leader of the Dutch (Calvinist) revolt against Spanish (Catholic) rule.
559	2408	As both spoke French in daily life, their court church in the Prinsenhof in Delft held services in French.
559	2409	The practice has continued to the present day.
559	2410	The Prinsenhof is one of the 14 active Walloon churches of the Dutch Reformed Church.
559	2411	The ties between Huguenots and the Dutch Republic's military and political leadership, the House of Orange-Nassau, which existed since the early days of the Dutch Revolt, helped support the many early settlements of Huguenots in the Dutch Republic's colonies.
559	2412	They settled at the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa and New Netherland in North America.
560	2413	Both before and after the 1708 passage of the Foreign Protestants Naturalization Act, an estimated 50,000 Protestant Walloons and Huguenots fled to England, with many moving on to Ireland and elsewhere.
560	2414	In relative terms, this was one of the largest waves of immigration ever of a single ethnic community to Britain.
560	2415	Andrew Lortie (born André Lortie), a leading Huguenot theologian and writer who led the exiled community in London, became known for articulating their criticism of the Pope and the doctrine of transubstantiation during Mass.
561	2416	Following the French Crown's revocation of the Edict of Nantes, many Huguenots settled in Ireland in the late 17th and early 18th centuries, encouraged by an act of parliament for Protestants' settling in Ireland.
561	2417	Huguenot regiments fought for William of Orange in the Williamite war in Ireland, for which they were rewarded with land grants and titles, many settling in Dublin.
561	2418	Significant Huguenot settlements were in Dublin, Cork, Portarlington, Lisburn, Waterford and Youghal.
561	2419	Smaller settlements, which included Killeshandra in County Cavan, contributed to the expansion of flax cultivation and the growth of the Irish linen industry.
562	2420	Prince Louis de Condé, along with his sons Daniel and Osias,[citation needed] arranged with Count Ludwig von Nassau-Saarbrücken to establish a Huguenot community in present-day Saarland in 1604.
562	2421	The Count supported mercantilism and welcomed technically skilled immigrants into his lands, regardless of their religion.
562	2422	The Condés established a thriving glass-making works, which provided wealth to the principality for many years.
562	2423	Other founding families created enterprises based on textiles and such traditional Huguenot occupations in France.
562	2424	The community and its congregation remain active to this day, with descendants of many of the founding families still living in the region.
562	2425	Some members of this community emigrated to the United States in the 1890s.
563	2426	The bulk of Huguenot émigrés relocated to Protestant European nations such as England, Wales, Scotland, Denmark, Sweden, Switzerland, the Dutch Republic, the Electorate of Brandenburg and Electorate of the Palatinate in the Holy Roman Empire, the Duchy of Prussia, the Channel Islands, and Ireland.
563	2427	They also spread beyond Europe to the Dutch Cape Colony in South Africa, the Dutch East Indies, the Caribbean, and several of the English colonies of North America, and Quebec, where they were accepted and allowed to worship freely.
564	2428	Some disagree with such double or triple non-French linguistic origins, arguing that for the word to have spread into common use in France, it must have originated in the French language.
564	2429	The "Hugues hypothesis" argues that the name was derived by association with Hugues Capet, king of France, who reigned long before the Reformation.
564	2430	He was regarded by the Gallicans and Protestants as a noble man who respected people's dignity and lives.
564	2431	Janet Gray and other supporters of the hypothesis suggest that the name huguenote would be roughly equivalent to little Hugos, or those who want Hugo.
565	2432	Other predecessors of the Reformed church included the pro-reform and Gallican Roman Catholics, such as Jacques Lefevre (c. 1455–1536).
565	2433	The Gallicans briefly achieved independence for the French church, on the principle that the religion of France could not be controlled by the Bishop of Rome, a foreign power.
565	2434	During the Protestant Reformation, Lefevre, a professor at the University of Paris, published his French translation of the New Testament in 1523, followed by the whole Bible in the French language in 1530.
565	2435	William Farel was a student of Lefevre who went on to become a leader of the Swiss Reformation, establishing a Protestant government in Geneva.
565	2436	Jean Cauvin (John Calvin), another student at the University of Paris, also converted to Protestantism.
565	2437	Long after the sect was suppressed by Francis I, the remaining French Waldensians, then mostly in the Luberon region, sought to join William Farel, Calvin and the Reformation, and Olivetan published a French Bible for them.
565	2438	The French Confession of 1559 shows a decidedly Calvinistic influence.
565	2439	Sometime between 1550 and 1580, members of the Reformed church in France came to be commonly known as Huguenots.
566	2440	In what became known as the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre of 24 August – 3 October 1572, Catholics killed thousands of Huguenots in Paris.
566	2441	Similar massacres took place in other towns in the weeks following.
566	2442	The main provincial towns and cities experiencing the Massacre were Aix, Bordeaux, Bourges, Lyons, Meaux, Orleans, Rouen, Toulouse, and Troyes.
566	2443	Nearly 3,000 Protestants were slaughtered in Toulouse alone.
566	2444	The exact number of fatalities throughout the country is not known.
566	2445	On 23–24 August, between about 2,000 and 3,000 Protestants were killed in Paris and between 3,000 and 7,000 more in the French provinces.
566	2446	By 17 September, almost 25,000 Protestants had been massacred in Paris alone.
566	2447	Beyond Paris, the killings continued until 3 October.
566	2448	An amnesty granted in 1573 pardoned the perpetrators.
567	2449	Louis XIV gained the throne in 1643 and acted increasingly aggressively to force the Huguenots to convert.
567	2450	At first he sent missionaries, backed by a fund to financially reward converts to Catholicism.
567	2451	Then he imposed penalties, closed Huguenot schools and excluded them from favored professions.
567	2452	Escalating, he instituted dragonnades, which included the occupation and looting of Huguenot homes by military troops, in an effort to forcibly convert them.
567	2453	In 1685, he issued the Edict of Fontainebleau, revoking the Edict of Nantes and declaring Protestantism illegal.
568	2454	New Rochelle, located in the county of Westchester on the north shore of Long Island Sound, seemed to be the great location of the Huguenots in New York.
568	2455	It is said that they landed on the coastline peninsula of Davenports Neck called "Bauffet's Point" after traveling from England where they had previously taken refuge on account of religious persecution, four years before the revocation of the Edict of Nantes.
568	2456	They purchased from John Pell, Lord of Pelham Manor, a tract of land consisting of six thousand one hundred acres with the help of Jacob Leisler.
568	2457	It was named New Rochelle after La Rochelle, their former strong-hold in France.
568	2458	A small wooden church was first erected in the community, followed by a second church that built of stone.
568	2459	Previous to the erection of it, the strong men would often walk twenty-three miles on Saturday evening, the distance by the road from New Rochelle to New York, to attend the Sunday service.
568	2460	The church was eventually replaced by a third, Trinity-St. Paul's Episcopal Church, which contains heirlooms including the original bell from the French Huguenot Church "Eglise du St. Esperit" on Pine Street in New York City, which is preserved as a relic in the tower room.
568	2461	The Huguenot cemetery, or "Huguenot Burial Ground", has since been recognized as a historic cemetery that is the final resting place for a wide range of the Huguenot founders, early settlers and prominent citizens dating back more than three centuries.
569	2462	Most of the Huguenot congregations (or individuals) in North America eventually affiliated with other Protestant denominations with more numerous members.
569	2463	The Huguenots adapted quickly and often married outside their immediate French communities, which led to their assimilation.
569	2464	Their descendants in many families continued to use French first names and surnames for their children well into the nineteenth century.
569	2465	Assimilated, the French made numerous contributions to United States economic life, especially as merchants and artisans in the late Colonial and early Federal periods.
569	2466	du Pont, a former student of Lavoisier, established the Eleutherian gunpowder mills.
570	2467	One of the most prominent Huguenot refugees in the Netherlands was Pierre Bayle.
570	2468	He started teaching in Rotterdam, where he finished writing and publishing his multi-volume masterpiece, Historical and Critical Dictionary.
570	2469	It became one of the 100 foundational texts of the US Library of Congress.
570	2470	Some Huguenot descendants in the Netherlands may be noted by French family names, although they typically use Dutch given names.
570	2471	Due to the Huguenots' early ties with the leadership of the Dutch Revolt and their own participation, some of the Dutch patriciate are of part-Huguenot descent.
570	2472	Some Huguenot families have kept alive various traditions, such as the celebration and feast of their patron Saint Nicolas, similar to the Dutch Sint Nicolaas (Sinterklaas) feast.
571	2473	The French Protestant Church of London was established by Royal Charter in 1550.
571	2474	It is now located at Soho Square.
571	2475	Huguenot refugees flocked to Shoreditch, London.
571	2476	They established a major weaving industry in and around Spitalfields (see Petticoat Lane and the Tenterground) in East London.
571	2477	In Wandsworth, their gardening skills benefited the Battersea market gardens.
571	2478	The Old Truman Brewery, then known as the Black Eagle Brewery, was founded in 1724.
571	2479	The flight of Huguenot refugees from Tours, France drew off most of the workers of its great silk mills which they had built.
571	2480	[citation needed] Some of these immigrants moved to Norwich, which had accommodated an earlier settlement of Walloon weavers.
571	2481	The French added to the existing immigrant population, then comprising about a third of the population of the city.
572	2482	Around 1685, Huguenot refugees found a safe haven in the Lutheran and Reformed states in Germany and Scandinavia.
572	2483	Nearly 50,000 Huguenots established themselves in Germany, 20,000 of whom were welcomed in Brandenburg-Prussia, where they were granted special privileges (Edict of Potsdam) and churches in which to worship (such as the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, Angermünde) by Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg and Duke of Prussia.
572	2484	The Huguenots furnished two new regiments of his army: the Altpreußische Infantry Regiments No.
572	2485	13 (Regiment on foot Varenne) and 15 (Regiment on foot Wylich).
572	2486	Another 4,000 Huguenots settled in the German territories of Baden, Franconia (Principality of Bayreuth, Principality of Ansbach), Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel, Duchy of Württemberg, in the Wetterau Association of Imperial Counts, in the Palatinate and Palatinate-Zweibrücken, in the Rhine-Main-Area (Frankfurt), in modern-day Saarland; and 1,500 found refuge in Hamburg, Bremen and Lower Saxony.
572	2487	Three hundred refugees were granted asylum at the court of George William, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg in Celle.
573	2488	Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg, invited Huguenots to settle in his realms, and a number of their descendants rose to positions of prominence in Prussia.
573	2489	Several prominent German military, cultural, and political figures were ethnic Huguenot, including poet Theodor Fontane, General Hermann von François, the hero of the First World War Battle of Tannenberg, Luftwaffe General and fighter ace Adolf Galland, Luftwaffe flying ace Hans-Joachim Marseille, and famed U-boat captain Lothar von Arnauld de la Perière.
573	2490	The last Prime Minister of the (East) German Democratic Republic, Lothar de Maizière, is also a descendant of a Huguenot family, as is the German Federal Minister of the Interior, Thomas de Maizière.
574	2491	Steam engines are external combustion engines, where the working fluid is separate from the combustion products.
574	2492	Non-combustion heat sources such as solar power, nuclear power or geothermal energy may be used.
574	2493	The ideal thermodynamic cycle used to analyze this process is called the Rankine cycle.
574	2494	In the cycle, water is heated and transforms into steam within a boiler operating at a high pressure.
574	2495	When expanded through pistons or turbines, mechanical work is done.
574	2496	The reduced-pressure steam is then condensed and pumped back into the boiler.
575	2497	The first commercially successful true engine, in that it could generate power and transmit it to a machine, was the atmospheric engine, invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712.
575	2498	It was an improvement over Savery's steam pump, using a piston as proposed by Papin.
575	2499	Newcomen's engine was relatively inefficient, and in most cases was used for pumping water.
575	2500	It worked by creating a partial vacuum by condensing steam under a piston within a cylinder.
575	2501	It was employed for draining mine workings at depths hitherto impossible, and also for providing a reusable water supply for driving waterwheels at factories sited away from a suitable "head".
575	2502	Water that had passed over the wheel was pumped back up into a storage reservoir above the wheel.
576	2503	The first full-scale working railway steam locomotive was built by Richard Trevithick in the United Kingdom and, on 21 February 1804, the world's first railway journey took place as Trevithick's unnamed steam locomotive hauled a train along the tramway from the Pen-y-darren ironworks, near Merthyr Tydfil to Abercynon in south Wales.
576	2504	The design incorporated a number of important innovations that included using high-pressure steam which reduced the weight of the engine and increased its efficiency.
576	2505	Trevithick visited the Newcastle area later in 1804 and the colliery railways in north-east England became the leading centre for experimentation and development of steam locomotives.
577	2506	The Rankine cycle and most practical steam engines have a water pump to recycle or top up the boiler water, so that they may be run continuously.
577	2507	Utility and industrial boilers commonly use multi-stage centrifugal pumps; however, other types are used.
577	2508	Another means of supplying lower-pressure boiler feed water is an injector, which uses a steam jet usually supplied from the boiler.
577	2509	Injectors became popular in the 1850s but are no longer widely used, except in applications such as steam locomotives.
578	2510	It is a logical extension of the compound engine (described above) to split the expansion into yet more stages to increase efficiency.
578	2511	The result is the multiple expansion engine.
578	2512	Such engines use either three or four expansion stages and are known as triple and quadruple expansion engines respectively.
578	2513	These engines use a series of cylinders of progressively increasing diameter.
578	2514	These cylinders are designed to divide the work into equal shares for each expansion stage.
578	2515	As with the double expansion engine, if space is at a premium, then two smaller cylinders may be used for the low-pressure stage.
578	2516	Multiple expansion engines typically had the cylinders arranged inline, but various other formations were used.
578	2517	In the late 19th century, the Yarrow-Schlick-Tweedy balancing 'system' was used on some marine triple expansion engines.
578	2518	Y-S-T engines divided the low-pressure expansion stages between two cylinders, one at each end of the engine.
578	2519	This allowed the crankshaft to be better balanced, resulting in a smoother, faster-responding engine which ran with less vibration.
578	2520	This made the 4-cylinder triple-expansion engine popular with large passenger liners (such as the Olympic class), but this was ultimately replaced by the virtually vibration-free turbine engine.
579	2521	In the 1840s and 50s, there were attempts to overcome this problem by means of various patent valve gears with a separate, variable cutoff expansion valve riding on the back of the main slide valve; the latter usually had fixed or limited cutoff.
579	2522	The combined setup gave a fair approximation of the ideal events, at the expense of increased friction and wear, and the mechanism tended to be complicated.
579	2523	The usual compromise solution has been to provide lap by lengthening rubbing surfaces of the valve in such a way as to overlap the port on the admission side, with the effect that the exhaust side remains open for a longer period after cut-off on the admission side has occurred.
579	2524	This expedient has since been generally considered satisfactory for most purposes and makes possible the use of the simpler Stephenson, Joy and Walschaerts motions.
579	2525	Corliss, and later, poppet valve gears had separate admission and exhaust valves driven by trip mechanisms or cams profiled so as to give ideal events; most of these gears never succeeded outside of the stationary marketplace due to various other issues including leakage and more delicate mechanisms.
580	2526	Lead fusible plugs may be present in the crown of the boiler's firebox.
580	2527	If the water level drops, such that the temperature of the firebox crown increases significantly, the lead melts and the steam escapes, warning the operators, who may then manually suppress the fire.
580	2528	Except in the smallest of boilers the steam escape has little effect on dampening the fire.
580	2529	The plugs are also too small in area to lower steam pressure significantly, depressurizing the boiler.
580	2530	If they were any larger, the volume of escaping steam would itself endanger the crew.
581	2531	In 1781 James Watt patented a steam engine that produced continuous rotary motion.
581	2532	Watt's ten-horsepower engines enabled a wide range of manufacturing machinery to be powered.
581	2533	The engines could be sited anywhere that water and coal or wood fuel could be obtained.
581	2534	By 1883, engines that could provide 10,000 hp had become feasible.
581	2535	The stationary steam engine was a key component of the Industrial Revolution, allowing factories to locate where water power was unavailable.
581	2536	The atmospheric engines of Newcomen and Watt were large compared to the amount of power they produced, but high pressure steam engines were light enough to be applied to vehicles such as traction engines and the railway locomotives.
582	2537	The history of the steam engine stretches back as far as the first century AD; the first recorded rudimentary steam engine being the aeolipile described by Greek mathematician Hero of Alexandria.
582	2538	In the following centuries, the few steam-powered "engines" known were, like the aeolipile, essentially experimental devices used by inventors to demonstrate the properties of steam.
582	2539	A rudimentary steam turbine device was described by Taqi al-Din in 1551 and by Giovanni Branca in 1629.
582	2540	Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont received patents in 1606 for fifty steam powered inventions, including a water pump for draining inundated mines.
582	2541	Denis Papin, a Huguenot refugee, did some useful work on the steam digester in 1679, and first used a piston to raise weights in 1690.
583	2542	Near the end of the 19th century compound engines came into widespread use.
583	2543	Compound engines exhausted steam in to successively larger cylinders to accommodate the higher volumes at reduced pressures, giving improved efficiency.
583	2544	These stages were called expansions, with double and triple expansion engines being common, especially in shipping where efficiency was important to reduce the weight of coal carried.
583	2545	Steam engines remained the dominant source of power until the early 20th century, when advances in the design of electric motors and internal combustion engines gradually resulted in the replacement of reciprocating (piston) steam engines, with shipping in the 20th-century relying upon the steam turbine.
584	2546	The final major evolution of the steam engine design was the use of steam turbines starting in the late part of the 19th century.
584	2547	Steam turbines are generally more efficient than reciprocating piston type steam engines (for outputs above several hundred horsepower), have fewer moving parts, and provide rotary power directly instead of through a connecting rod system or similar means.
584	2548	Steam turbines virtually replaced reciprocating engines in electricity generating stations early in the 20th century, where their efficiency, higher speed appropriate to generator service, and smooth rotation were advantages.
584	2549	Today most electric power is provided by steam turbines.
584	2550	In the United States 90% of the electric power is produced in this way using a variety of heat sources.
584	2551	Steam turbines were extensively applied for propulsion of large ships throughout most of the 20th century.
585	2552	The heat required for boiling the water and supplying the steam can be derived from various sources, most commonly from burning combustible materials with an appropriate supply of air in a closed space (called variously combustion chamber, firebox).
585	2553	In some cases the heat source is a nuclear reactor, geothermal energy, solar energy or waste heat from an internal combustion engine or industrial process.
585	2554	In the case of model or toy steam engines, the heat source can be an electric heating element.
586	2555	The most useful instrument for analyzing the performance of steam engines is the steam engine indicator.
586	2556	Early versions were in use by 1851, but the most successful indicator was developed for the high speed engine inventor and manufacturer Charles Porter by Charles Richard and exhibited at London Exhibition in 1862.
586	2557	The steam engine indicator traces on paper the pressure in the cylinder throughout the cycle, which can be used to spot various problems and calculate developed horsepower.
586	2558	It was routinely used by engineers, mechanics and insurance inspectors.
586	2559	The engine indicator can also be used on internal combustion engines.
586	2560	See image of indicator diagram below (in Types of motor units section).
587	2561	With two-cylinder compounds used in railway work, the pistons are connected to the cranks as with a two-cylinder simple at 90° out of phase with each other (quartered).
587	2562	When the double expansion group is duplicated, producing a 4-cylinder compound, the individual pistons within the group are usually balanced at 180°, the groups being set at 90° to each other.
587	2563	In one case (the first type of Vauclain compound), the pistons worked in the same phase driving a common crosshead and crank, again set at 90° as for a two-cylinder engine.
587	2564	With the 3-cylinder compound arrangement, the LP cranks were either set at 90° with the HP one at 135° to the other two, or in some cases all three cranks were set at 120°.
588	2565	In most reciprocating piston engines, the steam reverses its direction of flow at each stroke (counterflow), entering and exhausting from the cylinder by the same port.
588	2566	The complete engine cycle occupies one rotation of the crank and two piston strokes; the cycle also comprises four events – admission, expansion, exhaust, compression.
588	2567	These events are controlled by valves often working inside a steam chest adjacent to the cylinder; the valves distribute the steam by opening and closing steam ports communicating with the cylinder end(s) and are driven by valve gear, of which there are many types.
589	2568	Uniflow engines attempt to remedy the difficulties arising from the usual counterflow cycle where, during each stroke, the port and the cylinder walls will be cooled by the passing exhaust steam, whilst the hotter incoming admission steam will waste some of its energy in restoring working temperature.
589	2569	The aim of the uniflow is to remedy this defect and improve efficiency by providing an additional port uncovered by the piston at the end of each stroke making the steam flow only in one direction.
589	2570	By this means, the simple-expansion uniflow engine gives efficiency equivalent to that of classic compound systems with the added advantage of superior part-load performance, and comparable efficiency to turbines for smaller engines below one thousand horsepower.
589	2571	However, the thermal expansion gradient uniflow engines produce along the cylinder wall gives practical difficulties.
589	2572	The Quasiturbine is a uniflow rotary steam engine where steam intakes in hot areas, while exhausting in cold areas.
590	2573	An oscillating cylinder steam engine is a variant of the simple expansion steam engine which does not require valves to direct steam into and out of the cylinder.
590	2574	Instead of valves, the entire cylinder rocks, or oscillates, such that one or more holes in the cylinder line up with holes in a fixed port face or in the pivot mounting (trunnion).
590	2575	These engines are mainly used in toys and models, because of their simplicity, but have also been used in full size working engines, mainly on ships where their compactness is valued.
591	2576	The working fluid in a Rankine cycle can operate as a closed loop system, where the working fluid is recycled continuously, or may be an "open loop" system, where the exhaust steam is directly released to the atmosphere, and a separate source of water feeding the boiler is supplied.
591	2577	Normally water is the fluid of choice due to its favourable properties, such as non-toxic and unreactive chemistry, abundance, low cost, and its thermodynamic properties.
591	2578	Mercury is the working fluid in the mercury vapor turbine.
591	2579	Low boiling hydrocarbons can be used in a binary cycle.
592	2580	The efficiency of a Rankine cycle is usually limited by the working fluid.
592	2581	Without the pressure reaching supercritical levels for the working fluid, the temperature range the cycle can operate over is quite small; in steam turbines, turbine entry temperatures are typically 565 °C (the creep limit of stainless steel) and condenser temperatures are around 30 °C.
592	2582	This gives a theoretical Carnot efficiency of about 63% compared with an actual efficiency of 42% for a modern coal-fired power station.
592	2583	This low turbine entry temperature (compared with a gas turbine) is why the Rankine cycle is often used as a bottoming cycle in combined-cycle gas turbine power stations.
593	2584	Steam engines can be said to have been the moving force behind the Industrial Revolution and saw widespread commercial use driving machinery in factories, mills and mines; powering pumping stations; and propelling transport appliances such as railway locomotives, ships, steamboats and road vehicles.
593	2585	Their use in agriculture led to an increase in the land available for cultivation.
593	2586	There have at one time or another been steam-powered farm tractors, motorcycles (without much success) and even automobiles as the Stanley Steamer.
594	2587	Trevithick continued his own experiments using a trio of locomotives, concluding with the Catch Me Who Can in 1808.
594	2588	Only four years later, the successful twin-cylinder locomotive Salamanca by Matthew Murray was used by the edge railed rack and pinion Middleton Railway.
594	2589	In 1825 George Stephenson built the Locomotion for the Stockton and Darlington Railway.
594	2590	This was the first public steam railway in the world and then in 1829, he built The Rocket which was entered in and won the Rainhill Trials.
594	2591	The Liverpool and Manchester Railway opened in 1830 making exclusive use of steam power for both passenger and freight trains.
595	2592	A method to lessen the magnitude of this heating and cooling was invented in 1804 by British engineer Arthur Woolf, who patented his Woolf high-pressure compound engine in 1805.
595	2593	In the compound engine, high-pressure steam from the boiler expands in a high-pressure (HP) cylinder and then enters one or more subsequent lower-pressure (LP) cylinders.
595	2594	The complete expansion of the steam now occurs across multiple cylinders and as less expansion now occurs in each cylinder less heat is lost by the steam in each.
595	2595	This reduces the magnitude of cylinder heating and cooling, increasing the efficiency of the engine.
595	2596	By staging the expansion in multiple cylinders, torque variability can be reduced.
595	2597	To derive equal work from lower-pressure steam requires a larger cylinder volume as this steam occupies a greater volume.
595	2598	Therefore, the bore, and often the stroke, are increased in low-pressure cylinders resulting in larger cylinders.
596	2599	The main use for steam turbines is in electricity generation (in the 1990s about 90% of the world's electric production was by use of steam turbines) however the recent widespread application of large gas turbine units and typical combined cycle power plants has resulted in reduction of this percentage to the 80% regime for steam turbines.
596	2600	In electricity production, the high speed of turbine rotation matches well with the speed of modern electric generators, which are typically direct connected to their driving turbines.
596	2601	In marine service, (pioneered on the Turbinia), steam turbines with reduction gearing (although the Turbinia has direct turbines to propellers with no reduction gearbox) dominated large ship propulsion throughout the late 20th century, being more efficient (and requiring far less maintenance) than reciprocating steam engines.
596	2602	In recent decades, reciprocating Diesel engines, and gas turbines, have almost entirely supplanted steam propulsion for marine applications.
597	2603	The Rankine cycle is the fundamental thermodynamic underpinning of the steam engine.
597	2604	The cycle is an arrangement of components as is typically used for simple power production, and utilizes the phase change of water (boiling water producing steam, condensing exhaust steam, producing liquid water)) to provide a practical heat/power conversion system.
597	2605	The heat is supplied externally to a closed loop with some of the heat added being converted to work and the waste heat being removed in a condenser.
597	2606	The Rankine cycle is used in virtually all steam power production applications.
597	2607	In the 1990s, Rankine steam cycles generated about 90% of all electric power used throughout the world, including virtually all solar, biomass, coal and nuclear power plants.
597	2608	It is named after William John Macquorn Rankine, a Scottish polymath.
598	2609	The historical measure of a steam engine's energy efficiency was its "duty".
598	2610	The concept of duty was first introduced by Watt in order to illustrate how much more efficient his engines were over the earlier Newcomen designs.
598	2611	Duty is the number of foot-pounds of work delivered by burning one bushel (94 pounds) of coal.
598	2612	The best examples of Newcomen designs had a duty of about 7 million, but most were closer to 5 million.
598	2613	Watt's original low-pressure designs were able to deliver duty as high as 25 million, but averaged about 17.
598	2614	This was a three-fold improvement over the average Newcomen design.
