598	2615	Early Watt engines equipped with high-pressure steam improved this to 65 million.
599	2616	Reciprocating piston type steam engines remained the dominant source of power until the early 20th century, when advances in the design of electric motors and internal combustion engines gradually resulted in the replacement of reciprocating (piston) steam engines in commercial usage, and the ascendancy of steam turbines in power generation.
599	2617	Considering that the great majority of worldwide electric generation is produced by turbine type steam engines, the "steam age" is continuing with energy levels far beyond those of the turn of the 19th century.
600	2618	The first commercial steam-powered device was a water pump, developed in 1698 by Thomas Savery.
600	2619	It used condensing steam to create a vacuum which was used to raise water from below, then it used steam pressure to raise it higher.
600	2620	Small engines were effective though larger models were problematic.
600	2621	They proved only to have a limited lift height and were prone to boiler explosions.
600	2622	It received some use in mines, pumping stations and for supplying water wheels used to power textile machinery.
600	2623	An attractive feature of the Savery engine was its low cost.
600	2624	Bento de Moura Portugal introduced an ingenious improvement of Savery's construction "to render it capable of working itself", as described by John Smeaton in the Philosophical Transactions published in 1751.
600	2625	It continued to be manufactured until the late 18th century.
600	2626	One engine was still known to be operating in 1820.
601	2627	Around 1800 Richard Trevithick and, separately, Oliver Evans in 1801 introduced engines using high-pressure steam; Trevithick obtained his high-pressure engine patent in 1802.
601	2628	These were much more powerful for a given cylinder size than previous engines and could be made small enough for transport applications.
601	2629	Thereafter, technological developments and improvements in manufacturing techniques (partly brought about by the adoption of the steam engine as a power source) resulted in the design of more efficient engines that could be smaller, faster, or more powerful, depending on the intended application.
602	2630	Although the reciprocating steam engine is no longer in widespread commercial use, various companies are exploring or exploiting the potential of the engine as an alternative to internal combustion engines.
602	2631	The company Energiprojekt AB in Sweden has made progress in using modern materials for harnessing the power of steam.
602	2632	The efficiency of Energiprojekt's steam engine reaches some 27-30% on high-pressure engines.
602	2633	It is a single-step, 5-cylinder engine (no compound) with superheated steam and consumes approx.
602	2634	4 kg (8.8 lb) of steam per kWh.
603	2635	Where CHP is not used, steam turbines in power stations use surface condensers as a cold sink.
603	2636	The condensers are cooled by water flow from oceans, rivers, lakes, and often by cooling towers which evaporate water to provide cooling energy removal.
603	2637	The resulting condensed hot water output from the condenser is then put back into the boiler via a pump.
603	2638	A dry type cooling tower is similar to an automobile radiator and is used in locations where water is costly.
603	2639	Evaporative (wet) cooling towers use the rejected heat to evaporate water; this water is kept separate from the condensate, which circulates in a closed system and returns to the boiler.
603	2640	Such towers often have visible plumes due to the evaporated water condensing into droplets carried up by the warm air.
603	2641	Evaporative cooling towers need less water flow than "once-through" cooling by river or lake water; a 700 megawatt coal-fired power plant may use about 3600 cubic metres of make-up water every hour for evaporative cooling, but would need about twenty times as much if cooled by river water.
604	2642	The centrifugal governor was adopted by James Watt for use on a steam engine in 1788 after Watt’s partner Boulton saw one at a flour mill Boulton & Watt were building.
604	2643	The governor could not actually hold a set speed, because it would assume a new constant speed in response to load changes.
604	2644	The governor was able to handle smaller variations such as those caused by fluctuating heat load to the boiler.
604	2645	Also, there was a tendency for oscillation whenever there was a speed change.
604	2646	As a consequence, engines equipped only with this governor were not suitable for operations requiring constant speed, such as cotton spinning.
604	2647	The governor was improved over time and coupled with variable steam cut off, good speed control in response to changes in load was attainable near the end of the 19th century.
605	2648	The adoption of compounding was common for industrial units, for road engines and almost universal for marine engines after 1880; it was not universally popular in railway locomotives where it was often perceived as complicated.
605	2649	This is partly due to the harsh railway operating environment and limited space afforded by the loading gauge (particularly in Britain, where compounding was never common and not employed after 1930).
605	2650	However, although never in the majority, it was popular in many other countries.
606	2651	The simplest valve gears give events of fixed length during the engine cycle and often make the engine rotate in only one direction.
606	2652	Most however have a reversing mechanism which additionally can provide means for saving steam as speed and momentum are gained by gradually "shortening the cutoff" or rather, shortening the admission event; this in turn proportionately lengthens the expansion period.
606	2653	However, as one and the same valve usually controls both steam flows, a short cutoff at admission adversely affects the exhaust and compression periods which should ideally always be kept fairly constant; if the exhaust event is too brief, the totality of the exhaust steam cannot evacuate the cylinder, choking it and giving excessive compression ("kick back").
607	2654	Using boiling water to produce mechanical motion goes back over 2000 years, but early devices were not practical.
607	2655	The Spanish inventor Jerónimo de Ayanz y Beaumont obtained the first patent for a steam engine in 1606.
607	2656	In 1698 Thomas Savery patented a steam pump that used steam in direct contact with the water being pumped.
607	2657	Savery's steam pump used condensing steam to create a vacuum and draw water into a chamber, and then applied pressurized steam to further pump the water.
607	2658	Thomas Newcomen's atmospheric engine was the first commercial true steam engine using a piston, and was used in 1712 for pumping in a mine.
608	2659	A steam turbine consists of one or more rotors (rotating discs) mounted on a drive shaft, alternating with a series of stators (static discs) fixed to the turbine casing.
608	2660	The rotors have a propeller-like arrangement of blades at the outer edge.
608	2661	Steam acts upon these blades, producing rotary motion.
608	2662	The stator consists of a similar, but fixed, series of blades that serve to redirect the steam flow onto the next rotor stage.
608	2663	A steam turbine often exhausts into a surface condenser that provides a vacuum.
608	2664	The stages of a steam turbine are typically arranged to extract the maximum potential work from a specific velocity and pressure of steam, giving rise to a series of variably sized high- and low-pressure stages.
608	2665	Turbines are only efficient if they rotate at relatively high speed, therefore they are usually connected to reduction gearing to drive lower speed applications, such as a ship's propeller.
608	2666	In the vast majority of large electric generating stations, turbines are directly connected to generators with no reduction gearing.
608	2667	Typical speeds are 3600 revolutions per minute (RPM) in the USA with 60 Hertz power, 3000 RPM in Europe and other countries with 50 Hertz electric power systems.
608	2668	In nuclear power applications the turbines typically run at half these speeds, 1800 RPM and 1500 RPM.
608	2669	A turbine rotor is also only capable of providing power when rotating in one direction.
608	2670	Therefore, a reversing stage or gearbox is usually required where power is required in the opposite direction.
609	2671	The weight of boilers and condensers generally makes the power-to-weight ratio of a steam plant lower than for internal combustion engines.
609	2672	For mobile applications steam has been largely superseded by internal combustion engines or electric motors.
609	2673	However, most electric power is generated using steam turbine plant, so that indirectly the world's industry is still dependent on steam power.
609	2674	Recent concerns about fuel sources and pollution have incited a renewed interest in steam both as a component of cogeneration processes and as a prime mover.
609	2675	This is becoming known as the Advanced Steam movement.
610	2676	It is possible to use a mechanism based on a pistonless rotary engine such as the Wankel engine in place of the cylinders and valve gear of a conventional reciprocating steam engine.
610	2677	Many such engines have been designed, from the time of James Watt to the present day, but relatively few were actually built and even fewer went into quantity production; see link at bottom of article for more details.
610	2678	The major problem is the difficulty of sealing the rotors to make them steam-tight in the face of wear and thermal expansion; the resulting leakage made them very inefficient.
610	2679	Lack of expansive working, or any means of control of the cutoff is also a serious problem with many such designs.
611	2680	The next major step occurred when James Watt developed (1763–1775) an improved version of Newcomen's engine, with a separate condenser.
611	2681	Boulton and Watt's early engines used half as much coal as John Smeaton's improved version of Newcomen's.
611	2682	Newcomen's and Watt's early engines were "atmospheric".
611	2683	They were powered by air pressure pushing a piston into the partial vacuum generated by condensing steam, instead of the pressure of expanding steam.
611	2684	The engine cylinders had to be large because the only usable force acting on them was due to atmospheric pressure.
612	2685	Steam engines frequently possess two independent mechanisms for ensuring that the pressure in the boiler does not go too high; one may be adjusted by the user, the second is typically designed as an ultimate fail-safe.
612	2686	Such safety valves traditionally used a simple lever to restrain a plug valve in the top of a boiler.
612	2687	One end of the lever carried a weight or spring that restrained the valve against steam pressure.
612	2688	Early valves could be adjusted by engine drivers, leading to many accidents when a driver fastened the valve down to allow greater steam pressure and more power from the engine.
612	2689	The more recent type of safety valve uses an adjustable spring-loaded valve, which is locked such that operators may not tamper with its adjustment unless a seal illegally is broken.
613	2690	The acme of the horizontal engine was the Corliss steam engine, patented in 1849, which was a four-valve counter flow engine with separate steam admission and exhaust valves and automatic variable steam cutoff.
613	2691	When Corliss was given the Rumford medal the committee said that "no one invention since Watt's time has so enhanced the efficiency of the steam engine".
613	2692	In addition to using 30% less steam, it provided more uniform speed due to variable steam cut off, making it well suited to manufacturing, especially cotton spinning.
614	2693	The steam engine contributed much to the development of thermodynamic theory; however, the only applications of scientific theory that influenced the steam engine were the original concepts of harnessing the power of steam and atmospheric pressure and knowledge of properties of heat and steam.
614	2694	The experimental measurements made by Watt on a model steam engine led to the development of the separate condenser.
614	2695	Watt independently discovered latent heat, which was confirmed by the original discoverer Joseph Black, who also advised Watt on experimental procedures.
614	2696	Watt was also aware of the change in the boiling point of water with pressure.
614	2697	Otherwise, the improvements to the engine itself were more mechanical in nature.
614	2698	The thermodynamic concepts of the Rankine cycle did give engineers the understanding needed to calculate efficiency which aided the development of modern high-pressure and -temperature boilers and the steam turbine.
615	2699	One of the principal advantages the Rankine cycle holds over others is that during the compression stage relatively little work is required to drive the pump, the working fluid being in its liquid phase at this point.
615	2700	By condensing the fluid, the work required by the pump consumes only 1% to 3% of the turbine power and contributes to a much higher efficiency for a real cycle.
615	2701	The benefit of this is lost somewhat due to the lower heat addition temperature.
615	2702	Gas turbines, for instance, have turbine entry temperatures approaching 1500 °C.
615	2703	Nonetheless, the efficiencies of actual large steam cycles and large modern gas turbines are fairly well matched.
616	2704	Other components are often present; pumps (such as an injector) to supply water to the boiler during operation, condensers to recirculate the water and recover the latent heat of vaporisation, and superheaters to raise the temperature of the steam above its saturated vapour point, and various mechanisms to increase the draft for fireboxes.
616	2705	When coal is used, a chain or screw stoking mechanism and its drive engine or motor may be included to move the fuel from a supply bin (bunker) to the firebox.
617	2706	Land-based steam engines could exhaust much of their steam, as feed water was usually readily available.
617	2707	Prior to and during World War I, the expansion engine dominated marine applications where high vessel speed was not essential.
617	2708	It was however superseded by the British invention steam turbine where speed was required, for instance in warships, such as the dreadnought battleships, and ocean liners.
617	2709	HMS Dreadnought of 1905 was the first major warship to replace the proven technology of the reciprocating engine with the then-novel steam turbine.
618	2710	Virtually all nuclear power plants generate electricity by heating water to provide steam that drives a turbine connected to an electrical generator.
618	2711	Nuclear-powered ships and submarines either use a steam turbine directly for main propulsion, with generators providing auxiliary power, or else employ turbo-electric transmission, where the steam drives a turbo generator set with propulsion provided by electric motors.
618	2712	A limited number of steam turbine railroad locomotives were manufactured.
618	2713	Some non-condensing direct-drive locomotives did meet with some success for long haul freight operations in Sweden and for express passenger work in Britain, but were not repeated.
618	2714	Elsewhere, notably in the U.S.A., more advanced designs with electric transmission were built experimentally, but not reproduced.
618	2715	It was found that steam turbines were not ideally suited to the railroad environment and these locomotives failed to oust the classic reciprocating steam unit in the way that modern diesel and electric traction has done.
619	2716	The Rankine cycle is sometimes referred to as a practical Carnot cycle because, when an efficient turbine is used, the TS diagram begins to resemble the Carnot cycle.
619	2717	The main difference is that heat addition (in the boiler) and rejection (in the condenser) are isobaric (constant pressure) processes in the Rankine cycle and isothermal (constant temperature) processes in the theoretical Carnot cycle.
619	2718	In this cycle a pump is used to pressurize the working fluid which is received from the condenser as a liquid not as a gas.
619	2719	Pumping the working fluid in liquid form during the cycle requires a small fraction of the energy to transport it compared to the energy needed to compress the working fluid in gaseous form in a compressor (as in the Carnot cycle).
619	2720	The cycle of a reciprocating steam engine differs from that of turbines because of condensation and re-evaporation occurring in the cylinder or in the steam inlet passages.
620	2721	Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8.
620	2722	It is a member of the chalcogen group on the periodic table and is a highly reactive nonmetal and oxidizing agent that readily forms compounds (notably oxides) with most elements.
620	2723	By mass, oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe, after hydrogen and helium.
620	2724	At standard temperature and pressure, two atoms of the element bind to form dioxygen, a colorless and odorless diatomic gas with the formula O\n2.
620	2725	Diatomic oxygen gas constitutes 20.8% of the Earth's atmosphere.
620	2726	However, monitoring of atmospheric oxygen levels show a global downward trend, because of fossil-fuel burning.
620	2727	Oxygen is the most abundant element by mass in the Earth's crust as part of oxide compounds such as silicon dioxide, making up almost half of the crust's mass.
621	2728	Many major classes of organic molecules in living organisms, such as proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and fats, contain oxygen, as do the major inorganic compounds that are constituents of animal shells, teeth, and bone.
621	2729	Most of the mass of living organisms is oxygen as it is a part of water, the major constituent of lifeforms.
621	2730	Oxygen is used in cellular respiration and released by photosynthesis, which uses the energy of sunlight to produce oxygen from water.
621	2731	It is too chemically reactive to remain a free element in air without being continuously replenished by the photosynthetic action of living organisms.
621	2732	Another form (allotrope) of oxygen, ozone (O\n3), strongly absorbs UVB radiation and consequently the high-altitude ozone layer helps protect the biosphere from ultraviolet radiation, but is a pollutant near the surface where it is a by-product of smog.
621	2733	At even higher low earth orbit altitudes, sufficient atomic oxygen is present to cause erosion for spacecraft.
622	2734	In the late 17th century, Robert Boyle proved that air is necessary for combustion.
622	2735	English chemist John Mayow (1641–1679) refined this work by showing that fire requires only a part of air that he called spiritus nitroaereus or just nitroaereus.
622	2736	In one experiment he found that placing either a mouse or a lit candle in a closed container over water caused the water to rise and replace one-fourteenth of the air's volume before extinguishing the subjects.
622	2737	From this he surmised that nitroaereus is consumed in both respiration and combustion.
623	2738	In the meantime, on August 1, 1774, an experiment conducted by the British clergyman Joseph Priestley focused sunlight on mercuric oxide (HgO) inside a glass tube, which liberated a gas he named "dephlogisticated air".
623	2739	He noted that candles burned brighter in the gas and that a mouse was more active and lived longer while breathing it.
623	2740	After breathing the gas himself, he wrote: "The feeling of it to my lungs was not sensibly different from that of common air, but I fancied that my breast felt peculiarly light and easy for some time afterwards."
623	2741	Priestley published his findings in 1775 in a paper titled "An Account of Further Discoveries in Air" which was included in the second volume of his book titled Experiments and Observations on Different Kinds of Air.
623	2742	Because he published his findings first, Priestley is usually given priority in the discovery.
624	2743	One of the first known experiments on the relationship between combustion and air was conducted by the 2nd century BCE Greek writer on mechanics, Philo of Byzantium.
624	2744	In his work Pneumatica, Philo observed that inverting a vessel over a burning candle and surrounding the vessel's neck with water resulted in some water rising into the neck.
624	2745	Philo incorrectly surmised that parts of the air in the vessel were converted into the classical element fire and thus were able to escape through pores in the glass.
624	2746	Many centuries later Leonardo da Vinci built on Philo's work by observing that a portion of air is consumed during combustion and respiration.
625	2747	Highly concentrated sources of oxygen promote rapid combustion.
625	2748	Fire and explosion hazards exist when concentrated oxidants and fuels are brought into close proximity; an ignition event, such as heat or a spark, is needed to trigger combustion.
625	2749	Oxygen is the oxidant, not the fuel, but nevertheless the source of most of the chemical energy released in combustion.
625	2750	Combustion hazards also apply to compounds of oxygen with a high oxidative potential, such as peroxides, chlorates, nitrates, perchlorates, and dichromates because they can donate oxygen to a fire.
626	2751	Concentrated O\n2 will allow combustion to proceed rapidly and energetically.
626	2752	Steel pipes and storage vessels used to store and transmit both gaseous and liquid oxygen will act as a fuel; and therefore the design and manufacture of O\n2 systems requires special training to ensure that ignition sources are minimized.
626	2753	The fire that killed the Apollo 1 crew in a launch pad test spread so rapidly because the capsule was pressurized with pure O\n2 but at slightly more than atmospheric pressure, instead of the 1⁄3 normal pressure that would be used in a mission.
627	2754	Oxygen is present in the atmosphere in trace quantities in the form of carbon dioxide (CO\n2).
627	2755	The Earth's crustal rock is composed in large part of oxides of silicon (silica SiO\n2, as found in granite and quartz), aluminium (aluminium oxide Al\n2O\n3, in bauxite and corundum), iron (iron(III) oxide Fe\n2O\n3, in hematite and rust), and calcium carbonate (in limestone).
627	2756	The rest of the Earth's crust is also made of oxygen compounds, in particular various complex silicates (in silicate minerals).
627	2757	The Earth's mantle, of much larger mass than the crust, is largely composed of silicates of magnesium and iron.
628	2758	John Dalton's original atomic hypothesis assumed that all elements were monatomic and that the atoms in compounds would normally have the simplest atomic ratios with respect to one another.
628	2759	For example, Dalton assumed that water's formula was HO, giving the atomic mass of oxygen as 8 times that of hydrogen, instead of the modern value of about 16.
628	2760	In 1805, Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Alexander von Humboldt showed that water is formed of two volumes of hydrogen and one volume of oxygen; and by 1811 Amedeo Avogadro had arrived at the correct interpretation of water's composition, based on what is now called Avogadro's law and the assumption of diatomic elemental molecules.
629	2761	Highly combustible materials that leave little residue, such as wood or coal, were thought to be made mostly of phlogiston; whereas non-combustible substances that corrode, such as iron, contained very little.
629	2762	Air did not play a role in phlogiston theory, nor were any initial quantitative experiments conducted to test the idea; instead, it was based on observations of what happens when something burns, that most common objects appear to become lighter and seem to lose something in the process.
629	2763	The fact that a substance like wood gains overall weight in burning was hidden by the buoyancy of the gaseous combustion products.
629	2764	Indeed, one of the first clues that the phlogiston theory was incorrect was that metals, too, gain weight in rusting (when they were supposedly losing phlogiston).
630	2765	In this dioxygen, the two oxygen atoms are chemically bonded to each other.
630	2766	The bond can be variously described based on level of theory, but is reasonably and simply described as a covalent double bond that results from the filling of molecular orbitals formed from the atomic orbitals of the individual oxygen atoms, the filling of which results in a bond order of two.
630	2767	More specifically, the double bond is the result of sequential, low-to-high energy, or Aufbau, filling of orbitals, and the resulting cancellation of contributions from the 2s electrons, after sequential filling of the low σ and σ* orbitals; σ overlap of the two atomic 2p orbitals that lie along the O-O molecular axis and π overlap of two pairs of atomic 2p orbitals perpendicular to the O-O molecular axis, and then cancellation of contributions from the remaining two of the six 2p electrons after their partial filling of the lowest π and π* orbitals.
631	2768	Oxygen was discovered independently by Carl Wilhelm Scheele, in Uppsala, in 1773 or earlier, and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire, in 1774, but Priestley is often given priority because his work was published first.
631	2769	The name oxygen was coined in 1777 by Antoine Lavoisier, whose experiments with oxygen helped to discredit the then-popular phlogiston theory of combustion and corrosion.
631	2770	Its name derives from the Greek roots ὀξύς oxys, "acid", literally "sharp", referring to the sour taste of acids and -γενής -genes, "producer", literally "begetter", because at the time of naming, it was mistakenly thought that all acids required oxygen in their composition.
631	2771	Common uses of oxygen includes the production cycle of steel, plastics and textiles, brazing, welding and cutting of steels and other metals, rocket propellant, in oxygen therapy and life support systems in aircraft, submarines, spaceflight and diving.
632	2772	This combination of cancellations and σ and π overlaps results in dioxygen's double bond character and reactivity, and a triplet electronic ground state.
632	2773	An electron configuration with two unpaired electrons as found in dioxygen (see the filled π* orbitals in the diagram), orbitals that are of equal energy—i.e., degenerate—is a configuration termed a spin triplet state.
632	2774	Hence, the ground state of the O\n2 molecule is referred to as triplet oxygen.
632	2775	[b] The highest energy, partially filled orbitals are antibonding, and so their filling weakens the bond order from three to two.
632	2776	Because of its unpaired electrons, triplet oxygen reacts only slowly with most organic molecules, which have paired electron spins; this prevents spontaneous combustion.
633	2777	In one experiment, Lavoisier observed that there was no overall increase in weight when tin and air were heated in a closed container.
633	2778	He noted that air rushed in when he opened the container, which indicated that part of the trapped air had been consumed.
633	2779	He also noted that the tin had increased in weight and that increase was the same as the weight of the air that rushed back in.
633	2780	This and other experiments on combustion were documented in his book Sur la combustion en général, which was published in 1777.
633	2781	In that work, he proved that air is a mixture of two gases; 'vital air', which is essential to combustion and respiration, and azote (Gk.
633	2782	ἄζωτον "lifeless"), which did not support either.
633	2783	Azote later became nitrogen in English, although it has kept the name in French and several other European languages.
634	2784	Trioxygen (O\n3) is usually known as ozone and is a very reactive allotrope of oxygen that is damaging to lung tissue.
634	2785	Ozone is produced in the upper atmosphere when O\n2 combines with atomic oxygen made by the splitting of O\n2 by ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
634	2786	Since ozone absorbs strongly in the UV region of the spectrum, the ozone layer of the upper atmosphere functions as a protective radiation shield for the planet.
634	2787	Near the Earth's surface, it is a pollutant formed as a by-product of automobile exhaust.
634	2788	The metastable molecule tetraoxygen (O\n4) was discovered in 2001, and was assumed to exist in one of the six phases of solid oxygen.
634	2789	It was proven in 2006 that this phase, created by pressurizing O\n2 to 20 GPa, is in fact a rhombohedral O\n8 cluster.
634	2790	This cluster has the potential to be a much more powerful oxidizer than either O\n2 or O\n3 and may therefore be used in rocket fuel.
634	2791	A metallic phase was discovered in 1990 when solid oxygen is subjected to a pressure of above 96 GPa and it was shown in 1998 that at very low temperatures, this phase becomes superconducting.
635	2792	The common allotrope of elemental oxygen on Earth is called dioxygen, O\n2.
635	2793	It is the form that is a major part of the Earth's atmosphere (see Occurrence).
635	2794	O2 has a bond length of 121 pm and a bond energy of 498 kJ·mol−1, which is smaller than the energy of other double bonds or pairs of single bonds in the biosphere and responsible for the exothermic reaction of O2 with any organic molecule.
635	2795	Due to its energy content, O2 is used by complex forms of life, such as animals, in cellular respiration (see Biological role).
635	2796	Other aspects of O\n2 are covered in the remainder of this article.
636	2797	In 1891 Scottish chemist James Dewar was able to produce enough liquid oxygen to study.
636	2798	The first commercially viable process for producing liquid oxygen was independently developed in 1895 by German engineer Carl von Linde and British engineer William Hampson.
636	2799	Both men lowered the temperature of air until it liquefied and then distilled the component gases by boiling them off one at a time and capturing them.
636	2800	Later, in 1901, oxyacetylene welding was demonstrated for the first time by burning a mixture of acetylene and compressed O\n2.
636	2801	This method of welding and cutting metal later became common.
637	2802	Oxygen is more soluble in water than nitrogen is.
637	2803	Water in equilibrium with air contains approximately 1 molecule of dissolved O\n2 for every 2 molecules of N\n2, compared to an atmospheric ratio of approximately 1:4.
637	2804	The solubility of oxygen in water is temperature-dependent, and about twice as much (14.6 mg·L−1) dissolves at 0 °C than at 20 °C (7.6 mg·L−1).
637	2805	At 25 °C and 1 standard atmosphere (101.3 kPa) of air, freshwater contains about 6.04 milliliters (mL) of oxygen per liter, whereas seawater contains about 4.95 mL per liter.
637	2806	At 5 °C the solubility increases to 9.0 mL (50% more than at 25 °C) per liter for water and 7.2 mL (45% more) per liter for sea water.
638	2807	Oxygen is the most abundant chemical element by mass in the Earth's biosphere, air, sea and land.
638	2808	Oxygen is the third most abundant chemical element in the universe, after hydrogen and helium.
638	2809	About 0.9% of the Sun's mass is oxygen.
638	2810	Oxygen constitutes 49.2% of the Earth's crust by mass and is the major component of the world's oceans (88.8% by mass).
638	2811	Oxygen gas is the second most common component of the Earth's atmosphere, taking up 20.8% of its volume and 23.1% of its mass (some 1015 tonnes).
638	2812	[d] Earth is unusual among the planets of the Solar System in having such a high concentration of oxygen gas in its atmosphere: Mars (with 0.1% O\n2 by volume) and Venus have far lower concentrations.
638	2813	The O\n2 surrounding these other planets is produced solely by ultraviolet radiation impacting oxygen-containing molecules such as carbon dioxide.
639	2814	By the late 19th century scientists realized that air could be liquefied, and its components isolated, by compressing and cooling it.
639	2815	Using a cascade method, Swiss chemist and physicist Raoul Pierre Pictet evaporated liquid sulfur dioxide in order to liquefy carbon dioxide, which in turn was evaporated to cool oxygen gas enough to liquefy it.
639	2816	He sent a telegram on December 22, 1877 to the French Academy of Sciences in Paris announcing his discovery of liquid oxygen.
639	2817	Just two days later, French physicist Louis Paul Cailletet announced his own method of liquefying molecular oxygen.
639	2818	Only a few drops of the liquid were produced in either case so no meaningful analysis could be conducted.
639	2819	Oxygen was liquified in stable state for the first time on March 29, 1883 by Polish scientists from Jagiellonian University, Zygmunt Wróblewski and Karol Olszewski.
640	2820	Planetary geologists have measured different abundances of oxygen isotopes in samples from the Earth, the Moon, Mars, and meteorites, but were long unable to obtain reference values for the isotope ratios in the Sun, believed to be the same as those of the primordial solar nebula.
640	2821	Analysis of a silicon wafer exposed to the solar wind in space and returned by the crashed Genesis spacecraft has shown that the Sun has a higher proportion of oxygen-16 than does the Earth.
640	2822	The measurement implies that an unknown process depleted oxygen-16 from the Sun's disk of protoplanetary material prior to the coalescence of dust grains that formed the Earth.
641	2823	Singlet oxygen is a name given to several higher-energy species of molecular O\n2 in which all the electron spins are paired.
641	2824	It is much more reactive towards common organic molecules than is molecular oxygen per se.
641	2825	In nature, singlet oxygen is commonly formed from water during photosynthesis, using the energy of sunlight.
641	2826	It is also produced in the troposphere by the photolysis of ozone by light of short wavelength, and by the immune system as a source of active oxygen.
641	2827	Carotenoids in photosynthetic organisms (and possibly also in animals) play a major role in absorbing energy from singlet oxygen and converting it to the unexcited ground state before it can cause harm to tissues.
642	2828	Paleoclimatologists measure the ratio of oxygen-18 and oxygen-16 in the shells and skeletons of marine organisms to determine what the climate was like millions of years ago (see oxygen isotope ratio cycle).
642	2829	Seawater molecules that contain the lighter isotope, oxygen-16, evaporate at a slightly faster rate than water molecules containing the 12% heavier oxygen-18; this disparity increases at lower temperatures.
642	2830	During periods of lower global temperatures, snow and rain from that evaporated water tends to be higher in oxygen-16, and the seawater left behind tends to be higher in oxygen-18.
642	2831	Marine organisms then incorporate more oxygen-18 into their skeletons and shells than they would in a warmer climate.
642	2832	Paleoclimatologists also directly measure this ratio in the water molecules of ice core samples that are up to several hundreds of thousands of years old.
643	2833	Oxygen presents two spectrophotometric absorption bands peaking at the wavelengths 687 and 760 nm.
643	2834	Some remote sensing scientists have proposed using the measurement of the radiance coming from vegetation canopies in those bands to characterize plant health status from a satellite platform.
643	2835	This approach exploits the fact that in those bands it is possible to discriminate the vegetation's reflectance from its fluorescence, which is much weaker.
643	2836	The measurement is technically difficult owing to the low signal-to-noise ratio and the physical structure of vegetation; but it has been proposed as a possible method of monitoring the carbon cycle from satellites on a global scale.
644	2837	In the triplet form, O\n2 molecules are paramagnetic.
644	2838	That is, they impart magnetic character to oxygen when it is in the presence of a magnetic field, because of the spin magnetic moments of the unpaired electrons in the molecule, and the negative exchange energy between neighboring O\n2 molecules.
644	2839	Liquid oxygen is attracted to a magnet to a sufficient extent that, in laboratory demonstrations, a bridge of liquid oxygen may be supported against its own weight between the poles of a powerful magnet.
645	2840	Reactive oxygen species, such as superoxide ion (O−\n2) and hydrogen peroxide (H\n2O\n2), are dangerous by-products of oxygen use in organisms.
645	2841	Parts of the immune system of higher organisms create peroxide, superoxide, and singlet oxygen to destroy invading microbes.
645	2842	Reactive oxygen species also play an important role in the hypersensitive response of plants against pathogen attack.
645	2843	Oxygen is toxic to obligately anaerobic organisms, which were the dominant form of early life on Earth until O\n2 began to accumulate in the atmosphere about 2.5 billion years ago during the Great Oxygenation Event, about a billion years after the first appearance of these organisms.
646	2844	Oxygen condenses at 90.20 K (−182.95 °C, −297.31 °F), and freezes at 54.36 K (−218.79 °C, −361.82 °F).
646	2845	Both liquid and solid O\n2 are clear substances with a light sky-blue color caused by absorption in the red (in contrast with the blue color of the sky, which is due to Rayleigh scattering of blue light).
646	2846	High-purity liquid O\n2 is usually obtained by the fractional distillation of liquefied air.
646	2847	Liquid oxygen may also be produced by condensation out of air, using liquid nitrogen as a coolant.
646	2848	It is a highly reactive substance and must be segregated from combustible materials.
647	2849	Free oxygen also occurs in solution in the world's water bodies.
647	2850	The increased solubility of O\n2 at lower temperatures (see Physical properties) has important implications for ocean life, as polar oceans support a much higher density of life due to their higher oxygen content.
647	2851	Water polluted with plant nutrients such as nitrates or phosphates may stimulate growth of algae by a process called eutrophication and the decay of these organisms and other biomaterials may reduce amounts of O\n2 in eutrophic water bodies.
647	2852	Scientists assess this aspect of water quality by measuring the water's biochemical oxygen demand, or the amount of O\n2 needed to restore it to a normal concentration.
648	2853	Free oxygen gas was almost nonexistent in Earth's atmosphere before photosynthetic archaea and bacteria evolved, probably about 3.5 billion years ago.
648	2854	Free oxygen first appeared in significant quantities during the Paleoproterozoic eon (between 3.0 and 2.3 billion years ago).
648	2855	For the first billion years, any free oxygen produced by these organisms combined with dissolved iron in the oceans to form banded iron formations.
648	2856	When such oxygen sinks became saturated, free oxygen began to outgas from the oceans 3–2.7 billion years ago, reaching 10% of its present level around 1.7 billion years ago.
649	2857	The unusually high concentration of oxygen gas on Earth is the result of the oxygen cycle.
649	2858	This biogeochemical cycle describes the movement of oxygen within and between its three main reservoirs on Earth: the atmosphere, the biosphere, and the lithosphere.
649	2859	The main driving factor of the oxygen cycle is photosynthesis, which is responsible for modern Earth's atmosphere.
649	2860	Photosynthesis releases oxygen into the atmosphere, while respiration and decay remove it from the atmosphere.
649	2861	In the present equilibrium, production and consumption occur at the same rate of roughly 1/2000th of the entire atmospheric oxygen per year.
650	2862	The other major method of producing O\n2 gas involves passing a stream of clean, dry air through one bed of a pair of identical zeolite molecular sieves, which absorbs the nitrogen and delivers a gas stream that is 90% to 93% O\n2.
650	2863	Simultaneously, nitrogen gas is released from the other nitrogen-saturated zeolite bed, by reducing the chamber operating pressure and diverting part of the oxygen gas from the producer bed through it, in the reverse direction of flow.
650	2864	After a set cycle time the operation of the two beds is interchanged, thereby allowing for a continuous supply of gaseous oxygen to be pumped through a pipeline.
650	2865	This is known as pressure swing adsorption.
650	2866	Oxygen gas is increasingly obtained by these non-cryogenic technologies (see also the related vacuum swing adsorption).
651	2867	Oxygen gas can also be produced through electrolysis of water into molecular oxygen and hydrogen.
651	2868	DC electricity must be used: if AC is used, the gases in each limb consist of hydrogen and oxygen in the explosive ratio 2:1.
651	2869	Contrary to popular belief, the 2:1 ratio observed in the DC electrolysis of acidified water does not prove that the empirical formula of water is H2O unless certain assumptions are made about the molecular formulae of hydrogen and oxygen themselves.
651	2870	A similar method is the electrocatalytic O\n2 evolution from oxides and oxoacids.
651	2871	Chemical catalysts can be used as well, such as in chemical oxygen generators or oxygen candles that are used as part of the life-support equipment on submarines, and are still part of standard equipment on commercial airliners in case of depressurization emergencies.
651	2872	Another air separation technology involves forcing air to dissolve through ceramic membranes based on zirconium dioxide by either high pressure or an electric current, to produce nearly pure O\n2 gas.
652	2873	Oxygen, as a supposed mild euphoric, has a history of recreational use in oxygen bars and in sports.
652	2874	Oxygen bars are establishments, found in Japan, California, and Las Vegas, Nevada since the late 1990s that offer higher than normal O\n2 exposure for a fee.
652	2875	Professional athletes, especially in American football, also sometimes go off field between plays to wear oxygen masks in order to get a "boost" in performance.
652	2876	The pharmacological effect is doubtful; a placebo effect is a more likely explanation.
652	2877	Available studies support a performance boost from enriched O\n2 mixtures only if they are breathed during aerobic exercise.
653	2878	Hyperbaric (high-pressure) medicine uses special oxygen chambers to increase the partial pressure of O\n2 around the patient and, when needed, the medical staff.
653	2879	Carbon monoxide poisoning, gas gangrene, and decompression sickness (the 'bends') are sometimes treated using these devices.
653	2880	Increased O\n2 concentration in the lungs helps to displace carbon monoxide from the heme group of hemoglobin.
653	2881	Oxygen gas is poisonous to the anaerobic bacteria that cause gas gangrene, so increasing its partial pressure helps kill them.
653	2882	Decompression sickness occurs in divers who decompress too quickly after a dive, resulting in bubbles of inert gas, mostly nitrogen and helium, forming in their blood.
653	2883	Increasing the pressure of O\n2 as soon as possible is part of the treatment.
654	2884	Uptake of O\n2 from the air is the essential purpose of respiration, so oxygen supplementation is used in medicine.
654	2885	Treatment not only increases oxygen levels in the patient's blood, but has the secondary effect of decreasing resistance to blood flow in many types of diseased lungs, easing work load on the heart.
654	2886	Oxygen therapy is used to treat emphysema, pneumonia, some heart disorders (congestive heart failure), some disorders that cause increased pulmonary artery pressure, and any disease that impairs the body's ability to take up and use gaseous oxygen.
655	2887	Due to its electronegativity, oxygen forms chemical bonds with almost all other elements to give corresponding oxides.
655	2888	The surface of most metals, such as aluminium and titanium, are oxidized in the presence of air and become coated with a thin film of oxide that passivates the metal and slows further corrosion.
655	2889	Many oxides of the transition metals are non-stoichiometric compounds, with slightly less metal than the chemical formula would show.
655	2890	For example, the mineral FeO (wüstite) is written as Fe\n1 − xO, where x is usually around 0.05.
656	2891	People who climb mountains or fly in non-pressurized fixed-wing aircraft sometimes have supplemental O\n2 supplies.
656	2892	[h] Passengers traveling in (pressurized) commercial airplanes have an emergency supply of O\n2 automatically supplied to them in case of cabin depressurization.
656	2893	Sudden cabin pressure loss activates chemical oxygen generators above each seat, causing oxygen masks to drop.
656	2894	Pulling on the masks "to start the flow of oxygen" as cabin safety instructions dictate, forces iron filings into the sodium chlorate inside the canister.
656	2895	A steady stream of oxygen gas is then produced by the exothermic reaction.
657	2896	Oxygen storage methods include high pressure oxygen tanks, cryogenics and chemical compounds.
657	2897	For reasons of economy, oxygen is often transported in bulk as a liquid in specially insulated tankers, since one liter of liquefied oxygen is equivalent to 840 liters of gaseous oxygen at atmospheric pressure and 20 °C (68 °F).
657	2898	Such tankers are used to refill bulk liquid oxygen storage containers, which stand outside hospitals and other institutions with a need for large volumes of pure oxygen gas.
657	2899	Liquid oxygen is passed through heat exchangers, which convert the cryogenic liquid into gas before it enters the building.
657	2900	Oxygen is also stored and shipped in smaller cylinders containing the compressed gas; a form that is useful in certain portable medical applications and oxy-fuel welding and cutting.
658	2901	Among the most important classes of organic compounds that contain oxygen are (where "R" is an organic group): alcohols (R-OH); ethers (R-O-R); ketones (R-CO-R); aldehydes (R-CO-H); carboxylic acids (R-COOH); esters (R-COO-R); acid anhydrides (R-CO-O-CO-R); and amides (R-C(O)-NR\n2).
658	2902	There are many important organic solvents that contain oxygen, including: acetone, methanol, ethanol, isopropanol, furan, THF, diethyl ether, dioxane, ethyl acetate, DMF, DMSO, acetic acid, and formic acid.
658	2903	Acetone ((CH\n3)\n2CO) and phenol (C\n6H\n5OH) are used as feeder materials in the synthesis of many different substances.
658	2904	Other important organic compounds that contain oxygen are: glycerol, formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde, citric acid, acetic anhydride, and acetamide.
658	2905	Epoxides are ethers in which the oxygen atom is part of a ring of three atoms.
659	2906	The element is found in almost all biomolecules that are important to (or generated by) life.
659	2907	Only a few common complex biomolecules, such as squalene and the carotenes, contain no oxygen.
659	2908	Of the organic compounds with biological relevance, carbohydrates contain the largest proportion by mass of oxygen.
659	2909	All fats, fatty acids, amino acids, and proteins contain oxygen (due to the presence of carbonyl groups in these acids and their ester residues).
659	2910	Oxygen also occurs in phosphate (PO3−\n4) groups in the biologically important energy-carrying molecules ATP and ADP, in the backbone and the purines (except adenine) and pyrimidines of RNA and DNA, and in bones as calcium phosphate and hydroxylapatite.
660	2911	Oxygen toxicity to the lungs and central nervous system can also occur in deep scuba diving and surface supplied diving.
660	2912	Prolonged breathing of an air mixture with an O\n2 partial pressure more than 60 kPa can eventually lead to permanent pulmonary fibrosis.
660	2913	Exposure to a O\n2 partial pressures greater than 160 kPa (about 1.6 atm) may lead to convulsions (normally fatal for divers).
660	2914	Acute oxygen toxicity (causing seizures, its most feared effect for divers) can occur by breathing an air mixture with 21% O\n2 at 66 m or more of depth; the same thing can occur by breathing 100% O\n2 at only 6 m.
661	2915	Breathing pure O\n2 in space applications, such as in some modern space suits, or in early spacecraft such as Apollo, causes no damage due to the low total pressures used.
661	2916	In the case of spacesuits, the O\n2 partial pressure in the breathing gas is, in general, about 30 kPa (1.4 times normal), and the resulting O\n2 partial pressure in the astronaut's arterial blood is only marginally more than normal sea-level O\n2 partial pressure (for more information on this, see space suit and arterial blood gas).
662	2917	Oxygen gas (O\n2) can be toxic at elevated partial pressures, leading to convulsions and other health problems.
662	2918	[j] Oxygen toxicity usually begins to occur at partial pressures more than 50 kilopascals (kPa), equal to about 50% oxygen composition at standard pressure or 2.5 times the normal sea-level O\n2 partial pressure of about 21 kPa.
662	2919	This is not a problem except for patients on mechanical ventilators, since gas supplied through oxygen masks in medical applications is typically composed of only 30%–50% O\n2 by volume (about 30 kPa at standard pressure).
662	2920	(although this figure also is subject to wide variation, depending on type of mask).
663	2921	The 1973 oil crisis began in October 1973 when the members of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries (OAPEC, consisting of the Arab members of OPEC plus Egypt and Syria) proclaimed an oil embargo.
663	2922	By the end of the embargo in March 1974, the price of oil had risen from US$3 per barrel to nearly $12 globally; US prices were significantly higher.
663	2923	The embargo caused an oil crisis, or "shock", with many short- and long-term effects on global politics and the global economy.
663	2924	It was later called the "first oil shock", followed by the 1979 oil crisis, termed the "second oil shock."
664	2925	The crisis had a major impact on international relations and created a rift within NATO.
664	2926	Some European nations and Japan sought to disassociate themselves from United States foreign policy in the Middle East to avoid being targeted by the boycott.
664	2927	Arab oil producers linked any future policy changes to peace between the belligerents.
664	2928	To address this, the Nixon Administration began multilateral negotiations with the combatants.
664	2929	They arranged for Israel to pull back from the Sinai Peninsula and the Golan Heights.
664	2930	By January 18, 1974, US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger had negotiated an Israeli troop withdrawal from parts of the Sinai Peninsula.
664	2931	The promise of a negotiated settlement between Israel and Syria was enough to convince Arab oil producers to lift the embargo in March 1974.
665	2932	On August 15, 1971, the United States unilaterally pulled out of the Bretton Woods Accord.
665	2933	The US abandoned the Gold Exchange Standard whereby the value of the dollar had been pegged to the price of gold and all other currencies were pegged to the dollar, whose value was left to "float" (rise and fall according to market demand).
665	2934	Shortly thereafter, Britain followed, floating the pound sterling.
665	2935	The other industrialized nations followed suit with their respective currencies.
665	2936	Anticipating that currency values would fluctuate unpredictably for a time, the industrialized nations increased their reserves (by expanding their money supplies) in amounts far greater than before.
665	2937	The result was a depreciation of the dollar and other industrialized nations' currencies.
665	2938	Because oil was priced in dollars, oil producers' real income decreased.
665	2939	In September 1971, OPEC issued a joint communiqué stating that, from then on, they would price oil in terms of a fixed amount of gold.
666	2940	This contributed to the "Oil Shock".
666	2941	After 1971, OPEC was slow to readjust prices to reflect this depreciation.
666	2942	From 1947 to 1967, the dollar price of oil had risen by less than two percent per year.
666	2943	Until the oil shock, the price had also remained fairly stable versus other currencies and commodities.
666	2944	OPEC ministers had not developed institutional mechanisms to update prices in sync with changing market conditions, so their real incomes lagged.
666	2945	The substantial price increases of 1973–1974 largely returned their prices and corresponding incomes to Bretton Woods levels in terms of commodities such as gold.
667	2946	On October 6, 1973, Syria and Egypt, with support from other Arab nations, launched a surprise attack on Israel, on Yom Kippur.
667	2947	This renewal of hostilities in the Arab–Israeli conflict released the underlying economic pressure on oil prices.
667	2948	At the time, Iran was the world's second-largest oil exporter and a close US ally.
667	2949	Weeks later, the Shah of Iran said in an interview: "Of course [the price of oil] is going to rise...
667	2950	You've [Western nations] increased the price of the wheat you sell us by 300 percent, and the same for sugar and cement... You buy our crude oil and sell it back to us, refined as petrochemicals, at a hundred times the price you've paid us...
667	2951	It's only fair that, from now on, you should pay more for oil.
668	2952	In response to American aid to Israel, on October 16, 1973, OPEC raised the posted price of oil by 70%, to $5.11 a barrel.
668	2953	The following day, oil ministers agreed to the embargo, a cut in production by five percent from September's output and to continue to cut production in five percent monthly increments until their economic and political objectives were met.
668	2954	On October 19, Nixon requested Congress to appropriate $2.2 billion in emergency aid to Israel, including $1.5 billion in outright grants.
668	2955	George Lenczowski notes, "Military supplies did not exhaust Nixon's eagerness to prevent Israel's collapse...This [$2.2 billion] decision triggered a collective OPEC response."
668	2956	Libya immediately announced it would embargo oil shipments to the United States.
668	2957	Saudi Arabia and the other Arab oil-producing states joined the embargo on October 20, 1973.
668	2958	At their Kuwait meeting, OAPEC proclaimed the embargo that curbed exports to various countries and blocked all oil deliveries to the US as a "principal hostile country".
669	2959	Some of the income was dispensed in the form of aid to other underdeveloped nations whose economies had been caught between higher oil prices and lower prices for their own export commodities, amid shrinking Western demand.
669	2960	Much went for arms purchases that exacerbated political tensions, particularly in the Middle East.
669	2961	Saudi Arabia spent over 100 billion dollars in the ensuing decades for helping spread its fundamentalist interpretation of Islam, known as Wahhabism, throughout the world, via religious charities such al-Haramain Foundation, which often also distributed funds to violent Sunni extremist groups such as Al-Qaeda and the Taliban.
670	2962	In the United States, scholars argue that there already existed a negotiated settlement based on equality between both parties prior to 1973.
670	2963	The possibility that the Middle East could become another superpower confrontation with the USSR was of more concern to the US than oil.
670	2964	Further, interest groups and government agencies more worried about energy were no match for Kissinger's dominance.
670	2965	In the US production, distribution and price disruptions "have been held responsible for recessions, periods of excessive inflation, reduced productivity, and lower economic growth."
671	2966	The embargo had a negative influence on the US economy by causing immediate demands to address the threats to U.S. energy security.
671	2967	On an international level, the price increases changed competitive positions in many industries, such as automobiles.
671	2968	Macroeconomic problems consisted of both inflationary and deflationary impacts.
671	2969	The embargo left oil companies searching for new ways to increase oil supplies, even in rugged terrain such as the Arctic.
671	2970	Finding oil and developing new fields usually required five to ten years before significant production.
672	2971	The embargo was not uniform across Europe.
672	2972	Of the nine members of the European Economic Community (EEC), the Netherlands faced a complete embargo, the UK and France received almost uninterrupted supplies (having refused to allow America to use their airfields and embargoed arms and supplies to both the Arabs and the Israelis), while the other six faced partial cutbacks.
672	2973	The UK had traditionally been an ally of Israel, and Harold Wilson's government supported the Israelis during the Six-Day War.
672	2974	His successor, Ted Heath, reversed this policy in 1970, calling for Israel to withdraw to its pre-1967 borders.
673	2975	Despite being relatively unaffected by the embargo, the UK nonetheless faced an oil crisis of its own - a series of strikes by coal miners and railroad workers over the winter of 1973–74 became a major factor in the change of government.
673	2976	Heath asked the British to heat only one room in their houses over the winter.
673	2977	The UK, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and Norway banned flying, driving and boating on Sundays.
673	2978	Sweden rationed gasoline and heating oil.
673	2979	The Netherlands imposed prison sentences for those who used more than their ration of electricity.
674	2980	Price controls exacerbated the crisis in the US.
674	2981	The system limited the price of "old oil" (that which had already been discovered) while allowing newly discovered oil to be sold at a higher price to encourage investment.
674	2982	Predictably, old oil was withdrawn from the market, creating greater scarcity.
674	2983	The rule also discouraged development of alternative energies.
674	2984	The rule had been intended to promote oil exploration.
674	2985	Scarcity was addressed by rationing (as in many countries).
674	2986	Motorists faced long lines at gas stations beginning in summer 1972 and increasing by summer 1973.
675	2987	In 1973, Nixon named William E. Simon as the first Administrator of the Federal Energy Office, a short-term organization created to coordinate the response to the embargo.
675	2988	Simon allocated states the same amount of domestic oil for 1974 that each had consumed in 1972, which worked for states whose populations were not increasing.
675	2989	In other states, lines at gasoline stations were common.
675	2990	The American Automobile Association reported that in the last week of February 1974, 20% of American gasoline stations had no fuel.
676	2991	To help reduce consumption, in 1974 a national maximum speed limit of 55 mph (about 88 km/h) was imposed through the Emergency Highway Energy Conservation Act.
676	2992	Development of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve began in 1975, and in 1977 the cabinet-level Department of Energy was created, followed by the National Energy Act of 1978.
676	2993	[citation needed] On November 28, 1995, Bill Clinton signed the National Highway Designation Act, ending the federal 55 mph (89 km/h) speed limit, allowing states to restore their prior maximum speed limit.
677	2994	The energy crisis led to greater interest in renewable energy, nuclear power and domestic fossil fuels.
677	2995	There is criticism that American energy policies since the crisis have been dominated by crisis-mentality thinking, promoting expensive quick fixes and single-shot solutions that ignore market and technology realities.
677	2996	Instead of providing stable rules that support basic research while leaving plenty of scope for entrepreneurship and innovation, congresses and presidents have repeatedly backed policies which promise solutions that are politically expedient, but whose prospects are doubtful.
678	2997	In 2004, declassified documents revealed that the U.S. was so distraught by the rise in oil prices and being challenged by under-developed countries that they briefly considered military action to forcibly seize Middle Eastern oilfields in late 1973.
678	2998	Although no explicit plan was mentioned, a conversation between U.S. Secretary of Defense James Schlesinger and British Ambassador to the United States Lord Cromer revealed Schlesinger had told him that "it was no longer obvious to him that the U.S. could not use force."
678	2999	British Prime Minister Edward Heath was so worried by this prospect that he ordered a British intelligence estimate of U.S. intentions, which concluded America "might consider it could not tolerate a situation in which the U.S. and its allies were at the mercy of a small group of unreasonable countries," and that they would prefer a rapid operation to seize oilfields in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, and possibly Abu Dhabi in military action was decided upon.
678	3000	Although the Soviet response to such an act would likely not involve force, intelligence warned "the American occupation would need to last 10 years as the West developed alternative energy sources, and would result in the ‘total alienation’ of the Arabs and much of the rest of the Third World."
679	3001	Although lacking historical connections to the Middle East, Japan was the country most dependent on Arab oil.
679	3002	71% of its imported oil came from the Middle East in 1970.
679	3003	On November 7, 1973, the Saudi and Kuwaiti governments declared Japan a "nonfriendly" country to encourage it to change its noninvolvement policy.
679	3004	It received a 5% production cut in December, causing a panic.
679	3005	On November 22, Japan issued a statement "asserting that Israel should withdraw from all of the 1967 territories, advocating Palestinian self-determination, and threatening to reconsider its policy toward Israel if Israel refused to accept these preconditions".
679	3006	By December 25, Japan was considered an Arab-friendly state.
680	3007	The USSR's invasion of Afghanistan was only one sign of insecurity in the region, also marked by increased American weapons sales, technology, and outright military presence.
680	3008	Saudi Arabia and Iran became increasingly dependent on American security assurances to manage both external and internal threats, including increased military competition between them over increased oil revenues.
680	3009	Both states were competing for preeminence in the Persian Gulf and using increased revenues to fund expanded militaries.
680	3010	By 1979, Saudi arms purchases from the US exceeded five times Israel's.
680	3011	Another motive for the large scale purchase of arms from the US by Saudi Arabia was the failure of the Shah during January 1979 to maintain control of Iran, a non-Arabic but largely Shiite Muslim nation, which fell to a theocratic Islamist government under the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in the wake of the 1979 Iranian Revolution.
680	3012	Saudi Arabia, on the other hand, is an Arab, largely Sunni Muslim nation headed by a near absolutist monarchy.
680	3013	In the wake of the Iranian revolution the Saudis were forced to deal with the prospect of internal destabilization via the radicalism of Islamism, a reality which would quickly be revealed in the seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca by Wahhabi extremists during November 1979 and a Shiite revolt in the oil rich Al-Hasa region of Saudi Arabia in December of the same year.
680	3014	In November 2010, Wikileaks leaked confidential diplomatic cables pertaining to the United States and its allies which revealed that the late Saudi King Abdullah urged the United States to attack Iran in order to destroy its potential nuclear weapons program, describing Iran as "a snake whose head should be cut off without any procrastination."
681	3015	The crisis reduced the demand for large cars.
681	3016	Japanese imports, primarily the Toyota Corona, the Toyota Corolla, the Datsun B210, the Datsun 510, the Honda Civic, the Mitsubishi Galant (a captive import from Chrysler sold as the Dodge Colt), the Subaru DL, and later the Honda Accord all had four cylinder engines that were more fuel efficient than the typical American V8 and six cylinder engines.
681	3017	Japanese imports became mass-market leaders with unibody construction and front-wheel drive, which became de facto standards.
682	3018	Some buyers lamented the small size of the first Japanese compacts, and both Toyota and Nissan (then known as Datsun) introduced larger cars such as the Toyota Corona Mark II, the Toyota Cressida, the Mazda 616 and Datsun 810, which added passenger space and amenities such as air conditioning, power steering, AM-FM radios, and even power windows and central locking without increasing the price of the vehicle.
682	3019	A decade after the 1973 oil crisis, Honda, Toyota and Nissan, affected by the 1981 voluntary export restraints, opened US assembly plants and established their luxury divisions (Acura, Lexus and Infiniti, respectively) to distinguish themselves from their mass-market brands.
683	3020	Compact trucks were introduced, such as the Toyota Hilux and the Datsun Truck, followed by the Mazda Truck (sold as the Ford Courier), and the Isuzu-built Chevrolet LUV.
683	3021	Mitsubishi rebranded its Forte as the Dodge D-50 a few years after the oil crisis.
683	3022	Mazda, Mitsubishi and Isuzu had joint partnerships with Ford, Chrysler, and GM, respectively.
683	3023	Later the American makers introduced their domestic replacements (Ford Ranger, Dodge Dakota and the Chevrolet S10/GMC S-15), ending their captive import policy.
684	3024	An increase in imported cars into North America forced General Motors, Ford and Chrysler to introduce smaller and fuel-efficient models for domestic sales.
684	3025	The Dodge Omni / Plymouth Horizon from Chrysler, the Ford Fiesta and the Chevrolet Chevette all had four-cylinder engines and room for at least four passengers by the late 1970s.
684	3026	By 1985, the average American vehicle moved 17.4 miles per gallon, compared to 13.5 in 1970.
684	3027	The improvements stayed even though the price of a barrel of oil remained constant at $12 from 1974 to 1979.
684	3028	Sales of large sedans for most makes (except Chrysler products) recovered within two model years of the 1973 crisis.
684	3029	The Cadillac DeVille and Fleetwood, Buick Electra, Oldsmobile 98, Lincoln Continental, Mercury Marquis, and various other luxury oriented sedans became popular again in the mid-1970s.
684	3030	The only full-size models that did not recover were lower price models such as the Chevrolet Bel Air, and Ford Galaxie 500.
684	3031	Slightly smaller, mid-size models such as the Oldsmobile Cutlass, Chevrolet Monte Carlo, Ford Thunderbird and various other models sold well.
685	3032	Federal safety standards, such as NHTSA Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 215 (pertaining to safety bumpers), and compacts like the 1974 Mustang I were a prelude to the DOT "downsize" revision of vehicle categories.
685	3033	By 1977, GM's full-sized cars reflected the crisis.
685	3034	By 1979, virtually all "full-size" American cars had shrunk, featuring smaller engines and smaller outside dimensions.
685	3035	Chrysler ended production of their full-sized luxury sedans at the end of the 1981 model year, moving instead to a full front-wheel drive lineup for 1982 (except for the M-body Dodge Diplomat/Plymouth Gran Fury and Chrysler New Yorker Fifth Avenue sedans).
686	3036	OPEC soon lost its preeminent position, and in 1981, its production was surpassed by that of other countries.
686	3037	Additionally, its own member nations were divided.
686	3038	Saudi Arabia, trying to recover market share, increased production, pushing prices down, shrinking or eliminating profits for high-cost producers.
686	3039	The world price, which had peaked during the 1979 energy crisis at nearly $40 per barrel, decreased during the 1980s to less than $10 per barrel.
686	3040	Adjusted for inflation, oil briefly fell back to pre-1973 levels.
686	3041	This "sale" price was a windfall for oil-importing nations, both developing and developed.
687	3042	The Apollo program, also known as Project Apollo, was the third United States human spaceflight program carried out by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), which accomplished landing the first humans on the Moon from 1969 to 1972.
687	3043	First conceived during Dwight D. Eisenhower's administration as a three-man spacecraft to follow the one-man Project Mercury which put the first Americans in space, Apollo was later dedicated to President John F. Kennedy's national goal of "landing a man on the Moon and returning him safely to the Earth" by the end of the 1960s, which he proposed in a May 25, 1961, address to Congress.
687	3044	Project Mercury was followed by the two-man Project Gemini (1962–66).
687	3045	The first manned flight of Apollo was in 1968.
688	3046	Apollo ran from 1961 to 1972, and was supported by the two-man Gemini program which ran concurrently with it from 1962 to 1966.
688	3047	Gemini missions developed some of the space travel techniques that were necessary for the success of the Apollo missions.
688	3048	Apollo used Saturn family rockets as launch vehicles.
688	3049	Apollo/Saturn vehicles were also used for an Apollo Applications Program, which consisted of Skylab, a space station that supported three manned missions in 1973–74, and the Apollo–Soyuz Test Project, a joint Earth orbit mission with the Soviet Union in 1975.
689	3050	The Apollo program succeeded in achieving its goal of manned lunar landing, despite the major setback of a 1967 Apollo 1 cabin fire that killed the entire crew during a prelaunch test.
689	3051	After the first landing, sufficient flight hardware remained for nine follow-on landings with a plan for extended lunar geological and astrophysical exploration.
689	3052	Budget cuts forced the cancellation of three of these.
689	3053	Five of the remaining six missions achieved successful landings, but the Apollo 13 landing was prevented by an oxygen tank explosion in transit to the Moon, which disabled the command spacecraft's propulsion and life support.
689	3054	The crew returned to Earth safely by using the Lunar Module as a "lifeboat" for these functions.
690	3055	Apollo set several major human spaceflight milestones.
690	3056	It stands alone in sending manned missions beyond low Earth orbit.
690	3057	Apollo 8 was the first manned spacecraft to orbit another celestial body, while the final Apollo 17 mission marked the sixth Moon landing and the ninth manned mission beyond low Earth orbit.
690	3058	The program returned 842 pounds (382 kg) of lunar rocks and soil to Earth, greatly contributing to the understanding of the Moon's composition and geological history.
690	3059	The program laid the foundation for NASA's current human spaceflight capability, and funded construction of its Johnson Space Center and Kennedy Space Center.
690	3060	Apollo also spurred advances in many areas of technology incidental to rocketry and manned spaceflight, including avionics, telecommunications, and computers.
691	3061	The Apollo program was conceived during the Eisenhower administration in early 1960, as a follow-up to Project Mercury.
691	3062	While the Mercury capsule could only support one astronaut on a limited Earth orbital mission, Apollo would carry three astronauts.
691	3063	Possible missions included ferrying crews to a space station, circumlunar flights, and eventual manned lunar landings.
691	3064	The program was named after the Greek god of light, music, and the sun by NASA manager Abe Silverstein, who later said that "I was naming the spacecraft like I'd name my baby."
691	3065	Silverstein chose the name at home one evening, early in 1960, because he felt "Apollo riding his chariot across the Sun was appropriate to the grand scale of the proposed program."
692	3066	In July 1960, NASA Deputy Administrator Hugh L. Dryden announced the Apollo program to industry representatives at a series of Space Task Group conferences.
692	3067	Preliminary specifications were laid out for a spacecraft with a mission module cabin separate from the command module (piloting and re-entry cabin), and a propulsion and equipment module.
692	3068	On August 30, a feasibility study competition was announced, and on October 25, three study contracts were awarded to General Dynamics/Convair, General Electric, and the Glenn L. Martin Company.
692	3069	Meanwhile, NASA performed its own in-house spacecraft design studies led by Maxime Faget, to serve as a gauge to judge and monitor the three industry designs.
693	3070	In November 1960, John F. Kennedy was elected president after a campaign that promised American superiority over the Soviet Union in the fields of space exploration and missile defense.
693	3071	Up to the election of 1960, Kennedy had been speaking out against the "missile gap" that he and many other senators felt had formed between the Soviets and themselves due to the inaction of President Eisenhower.
693	3072	Beyond military power, Kennedy used aerospace technology as a symbol of national prestige, pledging to make the US not "first but, first and, first if, but first period."
693	3073	Despite Kennedy's rhetoric, he did not immediately come to a decision on the status of the Apollo program once he became president.
693	3074	He knew little about the technical details of the space program, and was put off by the massive financial commitment required by a manned Moon landing.
693	3075	When Kennedy's newly appointed NASA Administrator James E. Webb requested a 30 percent budget increase for his agency, Kennedy supported an acceleration of NASA's large booster program but deferred a decision on the broader issue.
694	3076	On April 12, 1961, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first person to fly in space, reinforcing American fears about being left behind in a technological competition with the Soviet Union.
694	3077	At a meeting of the US House Committee on Science and Astronautics one day after Gagarin's flight, many congressmen pledged their support for a crash program aimed at ensuring that America would catch up.
694	3078	Kennedy was circumspect in his response to the news, refusing to make a commitment on America's response to the Soviets.
695	3079	On April 20, Kennedy sent a memo to Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson, asking Johnson to look into the status of America's space program, and into programs that could offer NASA the opportunity to catch up.
695	3080	Johnson responded approximately one week later, concluding that "we are neither making maximum effort nor achieving results necessary if this country is to reach a position of leadership."
695	3081	His memo concluded that a manned Moon landing was far enough in the future that it was likely the United States would achieve it first.
696	3082	It became clear that managing the Apollo program would exceed the capabilities of Robert R. Gilruth's Space Task Group, which had been directing the nation's manned space program from NASA's Langley Research Center.
696	3083	So Gilruth was given authority to grow his organization into a new NASA center, the Manned Spacecraft Center (MSC).
696	3084	A site was chosen in Houston, Texas, on land donated by Rice University, and Administrator Webb announced the conversion on September 19, 1961.
696	3085	It was also clear NASA would soon outgrow its practice of controlling missions from its Cape Canaveral Air Force Station launch facilities in Florida, so a new Mission Control Center would be included in the MSC.
697	3086	It also became clear that Apollo would outgrow the Canaveral launch facilities in Florida.
697	3087	The two newest launch complexes were already being built for the Saturn I and IB rockets at the northernmost end: LC-34 and LC-37.
697	3088	But an even bigger facility would be needed for the mammoth rocket required for the manned lunar mission, so land acquisition was started in July 1961 for a Launch Operations Center (LOC) immediately north of Canaveral at Merritt Island.
697	3089	The design, development and construction of the center was conducted by Kurt H. Debus, a member of Dr. Wernher von Braun's original V-2 rocket engineering team.
697	3090	Debus was named the LOC's first Director.
697	3091	Upon Kennedy's death, President Johnson issued an executive order on November 29, 1963, to rename the LOC and Cape Canaveral in honor of Kennedy.
698	3092	The LOC included Launch Complex 39, a Launch Control Center, and a 130 million cubic foot (3.7 million cubic meter) Vertical Assembly Building (VAB) in which the space vehicle (launch vehicle and spacecraft) would be assembled on a Mobile Launcher Platform and then moved by a transporter to one of several launch pads.
698	3093	Although at least three pads were planned, only two, designated A and B, were completed in October 1965.
698	3094	The LOC also included an Operations and Checkout Building (OCB) to which Gemini and Apollo spacecraft were initially received prior to being mated to their launch vehicles.
698	3095	The Apollo spacecraft could be tested in two vacuum chambers capable of simulating atmospheric pressure at altitudes up to 250,000 feet (76 km), which is nearly a vacuum.
699	3096	Administrator Webb realized that in order to keep Apollo costs under control, he had to develop greater project management skills in his organization, so he recruited Dr. George E. Mueller for a high management job.
699	3097	Mueller accepted, on the condition that he have a say in NASA reorganization necessary to effectively administer Apollo.
699	3098	Webb then worked with Associate Administrator (later Deputy Administrator) Robert Seamans to reorganize the Office of Manned Space Flight (OMSF).
699	3099	On July 23, 1963, Webb announced Mueller's appointment as Deputy Associate Administrator for Manned Space Flight, to replace then Associate Administrator D. Brainerd Holmes on his retirement effective September 1.
699	3100	Under Webb's reorganization, the directors of the Manned Spacecraft Center (Gilruth) Marshall Space Flight Center (von Braun) and the Launch Operations Center (Debus) effectively reported to Mueller.
700	3101	Based on his industry experience on Air Force missile projects, Mueller realized some skilled managers could be found among high-ranking officers in the United States Air Force, so he got Webb's permission to recruit General Samuel C. Phillips, who gained a reputation for his effective management of the Minuteman program, as OMSF program controller.
700	3102	Phillips' superior officer Bernard A. Schriever agreed to loan Phillips to NASA, along with a staff of officers under him, on the condition that Phillips be made Apollo Program Director.
700	3103	Mueller agreed, and Phillips managed Apollo from January 1964, until it achieved the first manned landing in July 1969, after which he returned to Air Force duty.
701	3104	In early 1961, direct ascent was generally the mission mode in favor at NASA.
701	3105	Many engineers feared that a rendezvous —let alone a docking— neither of which had been attempted even in Earth orbit, would be extremely difficult in lunar orbit.
701	3106	Dissenters including John Houbolt at Langley Research Center emphasized the important weight reductions that were offered by the LOR approach.
701	3107	Throughout 1960 and 1961, Houbolt campaigned for the recognition of LOR as a viable and practical option.
701	3108	Bypassing the NASA hierarchy, he sent a series of memos and reports on the issue to Associate Administrator Robert Seamans; while acknowledging that he spoke "somewhat as a voice in the wilderness," Houbolt pleaded that LOR should not be discounted in studies of the question.
702	3109	 Seamans' establishment of an ad-hoc committee headed by his special technical assistant Nicholas E. Golovin in July 1961, to recommend a launch vehicle to be used in the Apollo program, represented a turning point in NASA's mission mode decision.
