872	4040	Some older networks such as TELENET and TYMNET were modified to provide a X.25 host interface in addition to older host connection schemes.
872	4041	DATAPAC was developed by Bell Northern Research which was a joint venture of Bell Canada (a common carrier) and Northern Telecom (a telecommunications equipment supplier).
872	4042	Northern Telecom sold several DATAPAC clones to foreign PTTs including the Deutsche Bundespost.
872	4043	X.75 and X.121 allowed the interconnection of national X.25 networks.
872	4044	A user or host could call a host on a foreign network by including the DNIC of the remote network as part of the destination address.
873	4045	AUSTPAC was an Australian public X.25 network operated by Telstra.
873	4046	Started by Telecom Australia in the early 1980s, AUSTPAC was Australia's first public packet-switched data network, supporting applications such as on-line betting, financial applications — the Australian Tax Office made use of AUSTPAC — and remote terminal access to academic institutions, who maintained their connections to AUSTPAC up until the mid-late 1990s in some cases.
873	4047	Access can be via a dial-up terminal to a PAD, or, by linking a permanent X.25 node to the network.
874	4048	Datanet 1 was the public switched data network operated by the Dutch PTT Telecom (now known as KPN).
874	4049	Strictly speaking Datanet 1 only referred to the network and the connected users via leased lines (using the X.121 DNIC 2041), the name also referred to the public PAD service Telepad (using the DNIC 2049).
874	4050	And because the main Videotex service used the network and modified PAD devices as infrastructure the name Datanet 1 was used for these services as well.
874	4051	Although this use of the name was incorrect all these services were managed by the same people within one department of KPN contributed to the confusion.
875	4052	The Computer Science Network (CSNET) was a computer network funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) that began operation in 1981.
875	4053	Its purpose was to extend networking benefits, for computer science departments at academic and research institutions that could not be directly connected to ARPANET, due to funding or authorization limitations.
875	4054	It played a significant role in spreading awareness of, and access to, national networking and was a major milestone on the path to development of the global Internet.
876	4055	Internet2 is a not-for-profit United States computer networking consortium led by members from the research and education communities, industry, and government.
876	4056	The Internet2 community, in partnership with Qwest, built the first Internet2 Network, called Abilene, in 1998 and was a prime investor in the National LambdaRail (NLR) project.
876	4057	In 2006, Internet2 announced a partnership with Level 3 Communications to launch a brand new nationwide network, boosting its capacity from 10 Gbit/s to 100 Gbit/s.
876	4058	In October, 2007, Internet2 officially retired Abilene and now refers to its new, higher capacity network as the Internet2 Network.
877	4059	The National Science Foundation Network (NSFNET) was a program of coordinated, evolving projects sponsored by the National Science Foundation (NSF) beginning in 1985 to promote advanced research and education networking in the United States.
877	4060	NSFNET was also the name given to several nationwide backbone networks operating at speeds of 56 kbit/s, 1.5 Mbit/s (T1), and 45 Mbit/s (T3) that were constructed to support NSF's networking initiatives from 1985-1995.
877	4061	Initially created to link researchers to the nation's NSF-funded supercomputing centers, through further public funding and private industry partnerships it developed into a major part of the Internet backbone.
878	4062	The Very high-speed Backbone Network Service (vBNS) came on line in April 1995 as part of a National Science Foundation (NSF) sponsored project to provide high-speed interconnection between NSF-sponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the United States.
878	4063	The network was engineered and operated by MCI Telecommunications under a cooperative agreement with the NSF.
878	4064	By 1998, the vBNS had grown to connect more than 100 universities and research and engineering institutions via 12 national points of presence with DS-3 (45 Mbit/s), OC-3c (155 Mbit/s), and OC-12c (622 Mbit/s) links on an all OC-12c backbone, a substantial engineering feat for that time.
878	4065	The vBNS installed one of the first ever production OC-48c (2.5 Gbit/s) IP links in February 1999 and went on to upgrade the entire backbone to OC-48c.
879	4066	The Black Death is thought to have originated in the arid plains of Central Asia, where it then travelled along the Silk Road, reaching Crimea by 1343.
879	4067	From there, it was most likely carried by Oriental rat fleas living on the black rats that were regular passengers on merchant ships.
879	4068	Spreading throughout the Mediterranean and Europe, the Black Death is estimated to have killed 30–60% of Europe's total population.
879	4069	In total, the plague reduced the world population from an estimated 450 million down to 350–375 million in the 14th century.
879	4070	The world population as a whole did not recover to pre-plague levels until the 17th century.
879	4071	The plague recurred occasionally in Europe until the 19th century.
880	4072	The plague disease, caused by Yersinia pestis, is enzootic (commonly present) in populations of fleas carried by ground rodents, including marmots, in various areas including Central Asia, Kurdistan, Western Asia, Northern India and Uganda.
880	4073	Nestorian graves dating to 1338–39 near Lake Issyk Kul in Kyrgyzstan have inscriptions referring to plague and are thought by many epidemiologists to mark the outbreak of the epidemic, from which it could easily have spread to China and India.
880	4074	In October 2010, medical geneticists suggested that all three of the great waves of the plague originated in China.
880	4075	In China, the 13th century Mongol conquest caused a decline in farming and trading.
880	4076	However, economic recovery had been observed at the beginning of the 14th century.
880	4077	In the 1330s a large number of natural disasters and plagues led to widespread famine, starting in 1331, with a deadly plague arriving soon after.
880	4078	Epidemics that may have included plague killed an estimated 25 million Chinese and other Asians during the 15 years before it reached Constantinople in 1347.
881	4079	Plague was reportedly first introduced to Europe via Genoese traders at the port city of Kaffa in the Crimea in 1347.
881	4080	After a protracted siege, during which the Mongol army under Jani Beg was suffering from the disease, the army catapulted the infected corpses over the city walls of Kaffa to infect the inhabitants.
881	4081	The Genoese traders fled, taking the plague by ship into Sicily and the south of Europe, whence it spread north.
881	4082	Whether or not this hypothesis is accurate, it is clear that several existing conditions such as war, famine, and weather contributed to the severity of the Black Death.
882	4083	From Italy, the disease spread northwest across Europe, striking France, Spain, Portugal and England by June 1348, then turned and spread east through Germany and Scandinavia from 1348 to 1350.
882	4084	It was introduced in Norway in 1349 when a ship landed at Askøy, then spread to Bjørgvin (modern Bergen) and Iceland.
882	4085	Finally it spread to northwestern Russia in 1351.
882	4086	The plague was somewhat less common in parts of Europe that had smaller trade relations with their neighbours, including the Kingdom of Poland, the majority of the Basque Country, isolated parts of Belgium and the Netherlands, and isolated alpine villages throughout the continent.
883	4087	The plague struck various countries in the Middle East during the pandemic, leading to serious depopulation and permanent change in both economic and social structures.
883	4088	As it spread to western Europe, the disease entered the region from southern Russia also.
883	4089	By autumn 1347, the plague reached Alexandria in Egypt, probably through the port's trade with Constantinople, and ports on the Black Sea.
883	4090	During 1347, the disease travelled eastward to Gaza, and north along the eastern coast to cities in Lebanon, Syria and Palestine, including Ashkelon, Acre, Jerusalem, Sidon, Damascus, Homs, and Aleppo.
883	4091	In 1348–49, the disease reached Antioch.
883	4092	The city's residents fled to the north, most of them dying during the journey, but the infection had been spread to the people of Asia Minor.
884	4093	Gasquet (1908) claimed that the Latin name atra mors (Black Death) for the 14th-century epidemic first appeared in modern times in 1631 in a book on Danish history by J.I.
884	4094	Pontanus: "Vulgo & ab effectu atram mortem vocatibant.
884	4095	("Commonly and from its effects, they called it the black death").
884	4096	The name spread through Scandinavia and then Germany, gradually becoming attached to the mid 14th-century epidemic as a proper name.
884	4097	In England, it was not until 1823 that the medieval epidemic was first called the Black Death.
885	4098	Medical knowledge had stagnated during the Middle Ages.
885	4099	The most authoritative account at the time came from the medical faculty in Paris in a report to the king of France that blamed the heavens, in the form of a conjunction of three planets in 1345 that caused a "great pestilence in the air".
885	4100	This report became the first and most widely circulated of a series of plague tracts that sought to give advice to sufferers.
885	4101	That the plague was caused by bad air became the most widely accepted theory.
885	4102	Today, this is known as the Miasma theory.
885	4103	The word 'plague' had no special significance at this time, and only the recurrence of outbreaks during the Middle Ages gave it the name that has become the medical term.
886	4104	The dominant explanation for the Black Death is the plague theory, which attributes the outbreak to Yersinia pestis, also responsible for an epidemic that began in southern China in 1865, eventually spreading to India.
886	4105	The investigation of the pathogen that caused the 19th-century plague was begun by teams of scientists who visited Hong Kong in 1894, among whom was the French-Swiss bacteriologist Alexandre Yersin, after whom the pathogen was named Yersinia pestis.
886	4106	The mechanism by which Y. pestis was usually transmitted was established in 1898 by Paul-Louis Simond and was found to involve the bites of fleas whose midguts had become obstructed by replicating Y. pestis several days after feeding on an infected host.
886	4107	This blockage results in starvation and aggressive feeding behaviour by the fleas, which repeatedly attempt to clear their blockage by regurgitation, resulting in thousands of plague bacteria being flushed into the feeding site, infecting the host.
886	4108	The bubonic plague mechanism was also dependent on two populations of rodents: one resistant to the disease, which act as hosts, keeping the disease endemic, and a second that lack resistance.
886	4109	When the second population dies, the fleas move on to other hosts, including people, thus creating a human epidemic.
887	4110	The historian Francis Aidan Gasquet wrote about the 'Great Pestilence' in 1893 and suggested that "it would appear to be some form of the ordinary Eastern or bubonic plague".
887	4111	He was able to adopt the epidemiology of the bubonic plague for the Black Death for the second edition in 1908, implicating rats and fleas in the process, and his interpretation was widely accepted for other ancient and medieval epidemics, such as the Justinian plague that was prevalent in the Eastern Roman Empire from 541 to 700 CE.
888	4112	Other forms of plague have been implicated by modern scientists.
888	4113	The modern bubonic plague has a mortality rate of 30–75% and symptoms including fever of 38–41 °C (100–106 °F), headaches, painful aching joints, nausea and vomiting, and a general feeling of malaise.
888	4114	Left untreated, of those that contract the bubonic plague, 80 percent die within eight days.
888	4115	Pneumonic plague has a mortality rate of 90 to 95 percent.
888	4116	Symptoms include fever, cough, and blood-tinged sputum.
888	4117	As the disease progresses, sputum becomes free flowing and bright red.
888	4118	Septicemic plague is the least common of the three forms, with a mortality rate near 100%.
888	4119	Symptoms are high fevers and purple skin patches (purpura due to disseminated intravascular coagulation).
888	4120	In cases of pneumonic and particularly septicemic plague, the progress of the disease is so rapid that there would often be no time for the development of the enlarged lymph nodes that were noted as buboes.
889	4121	In October 2010, the open-access scientific journal PLoS Pathogens published a paper by a multinational team who undertook a new investigation into the role of Yersinia pestis in the Black Death following the disputed identification by Drancourt and Raoult in 1998.
889	4122	They assessed the presence of DNA/RNA with Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) techniques for Y. pestis from the tooth sockets in human skeletons from mass graves in northern, central and southern Europe that were associated archaeologically with the Black Death and subsequent resurgences.
889	4123	The authors concluded that this new research, together with prior analyses from the south of France and Germany, ".
889	4124	ends the debate about the etiology of the Black Death, and unambiguously demonstrates that Y. pestis was the causative agent of the epidemic plague that devastated Europe during the Middle Ages".
890	4125	The study also found that there were two previously unknown but related clades (genetic branches) of the Y. pestis genome associated with medieval mass graves.
890	4126	These clades (which are thought to be extinct) were found to be ancestral to modern isolates of the modern Y. pestis strains Y. p. orientalis and Y. p. medievalis, suggesting the plague may have entered Europe in two waves.
890	4127	Surveys of plague pit remains in France and England indicate the first variant entered Europe through the port of Marseille around November 1347 and spread through France over the next two years, eventually reaching England in the spring of 1349, where it spread through the country in three epidemics.
890	4128	Surveys of plague pit remains from the Dutch town of Bergen op Zoom showed the Y. pestis genotype responsible for the pandemic that spread through the Low Countries from 1350 differed from that found in Britain and France, implying Bergen op Zoom (and possibly other parts of the southern Netherlands) was not directly infected from England or France in 1349 and suggesting a second wave of plague, different from those in Britain and France, may have been carried to the Low Countries from Norway, the Hanseatic cities or another site.
891	4129	The results of the Haensch study have since been confirmed and amended.
891	4130	Based on genetic evidence derived from Black Death victims in the East Smithfield burial site in England, Schuenemann et al.
891	4131	concluded in 2011 "that the Black Death in medieval Europe was caused by a variant of Y. pestis that may no longer exist."
891	4132	A study published in Nature in October 2011 sequenced the genome of Y. pestis from plague victims and indicated that the strain that caused the Black Death is ancestral to most modern strains of the disease.
892	4133	The plague theory was first significantly challenged by the work of British bacteriologist J. F. D. Shrewsbury in 1970, who noted that the reported rates of mortality in rural areas during the 14th-century pandemic were inconsistent with the modern bubonic plague, leading him to conclude that contemporary accounts were exaggerations.
892	4134	In 1984 zoologist Graham Twigg produced the first major work to challenge the bubonic plague theory directly, and his doubts about the identity of the Black Death have been taken up by a number of authors, including Samuel K. Cohn, Jr. (2002), David Herlihy (1997), and Susan Scott and Christopher Duncan (2001).
893	4135	It is recognised that an epidemiological account of the plague is as important as an identification of symptoms, but researchers are hampered by the lack of reliable statistics from this period.
893	4136	Most work has been done on the spread of the plague in England, and even estimates of overall population at the start vary by over 100% as no census was undertaken between the time of publication of the Domesday Book and the year 1377.
893	4137	Estimates of plague victims are usually extrapolated from figures from the clergy.
894	4138	In addition to arguing that the rat population was insufficient to account for a bubonic plague pandemic, sceptics of the bubonic plague theory point out that the symptoms of the Black Death are not unique (and arguably in some accounts may differ from bubonic plague); that transference via fleas in goods was likely to be of marginal significance; and that the DNA results may be flawed and might not have been repeated elsewhere, despite extensive samples from other mass graves.
895	4139	A variety of alternatives to the Y. pestis have been put forward.
895	4140	Twigg suggested that the cause was a form of anthrax, and Norman Cantor (2001) thought it may have been a combination of anthrax and other pandemics.
895	4141	Scott and Duncan have argued that the pandemic was a form of infectious disease that characterise as hemorrhagic plague similar to Ebola.
895	4142	Archaeologist Barney Sloane has argued that there is insufficient evidence of the extinction of a large number of rats in the archaeological record of the medieval waterfront in London and that the plague spread too quickly to support the thesis that the Y. pestis was spread from fleas on rats; he argues that transmission must have been person to person.
895	4143	However, no single alternative solution has achieved widespread acceptance.
895	4144	Many scholars arguing for the Y. pestis as the major agent of the pandemic suggest that its extent and symptoms can be explained by a combination of bubonic plague with other diseases, including typhus, smallpox and respiratory infections.
895	4145	In addition to the bubonic infection, others point to additional septicemic (a type of "blood poisoning") and pneumonic (an airborne plague that attacks the lungs before the rest of the body) forms of the plague, which lengthen the duration of outbreaks throughout the seasons and help account for its high mortality rate and additional recorded symptoms.
895	4146	In 2014, scientists with Public Health England announced the results of an examination of 25 bodies exhumed from the Clerkenwell area of London, as well as of wills registered in London during the period, which supported the pneumonic hypothesis.
896	4147	The most widely accepted estimate for the Middle East, including Iraq, Iran and Syria, during this time, is for a death rate of about a third.
896	4148	The Black Death killed about 40% of Egypt's population.
896	4149	Half of Paris's population of 100,000 people died.
896	4150	In Italy, the population of Florence was reduced from 110–120 thousand inhabitants in 1338 down to 50 thousand in 1351.
896	4151	At least 60% of the population of Hamburg and Bremen perished, and a similar percentage of Londoners may have died from the disease as well.
896	4152	Interestingly while contemporary reports account of mass burial pits being created in response to the large numbers of dead, recent scientific investigations of a burial pit in Central London found well-preserved individuals to be buried in isolated, evenly spaced graves, suggesting at least some pre-planning and Christian burials at this time.
896	4153	Before 1350, there were about 170,000 settlements in Germany, and this was reduced by nearly 40,000 by 1450.
896	4154	In 1348, the plague spread so rapidly that before any physicians or government authorities had time to reflect upon its origins, about a third of the European population had already perished.
896	4155	In crowded cities, it was not uncommon for as much as 50% of the population to die.
896	4156	The disease bypassed some areas, and the most isolated areas were less vulnerable to contagion.
896	4157	Monks and priests were especially hard hit since they cared for victims of the Black Death.
897	4158	The plague repeatedly returned to haunt Europe and the Mediterranean throughout the 14th to 17th centuries.
897	4159	According to Biraben, the plague was present somewhere in Europe in every year between 1346 and 1671.
897	4160	The Second Pandemic was particularly widespread in the following years: 1360–63; 1374; 1400; 1438–39; 1456–57; 1464–66; 1481–85; 1500–03; 1518–31; 1544–48; 1563–66; 1573–88; 1596–99; 1602–11; 1623–40; 1644–54; and 1664–67.
897	4161	Subsequent outbreaks, though severe, marked the retreat from most of Europe (18th century) and northern Africa (19th century).
897	4162	According to Geoffrey Parker, "France alone lost almost a million people to the plague in the epidemic of 1628–31."
898	4163	In England, in the absence of census figures, historians propose a range of preincident population figures from as high as 7 million to as low as 4 million in 1300, and a postincident population figure as low as 2 million.
898	4164	By the end of 1350, the Black Death subsided, but it never really died out in England.
898	4165	Over the next few hundred years, further outbreaks occurred in 1361–62, 1369, 1379–83, 1389–93, and throughout the first half of the 15th century.
898	4166	An outbreak in 1471 took as much as 10–15% of the population, while the death rate of the plague of 1479–80 could have been as high as 20%.
898	4167	The most general outbreaks in Tudor and Stuart England seem to have begun in 1498, 1535, 1543, 1563, 1589, 1603, 1625, and 1636, and ended with the Great Plague of London in 1665.
899	4168	In 1466, perhaps 40,000 people died of the plague in Paris.
899	4169	During the 16th and 17th centuries, the plague was present in Paris around 30 per cent of the time.
899	4170	The Black Death ravaged Europe for three years before it continued on into Russia, where the disease was present somewhere in the country 25 times between 1350 to 1490.
899	4171	Plague epidemics ravaged London in 1563, 1593, 1603, 1625, 1636, and 1665, reducing its population by 10 to 30% during those years.
899	4172	Over 10% of Amsterdam's population died in 1623–25, and again in 1635–36, 1655, and 1664.
899	4173	Plague occurred in Venice 22 times between 1361 and 1528.
899	4174	The plague of 1576–77 killed 50,000 in Venice, almost a third of the population.
899	4175	Late outbreaks in central Europe included the Italian Plague of 1629–1631, which is associated with troop movements during the Thirty Years' War, and the Great Plague of Vienna in 1679.
899	4176	Over 60% of Norway's population died in 1348–50.
899	4177	The last plague outbreak ravaged Oslo in 1654.
900	4178	In the first half of the 17th century, a plague claimed some 1.7 million victims in Italy, or about 14% of the population.
900	4179	In 1656, the plague killed about half of Naples' 300,000 inhabitants.
900	4180	More than 1.25 million deaths resulted from the extreme incidence of plague in 17th-century Spain.
900	4181	The plague of 1649 probably reduced the population of Seville by half.
900	4182	In 1709–13, a plague epidemic that followed the Great Northern War (1700–21, Sweden v. Russia and allies) killed about 100,000 in Sweden, and 300,000 in Prussia.
900	4183	The plague killed two-thirds of the inhabitants of Helsinki, and claimed a third of Stockholm's population.
900	4184	Europe's last major epidemic occurred in 1720 in Marseille.
901	4185	The Black Death ravaged much of the Islamic world.
901	4186	Plague was present in at least one location in the Islamic world virtually every year between 1500 and 1850.
901	4187	Plague repeatedly struck the cities of North Africa.
901	4188	Algiers lost 30 to 50 thousand inhabitants to it in 1620–21, and again in 1654–57, 1665, 1691, and 1740–42.
901	4189	Plague remained a major event in Ottoman society until the second quarter of the 19th century.
901	4190	Between 1701 and 1750, thirty-seven larger and smaller epidemics were recorded in Constantinople, and an additional thirty-one between 1751 and 1800.
901	4191	Baghdad has suffered severely from visitations of the plague, and sometimes two-thirds of its population has been wiped out.
902	4192	There are three major types of rock: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic.
902	4193	The rock cycle is an important concept in geology which illustrates the relationships between these three types of rock, and magma.
902	4194	When a rock crystallizes from melt (magma and/or lava), it is an igneous rock.
902	4195	This rock can be weathered and eroded, and then redeposited and lithified into a sedimentary rock, or be turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure that change the mineral content of the rock which gives it a characteristic fabric.
902	4196	The sedimentary rock can then be subsequently turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure and is then weathered, eroded, deposited, and lithified, ultimately becoming a sedimentary rock.
902	4197	Sedimentary rock may also be re-eroded and redeposited, and metamorphic rock may also undergo additional metamorphism.
902	4198	All three types of rocks may be re-melted; when this happens, a new magma is formed, from which an igneous rock may once again crystallize.
903	4199	In the 1960s, a series of discoveries, the most important of which was seafloor spreading, showed that the Earth's lithosphere, which includes the crust and rigid uppermost portion of the upper mantle, is separated into a number of tectonic plates that move across the plastically deforming, solid, upper mantle, which is called the asthenosphere.
903	4200	There is an intimate coupling between the movement of the plates on the surface and the convection of the mantle: oceanic plate motions and mantle convection currents always move in the same direction, because the oceanic lithosphere is the rigid upper thermal boundary layer of the convecting mantle.
903	4201	This coupling between rigid plates moving on the surface of the Earth and the convecting mantle is called plate tectonics.
904	4202	The development of plate tectonics provided a physical basis for many observations of the solid Earth.
904	4203	Long linear regions of geologic features could be explained as plate boundaries.
904	4204	Mid-ocean ridges, high regions on the seafloor where hydrothermal vents and volcanoes exist, were explained as divergent boundaries, where two plates move apart.
904	4205	Arcs of volcanoes and earthquakes were explained as convergent boundaries, where one plate subducts under another.
904	4206	Transform boundaries, such as the San Andreas fault system, resulted in widespread powerful earthquakes.
904	4207	Plate tectonics also provided a mechanism for Alfred Wegener's theory of continental drift, in which the continents move across the surface of the Earth over geologic time.
904	4208	They also provided a driving force for crustal deformation, and a new setting for the observations of structural geology.
904	4209	The power of the theory of plate tectonics lies in its ability to combine all of these observations into a single theory of how the lithosphere moves over the convecting mantle.
905	4210	Seismologists can use the arrival times of seismic waves in reverse to image the interior of the Earth.
905	4211	Early advances in this field showed the existence of a liquid outer core (where shear waves were not able to propagate) and a dense solid inner core.
905	4212	These advances led to the development of a layered model of the Earth, with a crust and lithosphere on top, the mantle below (separated within itself by seismic discontinuities at 410 and 660 kilometers), and the outer core and inner core below that.
905	4213	More recently, seismologists have been able to create detailed images of wave speeds inside the earth in the same way a doctor images a body in a CT scan.
905	4214	These images have led to a much more detailed view of the interior of the Earth, and have replaced the simplified layered model with a much more dynamic model.
906	4215	The following four timelines show the geologic time scale.
906	4216	The first shows the entire time from the formation of the Earth to the present, but this compresses the most recent eon.
906	4217	Therefore, the second scale shows the most recent eon with an expanded scale.
906	4218	The second scale compresses the most recent era, so the most recent era is expanded in the third scale.
906	4219	Since the Quaternary is a very short period with short epochs, it is further expanded in the fourth scale.
906	4220	The second, third, and fourth timelines are therefore each subsections of their preceding timeline as indicated by asterisks.
906	4221	The Holocene (the latest epoch) is too small to be shown clearly on the third timeline on the right, another reason for expanding the fourth scale.
906	4222	Q stands for the Quaternary period.
907	4223	The principle of cross-cutting relationships pertains to the formation of faults and the age of the sequences through which they cut.
907	4224	Faults are younger than the rocks they cut; accordingly, if a fault is found that penetrates some formations but not those on top of it, then the formations that were cut are older than the fault, and the ones that are not cut must be younger than the fault.
907	4225	Finding the key bed in these situations may help determine whether the fault is a normal fault or a thrust fault.
908	4226	The principle of inclusions and components states that, with sedimentary rocks, if inclusions (or clasts) are found in a formation, then the inclusions must be older than the formation that contains them.
908	4227	For example, in sedimentary rocks, it is common for gravel from an older formation to be ripped up and included in a newer layer.
908	4228	A similar situation with igneous rocks occurs when xenoliths are found.
908	4229	These foreign bodies are picked up as magma or lava flows, and are incorporated, later to cool in the matrix.
908	4230	As a result, xenoliths are older than the rock which contains them.
909	4231	The principle of faunal succession is based on the appearance of fossils in sedimentary rocks.
909	4232	As organisms exist at the same time period throughout the world, their presence or (sometimes) absence may be used to provide a relative age of the formations in which they are found.
909	4233	Based on principles laid out by William Smith almost a hundred years before the publication of Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, the principles of succession were developed independently of evolutionary thought.
909	4234	The principle becomes quite complex, however, given the uncertainties of fossilization, the localization of fossil types due to lateral changes in habitat (facies change in sedimentary strata), and that not all fossils may be found globally at the same time.
910	4235	At the beginning of the 20th century, important advancement in geological science was facilitated by the ability to obtain accurate absolute dates to geologic events using radioactive isotopes and other methods.
910	4236	This changed the understanding of geologic time.
910	4237	Previously, geologists could only use fossils and stratigraphic correlation to date sections of rock relative to one another.
910	4238	With isotopic dates it became possible to assign absolute ages to rock units, and these absolute dates could be applied to fossil sequences in which there was datable material, converting the old relative ages into new absolute ages.
911	4239	For many geologic applications, isotope ratios of radioactive elements are measured in minerals that give the amount of time that has passed since a rock passed through its particular closure temperature, the point at which different radiometric isotopes stop diffusing into and out of the crystal lattice.
911	4240	These are used in geochronologic and thermochronologic studies.
911	4241	Common methods include uranium-lead dating, potassium-argon dating, argon-argon dating and uranium-thorium dating.
911	4242	These methods are used for a variety of applications.
911	4243	Dating of lava and volcanic ash layers found within a stratigraphic sequence can provide absolute age data for sedimentary rock units which do not contain radioactive isotopes and calibrate relative dating techniques.
911	4244	These methods can also be used to determine ages of pluton emplacement.
911	4245	Thermochemical techniques can be used to determine temperature profiles within the crust, the uplift of mountain ranges, and paleotopography.
912	4246	When rock units are placed under horizontal compression, they shorten and become thicker.
912	4247	Because rock units, other than muds, do not significantly change in volume, this is accomplished in two primary ways: through faulting and folding.
912	4248	In the shallow crust, where brittle deformation can occur, thrust faults form, which cause deeper rock to move on top of shallower rock.
912	4249	Because deeper rock is often older, as noted by the principle of superposition, this can result in older rocks moving on top of younger ones.
912	4250	Movement along faults can result in folding, either because the faults are not planar or because rock layers are dragged along, forming drag folds as slip occurs along the fault.
912	4251	Deeper in the Earth, rocks behave plastically, and fold instead of faulting.
912	4252	These folds can either be those where the material in the center of the fold buckles upwards, creating "antiforms", or where it buckles downwards, creating "synforms".
912	4253	If the tops of the rock units within the folds remain pointing upwards, they are called anticlines and synclines, respectively.
912	4254	If some of the units in the fold are facing downward, the structure is called an overturned anticline or syncline, and if all of the rock units are overturned or the correct up-direction is unknown, they are simply called by the most general terms, antiforms and synforms.
913	4255	Extension causes the rock units as a whole to become longer and thinner.
913	4256	This is primarily accomplished through normal faulting and through the ductile stretching and thinning.
913	4257	Normal faults drop rock units that are higher below those that are lower.
913	4258	This typically results in younger units being placed below older units.
913	4259	Stretching of units can result in their thinning; in fact, there is a location within the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt in which the entire sedimentary sequence of the Grand Canyon can be seen over a length of less than a meter.
913	4260	Rocks at the depth to be ductilely stretched are often also metamorphosed.
913	4261	These stretched rocks can also pinch into lenses, known as boudins, after the French word for "sausage", because of their visual similarity.
914	4262	The addition of new rock units, both depositionally and intrusively, often occurs during deformation.
914	4263	Faulting and other deformational processes result in the creation of topographic gradients, causing material on the rock unit that is increasing in elevation to be eroded by hillslopes and channels.
914	4264	These sediments are deposited on the rock unit that is going down.
914	4265	Continual motion along the fault maintains the topographic gradient in spite of the movement of sediment, and continues to create accommodation space for the material to deposit.
914	4266	Deformational events are often also associated with volcanism and igneous activity.
914	4267	Volcanic ashes and lavas accumulate on the surface, and igneous intrusions enter from below.
914	4268	Dikes, long, planar igneous intrusions, enter along cracks, and therefore often form in large numbers in areas that are being actively deformed.
914	4269	This can result in the emplacement of dike swarms, such as those that are observable across the Canadian shield, or rings of dikes around the lava tube of a volcano.
915	4270	All of these processes do not necessarily occur in a single environment, and do not necessarily occur in a single order.
915	4271	The Hawaiian Islands, for example, consist almost entirely of layered basaltic lava flows.
915	4272	The sedimentary sequences of the mid-continental United States and the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States contain almost-undeformed stacks of sedimentary rocks that have remained in place since Cambrian time.
915	4273	Other areas are much more geologically complex.
915	4274	In the southwestern United States, sedimentary, volcanic, and intrusive rocks have been metamorphosed, faulted, foliated, and folded.
915	4275	Even older rocks, such as the Acasta gneiss of the Slave craton in northwestern Canada, the oldest known rock in the world have been metamorphosed to the point where their origin is undiscernable without laboratory analysis.
915	4276	In addition, these processes can occur in stages.
915	4277	In many places, the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States being a very visible example, the lower rock units were metamorphosed and deformed, and then deformation ended and the upper, undeformed units were deposited.
915	4278	Although any amount of rock emplacement and rock deformation can occur, and they can occur any number of times, these concepts provide a guide to understanding the geological history of an area.
916	4279	Geologists use a number of field, laboratory, and numerical modeling methods to decipher Earth history and understand the processes that occur on and inside the Earth.
916	4280	In typical geological investigations, geologists use primary information related to petrology (the study of rocks), stratigraphy (the study of sedimentary layers), and structural geology (the study of positions of rock units and their deformation).
916	4281	In many cases, geologists also study modern soils, rivers, landscapes, and glaciers; investigate past and current life and biogeochemical pathways, and use geophysical methods to investigate the subsurface.
917	4282	In addition to identifying rocks in the field, petrologists identify rock samples in the laboratory.
917	4283	Two of the primary methods for identifying rocks in the laboratory are through optical microscopy and by using an electron microprobe.
917	4284	In an optical mineralogy analysis, thin sections of rock samples are analyzed through a petrographic microscope, where the minerals can be identified through their different properties in plane-polarized and cross-polarized light, including their birefringence, pleochroism, twinning, and interference properties with a conoscopic lens.
917	4285	In the electron microprobe, individual locations are analyzed for their exact chemical compositions and variation in composition within individual crystals.
917	4286	Stable and radioactive isotope studies provide insight into the geochemical evolution of rock units.
918	4287	Petrologists can also use fluid inclusion data and perform high temperature and pressure physical experiments to understand the temperatures and pressures at which different mineral phases appear, and how they change through igneous and metamorphic processes.
918	4288	This research can be extrapolated to the field to understand metamorphic processes and the conditions of crystallization of igneous rocks.
918	4289	This work can also help to explain processes that occur within the Earth, such as subduction and magma chamber evolution.
919	4290	Structural geologists use microscopic analysis of oriented thin sections of geologic samples to observe the fabric within the rocks which gives information about strain within the crystalline structure of the rocks.
919	4291	They also plot and combine measurements of geological structures in order to better understand the orientations of faults and folds in order to reconstruct the history of rock deformation in the area.
919	4292	In addition, they perform analog and numerical experiments of rock deformation in large and small settings.
920	4293	Among the most well-known experiments in structural geology are those involving orogenic wedges, which are zones in which mountains are built along convergent tectonic plate boundaries.
920	4294	In the analog versions of these experiments, horizontal layers of sand are pulled along a lower surface into a back stop, which results in realistic-looking patterns of faulting and the growth of a critically tapered (all angles remain the same) orogenic wedge.
920	4295	Numerical models work in the same way as these analog models, though they are often more sophisticated and can include patterns of erosion and uplift in the mountain belt.
920	4296	This helps to show the relationship between erosion and the shape of the mountain range.
920	4297	These studies can also give useful information about pathways for metamorphism through pressure, temperature, space, and time.
921	4298	In the laboratory, stratigraphers analyze samples of stratigraphic sections that can be returned from the field, such as those from drill cores.
921	4299	Stratigraphers also analyze data from geophysical surveys that show the locations of stratigraphic units in the subsurface.
921	4300	Geophysical data and well logs can be combined to produce a better view of the subsurface, and stratigraphers often use computer programs to do this in three dimensions.
921	4301	Stratigraphers can then use these data to reconstruct ancient processes occurring on the surface of the Earth, interpret past environments, and locate areas for water, coal, and hydrocarbon extraction.
922	4302	In the laboratory, biostratigraphers analyze rock samples from outcrop and drill cores for the fossils found in them.
922	4303	These fossils help scientists to date the core and to understand the depositional environment in which the rock units formed.
922	4304	Geochronologists precisely date rocks within the stratigraphic section in order to provide better absolute bounds on the timing and rates of deposition.
922	4305	Magnetic stratigraphers look for signs of magnetic reversals in igneous rock units within the drill cores.
922	4306	Other scientists perform stable isotope studies on the rocks to gain information about past climate.
923	4307	Some modern scholars, such as Fielding H. Garrison, are of the opinion that the origin of the science of geology can be traced to Persia after the Muslim conquests had come to an end.
923	4308	Abu al-Rayhan al-Biruni (973–1048 CE) was one of the earliest Persian geologists, whose works included the earliest writings on the geology of India, hypothesizing that the Indian subcontinent was once a sea.
923	4309	Drawing from Greek and Indian scientific literature that were not destroyed by the Muslim conquests, the Persian scholar Ibn Sina (Avicenna, 981–1037) proposed detailed explanations for the formation of mountains, the origin of earthquakes, and other topics central to modern geology, which provided an essential foundation for the later development of the science.
923	4310	In China, the polymath Shen Kuo (1031–1095) formulated a hypothesis for the process of land formation: based on his observation of fossil animal shells in a geological stratum in a mountain hundreds of miles from the ocean, he inferred that the land was formed by erosion of the mountains and by deposition of silt.
924	4311	James Hutton is often viewed as the first modern geologist.
924	4312	In 1785 he presented a paper entitled Theory of the Earth to the Royal Society of Edinburgh.
924	4313	In his paper, he explained his theory that the Earth must be much older than had previously been supposed in order to allow enough time for mountains to be eroded and for sediments to form new rocks at the bottom of the sea, which in turn were raised up to become dry land.
924	4314	Hutton published a two-volume version of his ideas in 1795 (Vol.
925	4315	The first geological map of the U.S. was produced in 1809 by William Maclure.
925	4316	In 1807, Maclure commenced the self-imposed task of making a geological survey of the United States.
925	4317	Almost every state in the Union was traversed and mapped by him, the Allegheny Mountains being crossed and recrossed some 50 times.
925	4318	The results of his unaided labours were submitted to the American Philosophical Society in a memoir entitled Observations on the Geology of the United States explanatory of a Geological Map, and published in the Society's Transactions, together with the nation's first geological map.
925	4319	This antedates William Smith's geological map of England by six years, although it was constructed using a different classification of rocks.
926	4320	Sir Charles Lyell first published his famous book, Principles of Geology, in 1830.
926	4321	This book, which influenced the thought of Charles Darwin, successfully promoted the doctrine of uniformitarianism.
926	4322	This theory states that slow geological processes have occurred throughout the Earth's history and are still occurring today.
926	4323	In contrast, catastrophism is the theory that Earth's features formed in single, catastrophic events and remained unchanged thereafter.
926	4324	Though Hutton believed in uniformitarianism, the idea was not widely accepted at the time.
927	4325	Newcastle upon Tyne (RP: i/ˌnjuːkɑːsəl əˌpɒn ˈtaɪn/; Locally: i/njuːˌkæsəl əˌpən ˈtaɪn/), commonly known as Newcastle, is a city in Tyne and Wear, North East England, 103 miles (166 km) south of Edinburgh and 277 miles (446 km) north of London on the northern bank of the River Tyne, 8.5 mi (13.7 km) from the North Sea.
927	4326	Newcastle is the most populous city in the North East and Tyneside the eighth most populous conurbation in the United Kingdom.
927	4327	Newcastle is a member of the English Core Cities Group and is a member of the Eurocities network of European cities.
927	4328	Newcastle was part of the county of Northumberland until 1400, when it became a county itself, a status it retained until becoming part of Tyne and Wear in 1974.
927	4329	[not in citation given] The regional nickname and dialect for people from Newcastle and the surrounding area is Geordie.
928	4330	The city developed around the Roman settlement Pons Aelius and was named after the castle built in 1080 by Robert Curthose, William the Conqueror's eldest son.
928	4331	The city grew as an important centre for the wool trade in the 14th century, and later became a major coal mining area.
928	4332	The port developed in the 16th century and, along with the shipyards lower down the River Tyne, was amongst the world's largest shipbuilding and ship-repairing centres.
928	4333	Newcastle's economy includes corporate headquarters, learning, digital technology, retail, tourism and cultural centres, from which the city contributes £13 billion towards the United Kingdom's GVA.
928	4334	Among its icons are Newcastle Brown Ale; Newcastle United football club; and the Tyne Bridge.
928	4335	It has hosted the world's most popular half marathon, the Great North Run, since it began in 1981.
929	4336	The first recorded settlement in what is now Newcastle was Pons Aelius, a Roman fort and bridge across the River Tyne.
929	4337	It was given the family name of the Roman Emperor Hadrian, who founded it in the 2nd century AD.
929	4338	This rare honour suggests that Hadrian may have visited the site and instituted the bridge on his tour of Britain.
929	4339	The population of Pons Aelius at this period was estimated at 2,000.
929	4340	Fragments of Hadrian's Wall are still visible in parts of Newcastle, particularly along the West Road.
929	4341	The course of the "Roman Wall" can be traced eastwards to the Segedunum Roman fort in Wallsend—the "wall's end"—and to the supply fort Arbeia in South Shields.
929	4342	The extent of Hadrian's Wall was 73 miles (117 km), spanning the width of Britain; the Wall incorporated the Vallum, a large rearward ditch with parallel mounds, and was constructed primarily for defence, to prevent unwanted immigration and the incursion of Pictish tribes from the north, not as a fighting line for a major invasion.
930	4343	Throughout the Middle Ages, Newcastle was England's northern fortress.
930	4344	Incorporated first by Henry II, the city had a new charter granted by Elizabeth in 1589.
930	4345	A 25-foot (7.6 m) high stone wall was built around the town in the 13th century, to defend it from invaders during the Border war against Scotland.
930	4346	The Scots king William the Lion was imprisoned in Newcastle in 1174, and Edward I brought the Stone of Scone and William Wallace south through the town.
930	4347	Newcastle was successfully defended against the Scots three times during the 14th century, and was created a county corporate with its own sheriff by Henry IV in 1400.
931	4348	From 1530 a royal act restricted all shipments of coal from Tyneside to Newcastle Quayside, giving a monopoly in the coal trade to a cartel of Newcastle burgesses known as the Hostmen.
931	4349	This monopoly, which lasted for a considerable time, helped Newcastle prosper and develop into a major town.
931	4350	The phrase taking coals to Newcastle was first recorded contextually in 1538.
931	4351	The phrase itself means a pointless pursuit.
931	4352	In the 18th century American Timothy Dexter, an entrepreneur, widely regarded as an eccentric, defied this idiom.
931	4353	He was persuaded to sail a shipment of coal to Newcastle by merchants plotting to ruin him; however his shipment arrived on the Tyne during a strike that had crippled local production; unexpectedly he made a considerable profit.
932	4354	In the Sandgate area, to the east of the city and beside the river, resided the close-knit community of keelmen and their families.
932	4355	They were so called because they worked on the keels, boats that were used to transfer coal from the river banks to the waiting colliers, for export to London and elsewhere.
932	4356	In the 1630s about 7,000 out of 20,000 inhabitants of Newcastle died of plague, more than one-third of the population.
932	4357	Specifically within the year 1636, it is roughly estimated with evidence held by the Society of Antiquaries that 47% of the then population of Newcastle died from the epidemic; this may also have been the most devastating loss in any British City in this period.
933	4358	During the English Civil War, the North declared for the King.
933	4359	In a bid to gain Newcastle and the Tyne, Cromwell's allies, the Scots, captured the town of Newburn.
933	4360	In 1644 the Scots then captured the reinforced fortification on the Lawe in South Shields following a siege.
933	4361	In 1644 the city was then besieged for many months and was eventually stormed ('with roaring drummes') and sacked by Cromwell's allies.
933	4362	The grateful King bestowed the motto "Fortiter Defendit Triumphans" ("Triumphing by a brave defence") upon the town.
933	4363	Charles I was imprisoned in Newcastle by the Scots in 1646–7.
934	4364	In the 19th century, shipbuilding and heavy engineering were central to the city's prosperity; and the city was a powerhouse of the Industrial Revolution.
934	4365	This revolution resulted in the urbanization of the city.
934	4366	In 1817 the Maling company, at one time the largest pottery company in the world, moved to the city.
934	4367	The Victorian industrial revolution brought industrial structures that included the 2 1⁄2-mile (4.0 km) Victoria Tunnelling, built in 1842, which provided underground wagon ways to the staithes.
934	4368	On 3 February 1879, Mosley Street in the city, was the first public road in the world to be lit up by the incandescent lightbulb.
934	4369	Newcastle was one of the first cities in the world to be lit up by electric lighting.
934	4370	Innovations in Newcastle and surrounding areas included the development of safety lamps, Stephenson's Rocket, Lord Armstrong's artillery, Be-Ro flour, Joseph Swan's electric light bulbs, and Charles Parsons' invention of the steam turbine, which led to the revolution of marine propulsion and the production of cheap electricity.
934	4371	In 1882, Newcastle became the seat of an Anglican diocese, with St. Nicholas' Church becoming its cathedral.
935	4372	In large parts, Newcastle still retains a medieval street layout.
935	4373	Narrow alleys or 'chares', most of which can only be traversed by foot, still exist in abundance, particularly around the riverside.
935	4374	Stairs from the riverside to higher parts of the city centre and the extant Castle Keep, originally recorded in the 14th century, remain intact in places.
935	4375	Close, Sandhill and Quayside contain modern buildings as well as structures dating from the 15th–18th centuries, including Bessie Surtees House, the Cooperage and Lloyds Quayside Bars, Derwentwater House and "House of Tides", a restaurant situated at a Grade I-listed 16th century merchant's house at 28–30 Close.
936	4376	The city has an extensive neoclassical centre referred to as Tyneside Classical largely developed in the 1830s by Richard Grainger and John Dobson, and recently extensively restored.
936	4377	Broadcaster and writer Stuart Maconie described Newcastle as England's best-looking city and the late German-born British scholar of architecture, Nikolaus Pevsner, describes Grey Street as one of the finest streets in England.
936	4378	The street curves down from Grey's Monument towards the valley of the River Tyne and was voted England's finest street in 2005 in a survey of BBC Radio 4 listeners.
936	4379	In the Google Street View awards of 2010, Grey Street came 3rd in the British picturesque category.
936	4380	Osborne Road came 4th in the foodie street category.
936	4381	A portion of Grainger Town was demolished in the 1960s to make way for the Eldon Square Shopping Centre, including all but one side of the original Eldon Square itself.
937	4382	Another green space in Newcastle is the Town Moor, lying immediately north of the city centre.
937	4383	It is larger than London's famous Hyde Park and Hampstead Heath put together and the freemen of the city have the right to graze cattle on it.
937	4384	The right incidentally extends to the pitch of St. James' Park, Newcastle United Football Club's ground, though this is not exercised, although the Freemen do collect rent for the loss of privilege.
937	4385	Honorary freemen include Bob Geldof, King Harald V of Norway, Bobby Robson, Alan Shearer, the late Nelson Mandela and the Royal Shakespeare Company.
937	4386	The Hoppings funfair, said to be the largest travelling funfair in Europe, is held here annually in June.
938	4387	Large-scale regeneration has replaced former shipping premises with imposing new office developments; an innovative tilting bridge, the Gateshead Millennium Bridge was commissioned by Gateshead Council and has integrated the older Newcastle Quayside more closely with major cultural developments in Gateshead, including the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art, the venue for the Turner Prize 2011 and the Norman Foster-designed The Sage Gateshead music centre.
938	4388	The Newcastle and Gateshead Quaysides are now a thriving, cosmopolitan area with bars, restaurants and public spaces.
938	4389	As a tourist promotion, Newcastle and Gateshead have linked together under the banner "NewcastleGateshead", to spearhead the regeneration of the North-East.
938	4390	The River Tyne had the temporary Bambuco Bridge in 2008 for ten days; it was not made for walking, road or cycling, but was just a sculpture.
939	4391	The historic heart of Newcastle is the Grainger Town area.
939	4392	Established on classical streets built by Richard Grainger, a builder and developer, between 1835 and 1842, some of Newcastle upon Tyne's finest buildings and streets lie within this area of the city centre including Grainger Market, Theatre Royal, Grey Street, Grainger Street and Clayton Street.
939	4393	These buildings are predominantly four stories high, with vertical dormers, domes, turrets and spikes.
939	4394	Richard Grainger was said to 'have found Newcastle of bricks and timber and left it in stone'.
939	4395	Of Grainger Town's 450 buildings, 244 are listed, of which 29 are grade I and 49 are grade II*.
940	4396	The Grainger Market replaced an earlier market originally built in 1808 called the Butcher Market.
940	4397	The Grainger Market itself, was opened in 1835 and was Newcastle's first indoor market.
940	4398	At the time of its opening in 1835 it was said to be one of the largest and most beautiful markets in Europe.
940	4399	The opening was celebrated with a grand dinner attended by 2000 guests, and the Laing Art Gallery has a painting of this event.
940	4400	With the exception of the timber roof which was destroyed by a fire in 1901 and replaced by latticed-steel arches the Market is largely in its original condition.
940	4401	The Grainger Market architecture, like most in Grainger Town, which are either grade I or II listed, was listed grade I in 1954 by English Heritage.
941	4402	The climate in Newcastle is oceanic (Köppen Cfb) and significantly milder than some other locations in the world at a similar latitude, due to the warming influence of the Gulf Stream (via the North Atlantic Drift).
941	4403	Being in the rain shadow of the North Pennines, it is among the driest cities in the UK.
941	4404	Temperature extremes recorded at Newcastle Weather Centre include 32.5 °C (90.5 °F) during August 1990 down to −12.6 °C (9.3 °F) during January 1982.
941	4405	In contrast to other areas influenced by the Gulf Stream, such as inland Scandinavia, Newcastle has milder winters and cooler summers, similar to the remainder of the British Isles.
942	4406	In 2010, Newcastle was positioned ninth in the retail centre expenditure league of the UK.
942	4407	There are several major shopping areas in Newcastle City Centre.
942	4408	The largest of these is the Eldon Square Shopping Centre, one of the largest city centre shopping complexes in the UK.
942	4409	It incorporates a flagship Debenhams store as well as one of the largest John Lewis stores in the UK.
942	4410	John Lewis is still known to many in Newcastle as Bainbridges.
942	4411	Newcastle store Bainbridge's, opened in 1838, is often cited as the world’s first department store.
942	4412	Emerson Bainbridge (1817–1892), a pioneer and the founder of Bainbridges, sold goods via department, a new for merchant custom for that time.
942	4413	The Bainbridge’s official ledgers reported revenue by department, giving birth to the name department store.
942	4414	Eldon Square is currently undergoing a full redevelopment.
942	4415	A new bus station, replacing the old underground bus station, was officially opened in March 2007.
942	4416	The wing of the centre, including the undercover Green Market, near Grainger Street was demolished in 2007 so that the area could be redeveloped.
942	4417	This was completed in February 2010 with the opening of a flagship Debenhams department store as well as other major stores including Apple, Hollister and Guess.
943	4418	Other shopping destinations in Newcastle include Grainger Street and the area around Grey's Monument, the relatively modern Eldon Garden and Monument Mall complexes, the Newgate Centre, Central Arcade and the traditional Grainger Market.
943	4419	Outside the city centre, the largest suburban shopping areas are Gosforth and Byker.
943	4420	The largest Tesco store in the United Kingdom is located in Kingston Park on the edge of Newcastle.
943	4421	Close to Newcastle, the largest indoor shopping centre in Europe, the MetroCentre, is located in Gateshead.
944	4422	The Tyneside flat was the dominant housing form constructed at the time when the industrial centres on Tyneside were growing most rapidly.
944	4423	They can still be found in areas such as South Heaton in Newcastle but once dominated the streetscape on both sides of the Tyne.
944	4424	Tyneside flats were built as terraces, one of each pair of doors led to an upstairs flat while the other led into the ground-floor flat, each of two or three rooms.
944	4425	A new development in the Ouseburn valley has recreated them; Architects Cany Ash and Robert Sakula were attracted by the possibilities of high density without building high and getting rid of common areas.
946	4426	According to the UK Government's returned 2001 census information, the city of Newcastle had a population of 189,863, whereas the metropolitan borough of Newcastle had a population of around 259,000.
946	4427	Newcastle has a population of 282,442 according to the Office for National Statistics.
946	4428	The metropolitan boroughs of North Tyneside (population circa 201,000), South Tyneside (population circa 148,000) and Gateshead (population circa 201,000) are, along with Newcastle, all part of the Tyneside conurbation (population circa 880,000).
946	4429	The metropolitan county of Tyne and Wear, which consists of the four aforementioned boroughs as well as the City of Sunderland (population circa 275,000), had a population of around 1,076,000 and the Tyne and Wear City Region which also includes North Durham, South East Northumberland and the Tyne Valley has a population of 1,650,000.
946	4430	Newcastle is also home to a large student population with Newcastle and Northumbria Universities in the local area.
946	4431	Areas with predominant student populations include Jesmond and Heaton.
947	4432	According to the same statistics, the average age of people living in Newcastle is 37.8 (the national average being 38.6).
947	4433	Many people in the city have Scottish or Irish ancestors.
947	4434	There is a strong presence of Border Reiver surnames, such as Armstrong, Charlton, Elliot, Johnstone, Kerr, Hall, Nixon, Little and Robson.
947	4435	There are also small but significant Chinese, Jewish and Eastern European (Polish, Czech Roma) populations.
947	4436	There are also estimated to be between 500 and 2,000 Bolivians in Newcastle, forming up to 1% of the population—the largest such percentage of any UK city.
948	4437	The dialect of Newcastle is known as Geordie, and contains a large amount of vocabulary and distinctive word pronunciations not used in other parts of the United Kingdom.
948	4438	The Geordie dialect has much of its origins in the language spoken by the Anglo-Saxon populations who migrated to and conquered much of England after the end of Roman Imperial rule.
948	4439	This language was the forerunner of Modern English; but while the dialects of other English regions have been heavily altered by the influences of other foreign languages—particularly Latin and Norman French—the Geordie dialect retains many elements of the old language.
948	4440	An example of this is the pronunciation of certain words: "dead", "cow", "house" and "strong" are pronounced "deed", "coo", "hoos" and "strang"—which is how they were pronounced in the Anglo-Saxon language.
948	4441	Other Geordie words with Anglo-Saxon origins include: "larn" (from the Anglo-Saxon "laeran", meaning "teach"), "burn" ("stream") and "gan" ("go").
949	4442	"Bairn" and "hyem", meaning "child" and "home", respectively, are examples of Geordie words with origins in Scandinavia; barn and hjem are the corresponding modern Norwegian and Danish words.
949	4443	Some words used in the Geordie dialect are used elsewhere in the Northern United Kingdom.
949	4444	The words "bonny" (meaning "pretty"), "howay" ("come on"), "stot" ("bounce") and "hadaway" ("go away" or "you're kidding"), all appear to be used in Scots; "aye" ("yes") and "nowt" (IPA://naʊt/, rhymes with out,"nothing") are used elsewhere in Northern England.
949	4445	Many words, however, appear to be used exclusively in Newcastle and the surrounding area, such as "Canny" (a versatile word meaning "good", "nice" or "very"), "hacky" ("dirty"), "netty" ("toilet"), "hoy" ("throw", from the Dutch gooien, via West Frisian), "hockle" ("spit").
950	4446	In a report, published in early February 2007 by the Ear Institute at the University College London, and Widex, a Danish hearing aid manufacturer, Newcastle was named as the noisiest city in the whole of the UK, with an average level of 80.4 decibels.
950	4447	The report claimed that these noise levels would have a negative long-term impact on the health of the city's residents.
950	4448	The report was criticized, however, for attaching too much weight to readings at arbitrarily selected locations, which in Newcastle's case included a motorway underpass without pedestrian access.
951	4449	There are concentrations of pubs, bars and nightclubs around the Bigg Market and the Quayside area of the city centre.
951	4450	There are many bars on the Bigg Market, and other popular areas for nightlife are Collingwood Street, popularly referred to as the 'Diamond Strip' due to its concentration of high-end bars, Neville Street, the Central Station area and Osborne Road in the Jesmond area of the city.
951	4451	In recent years "The Gate" has opened in the city centre, a new indoor complex consisting of bars, upmarket clubs, restaurants and a 12-screen Empire multiplex cinema.
951	4452	Newcastle's gay scene - 'The Pink Triangle' - is centred on the Times Square area near the Centre for Life and has a range of bars, cafés and clubs.
952	4453	The city has a proud history of theatre.
952	4454	Stephen Kemble of the famous Kemble family successfully managed the original Theatre Royal, Newcastle for fifteen years (1791–1806).
952	4455	He brought members of his famous acting family such as Sarah Siddons and John Kemble out of London to Newcastle.
952	4456	Stephen Kemble guided the theatre through many celebrated seasons.
952	4457	The original Theatre Royal in Newcastle was opened on 21 January 1788 and was located on Mosley Street.
952	4458	It was demolished to make way for Grey Street, where its replacement was built.
953	4459	The city still contains many theatres.
953	4460	The largest, the Theatre Royal on Grey Street, first opened in 1837, designed by John and Benjamin Green.
953	4461	It has hosted a season of performances from the Royal Shakespeare Company for over 25 years, as well as touring productions of West End musicals.
953	4462	The Mill Volvo Tyne Theatre hosts smaller touring productions, whilst other venues feature local talent.
953	4463	Northern Stage, formally known as the Newcastle Playhouse and Gulbenkian Studio, hosts various local, national and international productions in addition to those produced by the Northern Stage company.
953	4464	Other theatres in the city include the Live Theatre, the People's Theatre and the Jubilee Theatre.
953	4465	NewcastleGateshead was voted in 2006 as the arts capital of the UK in a survey conducted by the Artsworld TV channel.
954	4466	The Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne (popularly known as the 'Lit & Phil') is the largest independent library outside London, housing more than 150,000 books.
954	4467	Its music library contains 8000 CDs and 10,000 LPs.
954	4468	The current Lit and Phil premises were built in 1825 and the building was designed by John and Benjamin Green.
954	4469	Operating since 1793 and founded as a ‘conversation club,’ its lecture theatre was the first public building to be lit by electric light, during a lecture by Joseph Swan on 20 October 1880.
955	4470	The Newcastle Beer Festival, organized by CAMRA, takes place in April.
955	4471	In May, Newcastle and Gateshead host the Evolution Festival, a music festival held on the Newcastle and Gateshead Quaysides over the Spring bank holiday, with performances by acts from the world of Rock, Indie and Dance music.
955	4472	The biennial AV Festival of international electronic art, featuring exhibitions, concerts, conferences and film screenings, is held in March.
955	4473	The North East Art Expo, a festival of art and design from the regions professional artists, is held in late May.
955	4474	NewcastleGateshead, a festival of food and drink, runs for 2 weeks each year in mid June.
956	4475	The Hoppings, reputedly the largest travelling fair in Europe, takes place on Newcastle Town Moor every June.
956	4476	The event has its origins in the Temperance Movement during the early 1880s and coincides with the annual race week at High Gosforth Park.
956	4477	Newcastle Community Green Festival, which claims to be the UK's biggest free community environmental festival, also takes place every June, in Leazes Park.
956	4478	The Northern Rock Cyclone, a cycling festival, takes place within, or starting from, Newcastle in June.
956	4479	The Northern Pride Festival and Parade is held in Leazes Park and in the city's Gay Community in mid July.
956	4480	The Ouseburn Festival, a family oriented weekend festival near the city centre, incorporating a "Family Fun Day" and "Carnival Day", is held in late July.
957	4481	Newcastle Mela, held on the late August bank holiday weekend, is an annual two-day multicultural event, blending drama, music and food from Punjabi, Pakistani, Bengali and Hindu cultures.
957	4482	NewcastleGateshead also holds an annual International Arts Fair.
957	4483	The 2009 event will be in the Norman Foster designed Sage Gateshead Music and Arts Centre in September.
957	4484	In October, there is the Design Event festival—an annual festival providing the public with an opportunity to see work by regional, national and international designers.
957	4485	The SAMA Festival, an East Asian cultural festival is also held in early October.
958	4486	Lindisfarne are a folk-rock group with a strong Tyneside connection.
958	4487	Their most famous song, "Fog on the Tyne" (1971), was covered by Geordie ex-footballer Paul Gascoigne in 1990.
958	4488	Venom, reckoned by many to be the originators of black metal and extremely influential to the extreme metal scene as a whole, formed in Newcastle in 1979.
958	4489	Folk metal band Skyclad, often regarded as the first folk metal band, also formed in Newcastle after the break-up of Martin Walkyier thrash metal band, Sabbat.
958	4490	Andy Taylor, former lead guitarist of Duran Duran was born here in 1961.
958	4491	Brian Johnson was a member of local rock band Geordie before becoming the lead vocalist of AC/DC.
959	4492	The Pilgrim Street building was refurbished between November 2006 and May 2008; during the refurbishment works, the cinema relocated to the Old Town Hall, Gateshead.
959	4493	In May 2008 the Tyneside Cinema reopened in the restored and refurbished original building.
959	4494	The site currently houses three cinemas, including the restored Classic —the United Kingdom's last surviving news cinema still in full-time operation—alongside two new screens, a roof extension containing the Tyneside Bar, and dedicated education and teaching suites.
960	4495	There are several museums and galleries in Newcastle, including the Centre for Life with its Science Village; the Discovery Museum a museum highlighting life on Tyneside, including Tyneside's shipbuilding heritage, and inventions which changed the world; the Great North Museum; in 2009 the Newcastle on Tyne Museum of Antiquities merged with the Great North Museum (Hancock Museum); Seven Stories a museum dedicated to children's books, the Side Gallery historical and contemporary photography from around the world and Northern England and the Newburn Hall Motor Museum.
961	4496	The earliest known movie featuring some exterior scenes filmed in the city is On the Night of the Fire (1939), though by and large the action is studio-bound.
961	4497	Later came The Clouded Yellow (1951) and Payroll (1961), both of which feature more extensive scenes filmed in the city.
961	4498	The 1971 film Get Carter was shot on location in and around Newcastle and offers an opportunity to see what Newcastle looked like in the 1960s and early 1970s.
961	4499	The city was also backdrop to another gangster film, the 1988 film noir thriller Stormy Monday, directed by Mike Figgis and starring Tommy Lee Jones, Melanie Griffith, Sting and Sean Bean.
962	4500	Newcastle has a horse racing course at Gosforth Park.
962	4501	The city is also home to the Newcastle Eagles basketball team who play their home games at the new Sport Central complex at Northumbria University.
962	4502	The Eagles are the most successful team in the history of the British Basketball League (BBL).
962	4503	The city's speedway team Newcastle Diamonds are based at Brough Park in Byker, a venue that is also home to greyhound racing.
962	4504	Newcastle also hosts the start of the annual Great North Run, the world's largest half-marathon in which participants race over the Tyne Bridge into Gateshead and then towards the finish line 13.1 miles (21.1 km) away on the coast at South Shields.
962	4505	Another famous athletic event is the 5.9-mile (9.5 km) Blaydon Race (a road race from Newcastle to Blaydon), which has taken place on 9 June annually since 1981, to commemorate the celebrated Blaydon Races horse racing.
963	4506	Newcastle International Airport is located approximately 6 miles (9.7 km) from the city centre on the northern outskirts of the city near Ponteland and is the larger of the two main airports serving the North East.
963	4507	It is connected to the city via the Metro Light Rail system and a journey into Newcastle city centre takes approximately 20 minutes.
963	4508	The airport handles over five million passengers per year, and is the tenth largest, and the fastest growing regional airport in the UK, expecting to reach 10 million passengers by 2016, and 15 million by 2030.
963	4509	As of 2007[update], over 90 destinations are available worldwide.
964	4510	In 2014, work was completed on the stations historic entrance.
964	4511	Glazing was placed over the historic arches and the Victorian architecture was enhanced; transforming the 19th century public portico.
964	4512	The station is one of only six Grade One listed railway stations in the UK.
964	4513	Opened in 1850 by Queen Victoria, it was the first covered railway station in the world and was much copied across the UK.
964	4514	It has a neoclassical façade, originally designed by the architect John Dobson, and was constructed in collaboration with Robert Stephenson.
964	4515	The station sightlines towards the Castle Keep, whilst showcasing the curvature of the station’s arched roof.
964	4516	The first services were operated by the North Eastern Railway company.
964	4517	The city's other mainline station, Manors, is to the east of the city centre.
965	4518	Train operator Virgin Trains East Coast provides a half-hourly frequency of trains to London King's Cross, with a journey time of about three hours, these services call at Durham, Darlington, York, Doncaster, Newark North Gate and Peterborough and north to Scotland with all trains calling at Edinburgh and a small number of trains extended to Glasgow, Aberdeen and Inverness.
965	4519	CrossCountry trains serve destinations in Yorkshire, the Midlands and the South West.
965	4520	First TransPennine Express operates services to Manchester and Liverpool.
965	4521	Northern Rail provides local and regional services.
966	4522	The city is served by the Tyne and Wear Metro, a system of suburban and underground railways covering much of Tyne and Wear.
966	4523	It was opened in five phases between 1980 and 1984, and was Britain's first urban light rail transit system; two extensions were opened in 1991 and 2002.
966	4524	It was developed from a combination of existing and newly built tracks and stations, with deep-level tunnels constructed through Newcastle city centre.
966	4525	A bridge was built across the Tyne, between Newcastle and Gateshead, and opened by Queen Elizabeth II in 1981.
966	4526	The network is operated by DB Regio on behalf of Nexus and carries over 37 million passengers a year, extending as far as Newcastle Airport, Tynemouth, South Shields and South Hylton in Sunderland.
966	4527	In 2004, the company Marconi designed and constructed the mobile radio system to the underground Metro system.
966	4528	The Metro system was the first in the UK to have mobile phone antennae installed in the tunnels.
967	4529	The system is currently undergoing a period of refurbishment and modernization, entitled 'Metro: All Change.'
967	4530	The programme has replaced all ticket machines and introduced ticket gates at the busiest stations - part of the transition to smart ticketing.
967	4531	All Metro trains are being completely refurbished and most stations are undergoing improvement works (or in some cases complete reconstruction, for example North Shields).
967	4532	In addition; tracks, signalling and overhead wires are also being overhauled.
967	4533	Longer term plans include the procurement of an entirely new fleet of trains and further extensions to the system.
967	4534	Proposed routes include to Newcastle's west end, to the Cobalt business park in North Tyneside, to the Metrocentre in Gateshead and to additional locations in Gateshead, South Tyneside and Sunderland.
967	4535	Several of the proposed routes would require trams as opposed to the current light rail trains.
968	4536	Major roads in the area include the A1 (Gateshead Newcastle Western Bypass), stretching north to Edinburgh and south to London; the A19 heading south past Sunderland and Middlesbrough to York and Doncaster; the A69 heading west to Carlisle; the A696, which becomes the A68 heads past Newcastle Airport and up through central Northumberland and central Scottish Borders, the A167, the old "Great North Road", heading south to Gateshead, Chester-le-Street, Durham and Darlington; and the A1058 "Coast Road", which runs from Jesmond to the east coast between Tynemouth and Cullercoats.
968	4537	Many of these designations are recent—upon completion of the Western Bypass, and its designation as the new line of the A1, the roads between this and the A1's former alignment through the Tyne Tunnel were renumbered, with many city centre roads changing from a 6-prefix to their present 1-prefix numbers.
968	4538	In November 2011 the capacity of the Tyne Tunnel was increased when a project to build a second road tunnel and refurbish the first tunnel was completed.
969	4539	There are 3 main bus companies providing services in the city; Arriva North East, Go North East and Stagecoach North East.
969	4540	There are two major bus stations in the city: Haymarket bus station and Eldon Square bus station.
969	4541	Arriva mainly operates from Haymarket Bus Station providing the majority of services to the north of Newcastle, Northumberland and North Tyneside.
969	4542	Go-Ahead operates from Eldon Square Bus Station, providing the majority of services south of the river in Gateshead, South Tyneside, Sunderland, and County Durham.
969	4543	Stagecoach is the primary operator in the city proper, with cross-city services mainly between both the West and East ends via the city centre with some services extending out to the MetroCentre, Killingworth, Wallsend and Ponteland.
969	4544	Bus Services in Newcastle upon Tyne and the surrounding boroughs part of the Tyne and Wear area are coordinated by Nexus, the Tyne and Wear Passenger Transport Executive.
970	4545	Following guidelines set in the National Cycling strategy, Newcastle first developed its cycling strategy in 1998.
971	4546	From Newcastle International Ferry Terminal, at North Shields, Danish DFDS Seaways run a service to IJmuiden (near Amsterdam).
