1701	8266	β-carotene is a bright red-orange carotenoid found in nearly all chloroplasts, like chlorophyll a. Xanthophylls, especially the orange-red zeaxanthin, are also common.
1701	8267	Many other forms of carotenoids exist that are only found in certain groups of chloroplasts.
1702	8268	Phycobilins are a third group of pigments found in cyanobacteria, and glaucophyte, red algal, and cryptophyte chloroplasts.
1702	8269	Phycobilins come in all colors, though phycoerytherin is one of the pigments that makes many red algae red.
1702	8270	Phycobilins often organize into relatively large protein complexes about 40 nanometers across called phycobilisomes.
1702	8271	Like photosystem I and ATP synthase, phycobilisomes jut into the stroma, preventing thylakoid stacking in red algal chloroplasts.
1702	8272	Cryptophyte chloroplasts and some cyanobacteria don't have their phycobilin pigments organized into phycobilisomes, and keep them in their thylakoid space instead.
1703	8273	To fix carbon dioxide into sugar molecules in the process of photosynthesis, chloroplasts use an enzyme called rubisco.
1703	8274	Rubisco has a problem—it has trouble distinguishing between carbon dioxide and oxygen, so at high oxygen concentrations, rubisco starts accidentally adding oxygen to sugar precursors.
1703	8275	This has the end result of ATP energy being wasted and CO2 being released, all with no sugar being produced.
1703	8276	This is a big problem, since O2 is produced by the initial light reactions of photosynthesis, causing issues down the line in the Calvin cycle which uses rubisco.
1704	8277	As a result, chloroplasts in C4 mesophyll cells and bundle sheath cells are specialized for each stage of photosynthesis.
1704	8278	In mesophyll cells, chloroplasts are specialized for the light reactions, so they lack rubisco, and have normal grana and thylakoids, which they use to make ATP and NADPH, as well as oxygen.
1704	8279	They store CO2 in a four-carbon compound, which is why the process is called C4 photosynthesis.
1704	8280	The four-carbon compound is then transported to the bundle sheath chloroplasts, where it drops off CO2 and returns to the mesophyll.
1704	8281	Bundle sheath chloroplasts do not carry out the light reactions, preventing oxygen from building up in them and disrupting rubisco activity.
1704	8282	Because of this, they lack thylakoids organized into grana stacks—though bundle sheath chloroplasts still have free-floating thylakoids in the stroma where they still carry out cyclic electron flow, a light-driven method of synthesizing ATP to power the Calvin cycle without generating oxygen.
1704	8283	They lack photosystem II, and only have photosystem I—the only protein complex needed for cyclic electron flow.
1704	8284	Because the job of bundle sheath chloroplasts is to carry out the Calvin cycle and make sugar, they often contain large starch grains.
1705	8285	Not all cells in a multicellular plant contain chloroplasts.
1705	8286	All green parts of a plant contain chloroplasts—the chloroplasts, or more specifically, the chlorophyll in them are what make the photosynthetic parts of a plant green.
1705	8287	The plant cells which contain chloroplasts are usually parenchyma cells, though chloroplasts can also be found in collenchyma tissue.
1705	8288	A plant cell which contains chloroplasts is known as a chlorenchyma cell.
1705	8289	A typical chlorenchyma cell of a land plant contains about 10 to 100 chloroplasts.
1706	8290	In some plants such as cacti, chloroplasts are found in the stems, though in most plants, chloroplasts are concentrated in the leaves.
1706	8291	One square millimeter of leaf tissue can contain half a million chloroplasts.
1706	8292	Within a leaf, chloroplasts are mainly found in the mesophyll layers of a leaf, and the guard cells of stomata.
1706	8293	Palisade mesophyll cells can contain 30–70 chloroplasts per cell, while stomatal guard cells contain only around 8–15 per cell, as well as much less chlorophyll.
1706	8294	Chloroplasts can also be found in the bundle sheath cells of a leaf, especially in C4 plants, which carry out the Calvin cycle in their bundle sheath cells.
1706	8295	They are often absent from the epidermis of a leaf.
1707	8296	The chloroplasts of plant and algal cells can orient themselves to best suit the available light.
1707	8297	In low-light conditions, they will spread out in a sheet—maximizing the surface area to absorb light.
1707	8298	Under intense light, they will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along the plant cell's cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edge-on.
1707	8299	This reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage.
1707	8300	This ability to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out may be the reason why land plants evolved to have many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones.
1707	8301	Chloroplast movement is considered one of the most closely regulated stimulus-response systems that can be found in plants.
1707	8302	Mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as they move.
1708	8303	Plants have two main immune responses—the hypersensitive response, in which infected cells seal themselves off and undergo programmed cell death, and systemic acquired resistance, where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen's presence.
1708	8304	Chloroplasts stimulate both responses by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system, producing reactive oxygen species.
1708	8305	High levels of reactive oxygen species will cause the hypersensitive response.
1708	8306	The reactive oxygen species also directly kill any pathogens within the cell.
1708	8307	Lower levels of reactive oxygen species initiate systemic acquired resistance, triggering defense-molecule production in the rest of the plant.
1709	8308	Chloroplasts can serve as cellular sensors.
1709	8309	After detecting stress in a cell, which might be due to a pathogen, chloroplasts begin producing molecules like salicylic acid, jasmonic acid, nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species which can serve as defense-signals.
1709	8310	As cellular signals, reactive oxygen species are unstable molecules, so they probably don't leave the chloroplast, but instead pass on their signal to an unknown second messenger molecule.
1709	8311	All these molecules initiate retrograde signaling—signals from the chloroplast that regulate gene expression in the nucleus.
1710	8312	One of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis, the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy, to subsequently produce food in the form of sugars.
1710	8313	Water (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) are used in photosynthesis, and sugar and oxygen (O2) is made, using light energy.
1710	8314	Photosynthesis is divided into two stages—the light reactions, where water is split to produce oxygen, and the dark reactions, or Calvin cycle, which builds sugar molecules from carbon dioxide.
1710	8315	The two phases are linked by the energy carriers adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP+).
1711	8316	Like mitochondria, chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H+, or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy.
1711	8317	The two photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water, and release them down an electron transport chain.
1711	8318	The molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, creating a concentration gradient, with more hydrogen ions (up to a thousand times as many) inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma.
1711	8319	The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space then diffuse back down their concentration gradient, flowing back out into the stroma through ATP synthase.
1711	8320	ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or ATP.
1711	8321	Because chloroplast ATP synthase projects out into the stroma, the ATP is synthesized there, in position to be used in the dark reactions.
1712	8322	While photosystem II photolyzes water to obtain and energize new electrons, photosystem I simply reenergizes depleted electrons at the end of an electron transport chain.
1712	8323	Normally, the reenergized electrons are taken by NADP+, though sometimes they can flow back down more H+-pumping electron transport chains to transport more hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more ATP.
1712	8324	This is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled.
1712	8325	Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants, which need more ATP than NADPH.
1713	8326	The Calvin cycle starts by using the enzyme Rubisco to fix CO2 into five-carbon Ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP) molecules.
1713	8327	The result is unstable six-carbon molecules that immediately break down into three-carbon molecules called 3-phosphoglyceric acid, or 3-PGA.
1713	8328	The ATP and NADPH made in the light reactions is used to convert the 3-PGA into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, or G3P sugar molecules.
1713	8329	Most of the G3P molecules are recycled back into RuBP using energy from more ATP, but one out of every six produced leaves the cycle—the end product of the dark reactions.
1714	8330	Alternatively, glucose monomers in the chloroplast can be linked together to make starch, which accumulates into the starch grains found in the chloroplast.
1714	8331	Under conditions such as high atmospheric CO2 concentrations, these starch grains may grow very large, distorting the grana and thylakoids.
1714	8332	The starch granules displace the thylakoids, but leave them intact.
1714	8333	Waterlogged roots can also cause starch buildup in the chloroplasts, possibly due to less sucrose being exported out of the chloroplast (or more accurately, the plant cell).
1714	8334	This depletes a plant's free phosphate supply, which indirectly stimulates chloroplast starch synthesis.
1714	8335	While linked to low photosynthesis rates, the starch grains themselves may not necessarily interfere significantly with the efficiency of photosynthesis, and might simply be a side effect of another photosynthesis-depressing factor.
1715	8336	Photorespiration can occur when the oxygen concentration is too high.
1715	8337	Rubisco cannot distinguish between oxygen and carbon dioxide very well, so it can accidentally add O2 instead of CO2 to RuBP.
1715	8338	This process reduces the efficiency of photosynthesis—it consumes ATP and oxygen, releases CO2, and produces no sugar.
1715	8339	It can waste up to half the carbon fixed by the Calvin cycle.
1715	8340	Several mechanisms have evolved in different lineages that raise the carbon dioxide concentration relative to oxygen within the chloroplast, increasing the efficiency of photosynthesis.
1715	8341	These mechanisms are called carbon dioxide concentrating mechanisms, or CCMs.
1715	8342	These include Crassulacean acid metabolism, C4 carbon fixation, and pyrenoids.
1715	8343	Chloroplasts in C4 plants are notable as they exhibit a distinct chloroplast dimorphism.
1716	8344	Chloroplasts alone make almost all of a plant cell's amino acids in their stroma except the sulfur-containing ones like cysteine and methionine.
1716	8345	Cysteine is made in the chloroplast (the proplastid too) but it is also synthesized in the cytosol and mitochondria, probably because it has trouble crossing membranes to get to where it is needed.
1716	8346	The chloroplast is known to make the precursors to methionine but it is unclear whether the organelle carries out the last leg of the pathway or if it happens in the cytosol.
1717	8347	Chloroplasts are a special type of a plant cell organelle called a plastid, though the two terms are sometimes used interchangeably.
1717	8348	There are many other types of plastids, which carry out various functions.
1717	8349	All chloroplasts in a plant are descended from undifferentiated proplastids found in the zygote, or fertilized egg.
1717	8350	Proplastids are commonly found in an adult plant's apical meristems.
1717	8351	Chloroplasts do not normally develop from proplastids in root tip meristems—instead, the formation of starch-storing amyloplasts is more common.
1718	8352	If angiosperm shoots are not exposed to the required light for chloroplast formation, proplastids may develop into an etioplast stage before becoming chloroplasts.
1718	8353	An etioplast is a plastid that lacks chlorophyll, and has inner membrane invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma, called a prolamellar body.
1718	8354	While etioplasts lack chlorophyll, they have a yellow chlorophyll precursor stocked.
1718	8355	Within a few minutes of light exposure, the prolamellar body begins to reorganize into stacks of thylakoids, and chlorophyll starts to be produced.
1718	8356	This process, where the etioplast becomes a chloroplast, takes several hours.
1718	8357	Gymnosperms do not require light to form chloroplasts.
1719	8358	Plastid differentiation is not permanent, in fact many interconversions are possible.
1719	8359	Chloroplasts may be converted to chromoplasts, which are pigment-filled plastids responsible for the bright colors seen in flowers and ripe fruit.
1719	8360	Starch storing amyloplasts can also be converted to chromoplasts, and it is possible for proplastids to develop straight into chromoplasts.
1719	8361	Chromoplasts and amyloplasts can also become chloroplasts, like what happens when a carrot or a potato is illuminated.
1719	8362	If a plant is injured, or something else causes a plant cell to revert to a meristematic state, chloroplasts and other plastids can turn back into proplastids.
1719	8363	Chloroplast, amyloplast, chromoplast, proplast, etc., are not absolute states—intermediate forms are common.
1720	8364	The division process starts when the proteins FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 assemble into filaments, and with the help of a protein ARC6, form a structure called a Z-ring within the chloroplast's stroma.
1720	8365	The Min system manages the placement of the Z-ring, ensuring that the chloroplast is cleaved more or less evenly.
1720	8366	The protein MinD prevents FtsZ from linking up and forming filaments.
1720	8367	Another protein ARC3 may also be involved, but it is not very well understood.
1720	8368	These proteins are active at the poles of the chloroplast, preventing Z-ring formation there, but near the center of the chloroplast, MinE inhibits them, allowing the Z-ring to form.
1721	8369	Next, the two plastid-dividing rings, or PD rings form.
1721	8370	The inner plastid-dividing ring is located in the inner side of the chloroplast's inner membrane, and is formed first.
1721	8371	The outer plastid-dividing ring is found wrapped around the outer chloroplast membrane.
1721	8372	It consists of filaments about 5 nanometers across, arranged in rows 6.4 nanometers apart, and shrinks to squeeze the chloroplast.
1721	8373	This is when chloroplast constriction begins.
1721	8374	In a few species like Cyanidioschyzon merolæ, chloroplasts have a third plastid-dividing ring located in the chloroplast's intermembrane space.
1722	8375	Light has been shown to be a requirement for chloroplast division.
1722	8376	Chloroplasts can grow and progress through some of the constriction stages under poor quality green light, but are slow to complete division—they require exposure to bright white light to complete division.
1722	8377	Spinach leaves grown under green light have been observed to contain many large dumbbell-shaped chloroplasts.
1722	8378	Exposure to white light can stimulate these chloroplasts to divide and reduce the population of dumbbell-shaped chloroplasts.
1723	8379	Recently, chloroplasts have caught attention by developers of genetically modified crops.
1723	8380	Since, in most flowering plants, chloroplasts are not inherited from the male parent, transgenes in these plastids cannot be disseminated by pollen.
1723	8381	This makes plastid transformation a valuable tool for the creation and cultivation of genetically modified plants that are biologically contained, thus posing significantly lower environmental risks.
1723	8382	This biological containment strategy is therefore suitable for establishing the coexistence of conventional and organic agriculture.
1723	8383	While the reliability of this mechanism has not yet been studied for all relevant crop species, recent results in tobacco plants are promising, showing a failed containment rate of transplastomic plants at 3 in 1,000,000.
1724	8384	A prime number (or a prime) is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself.
1724	8385	A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number.
1724	8386	For example, 5 is prime because 1 and 5 are its only positive integer factors, whereas 6 is composite because it has the divisors 2 and 3 in addition to 1 and 6.
1724	8387	The fundamental theorem of arithmetic establishes the central role of primes in number theory: any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering.
1724	8388	The uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization, e.g., 3, 1 · 3, 1 · 1 · 3, etc.
1724	8389	are all valid factorizations of 3.
1725	8390	The property of being prime (or not) is called primality.
1725	8391	A simple but slow method of verifying the primality of a given number n is known as trial division.
1725	8392	It consists of testing whether n is a multiple of any integer between 2 and .
1725	8393	Algorithms much more efficient than trial division have been devised to test the primality of large numbers.
1725	8394	These include the Miller–Rabin primality test, which is fast but has a small probability of error, and the AKS primality test, which always produces the correct answer in polynomial time but is too slow to be practical.
1725	8395	Particularly fast methods are available for numbers of special forms, such as Mersenne numbers.
1725	8396	As of January 2016[update], the largest known prime number has 22,338,618 decimal digits.
1726	8397	There are infinitely many primes, as demonstrated by Euclid around 300 BC.
1726	8398	There is no known simple formula that separates prime numbers from composite numbers.
1726	8399	However, the distribution of primes, that is to say, the statistical behaviour of primes in the large, can be modelled.
1726	8400	The first result in that direction is the prime number theorem, proven at the end of the 19th century, which says that the probability that a given, randomly chosen number n is prime is inversely proportional to its number of digits, or to the logarithm of n.
1727	8401	Many questions regarding prime numbers remain open, such as Goldbach's conjecture (that every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes), and the twin prime conjecture (that there are infinitely many pairs of primes whose difference is 2).
1727	8402	Such questions spurred the development of various branches of number theory, focusing on analytic or algebraic aspects of numbers.
1727	8403	Primes are used in several routines in information technology, such as public-key cryptography, which makes use of properties such as the difficulty of factoring large numbers into their prime factors.
1727	8404	Prime numbers give rise to various generalizations in other mathematical domains, mainly algebra, such as prime elements and prime ideals.
1728	8405	The image at the right illustrates that 12 is not prime: 12 = 3 · 4.
1728	8406	No even number greater than 2 is prime because by definition, any such number n has at least three distinct divisors, namely 1, 2, and n. This implies that n is not prime.
1728	8407	Accordingly, the term odd prime refers to any prime number greater than 2.
1728	8408	Similarly, when written in the usual decimal system, all prime numbers larger than 5 end in 1, 3, 7, or 9, since even numbers are multiples of 2 and numbers ending in 0 or 5 are multiples of 5.
1729	8409	Most early Greeks did not even consider 1 to be a number, so they could not consider it to be a prime.
1729	8410	By the Middle Ages and Renaissance many mathematicians included 1 as the first prime number.
1729	8411	In the mid-18th century Christian Goldbach listed 1 as the first prime in his famous correspondence with Leonhard Euler -- who did not agree.
1729	8412	In the 19th century many mathematicians still considered the number 1 to be a prime.
1729	8413	For example, Derrick Norman Lehmer's list of primes up to 10,006,721, reprinted as late as 1956, started with 1 as its first prime.
1729	8414	Henri Lebesgue is said to be the last professional mathematician to call 1 prime.
1729	8415	By the early 20th century, mathematicians began to accept that 1 is not a prime number, but rather forms its own special category as a "unit".
1730	8416	A large body of mathematical work would still be valid when calling 1 a prime, but Euclid's fundamental theorem of arithmetic (mentioned above) would not hold as stated.
1730	8417	For example, the number 15 can be factored as 3 · 5 and 1 · 3 · 5; if 1 were admitted as a prime, these two presentations would be considered different factorizations of 15 into prime numbers, so the statement of that theorem would have to be modified.
1730	8418	Similarly, the sieve of Eratosthenes would not work correctly if 1 were considered a prime: a modified version of the sieve that considers 1 as prime would eliminate all multiples of 1 (that is, all other numbers) and produce as output only the single number 1.
1730	8419	Furthermore, the prime numbers have several properties that the number 1 lacks, such as the relationship of the number to its corresponding value of Euler's totient function or the sum of divisors function.
1731	8420	There are hints in the surviving records of the ancient Egyptians that they had some knowledge of prime numbers: the Egyptian fraction expansions in the Rhind papyrus, for instance, have quite different forms for primes and for composites.
1731	8421	However, the earliest surviving records of the explicit study of prime numbers come from the Ancient Greeks.
1731	8422	Euclid's Elements (circa 300 BC) contain important theorems about primes, including the infinitude of primes and the fundamental theorem of arithmetic.
1731	8423	Euclid also showed how to construct a perfect number from a Mersenne prime.
1731	8424	The Sieve of Eratosthenes, attributed to Eratosthenes, is a simple method to compute primes, although the large primes found today with computers are not generated this way.
1732	8425	After the Greeks, little happened with the study of prime numbers until the 17th century.
1732	8426	In 1640 Pierre de Fermat stated (without proof) Fermat's little theorem (later proved by Leibniz and Euler).
1732	8427	Fermat also conjectured that all numbers of the form 22n + 1 are prime (they are called Fermat numbers) and he verified this up to n = 4 (or 216 + 1).
1732	8428	However, the very next Fermat number 232 + 1 is composite (one of its prime factors is 641), as Euler discovered later, and in fact no further Fermat numbers are known to be prime.
1732	8429	The French monk Marin Mersenne looked at primes of the form 2p − 1, with p a prime.
1732	8430	They are called Mersenne primes in his honor.
1733	8431	The most basic method of checking the primality of a given integer n is called trial division.
1733	8432	This routine consists of dividing n by each integer m that is greater than 1 and less than or equal to the square root of n. If the result of any of these divisions is an integer, then n is not a prime, otherwise it is a prime.
1733	8433	Indeed, if  is composite (with a and b ≠ 1) then one of the factors a or b is necessarily at most .
1733	8434	For example, for , the trial divisions are by m = 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6.
1733	8435	None of these numbers divides 37, so 37 is prime.
1733	8436	This routine can be implemented more efficiently if a complete list of primes up to  is known—then trial divisions need to be checked only for those m that are prime.
1733	8437	For example, to check the primality of 37, only three divisions are necessary (m = 2, 3, and 5), given that 4 and 6 are composite.
1734	8438	Modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided into two main classes, probabilistic (or "Monte Carlo") and deterministic algorithms.
1734	8439	Deterministic algorithms provide a way to tell for sure whether a given number is prime or not.
1734	8440	For example, trial division is a deterministic algorithm because, if performed correctly, it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite.
1734	8441	Probabilistic algorithms are normally faster, but do not completely prove that a number is prime.
1734	8442	These tests rely on testing a given number in a partly random way.
1734	8443	For example, a given test might pass all the time if applied to a prime number, but pass only with probability p if applied to a composite number.
1734	8444	If we repeat the test n times and pass every time, then the probability that our number is composite is 1/(1-p)n, which decreases exponentially with the number of tests, so we can be as sure as we like (though never perfectly sure) that the number is prime.
1734	8445	On the other hand, if the test ever fails, then we know that the number is composite.
1735	8446	A particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is the Fermat primality test, which relies on the fact (Fermat's little theorem) that np≡n (mod p) for any n if p is a prime number.
1735	8447	If we have a number b that we want to test for primality, then we work out nb (mod b) for a random value of n as our test.
1735	8448	A flaw with this test is that there are some composite numbers (the Carmichael numbers) that satisfy the Fermat identity even though they are not prime, so the test has no way of distinguishing between prime numbers and Carmichael numbers.
1735	8449	Carmichael numbers are substantially rarer than prime numbers, though, so this test can be useful for practical purposes.
1735	8450	More powerful extensions of the Fermat primality test, such as the Baillie-PSW, Miller-Rabin, and Solovay-Strassen tests, are guaranteed to fail at least some of the time when applied to a composite number.
1736	8451	Prime numbers of this form are known as factorial primes.
1736	8452	Other primes where either p + 1 or p − 1 is of a particular shape include the Sophie Germain primes (primes of the form 2p + 1 with p prime), primorial primes, Fermat primes and Mersenne primes, that is, prime numbers that are of the form 2p − 1, where p is an arbitrary prime.
1736	8453	The Lucas–Lehmer test is particularly fast for numbers of this form.
1736	8454	This is why the largest known prime has almost always been a Mersenne prime since the dawn of electronic computers.
1737	8455	The following table gives the largest known primes of the mentioned types.
1737	8456	Some of these primes have been found using distributed computing.
1737	8457	In 2009, the Great Internet Mersenne Prime Search project was awarded a US$100,000 prize for first discovering a prime with at least 10 million digits.
1737	8458	The Electronic Frontier Foundation also offers $150,000 and $250,000 for primes with at least 100 million digits and 1 billion digits, respectively.
1737	8459	Some of the largest primes not known to have any particular form (that is, no simple formula such as that of Mersenne primes) have been found by taking a piece of semi-random binary data, converting it to a number n, multiplying it by 256k for some positive integer k, and searching for possible primes within the interval [256kn + 1, 256k(n + 1) − 1].
1738	8460	are prime for any natural number n. Here  represents the floor function, i.e., largest integer not greater than the number in question.
1738	8461	The latter formula can be shown using Bertrand's postulate (proven first by Chebyshev), which states that there always exists at least one prime number p with n < p < 2n − 2, for any natural number n > 3.
1738	8462	However, computing A or μ requires the knowledge of infinitely many primes to begin with.
1738	8463	Another formula is based on Wilson's theorem and generates the number 2 many times and all other primes exactly once.
1739	8464	can have infinitely many primes only when a and q are coprime, i.e., their greatest common divisor is one.
1739	8465	If this necessary condition is satisfied, Dirichlet's theorem on arithmetic progressions asserts that the progression contains infinitely many primes.
1739	8466	The picture below illustrates this with q = 9: the numbers are "wrapped around" as soon as a multiple of 9 is passed.
1739	8467	The rows (=progressions) starting with a = 3, 6, or 9 contain at most one prime number.
1739	8468	In all other rows (a = 1, 2, 4, 5, 7, and 8) there are infinitely many prime numbers.
1739	8469	What is more, the primes are distributed equally among those rows in the long run—the density of all primes congruent a modulo 9 is 1/6.
1740	8470	The zeta function is closely related to prime numbers.
1740	8471	For example, the aforementioned fact that there are infinitely many primes can also be seen using the zeta function: if there were only finitely many primes then ζ(1) would have a finite value.
1740	8472	However, the harmonic series 1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/4 + ... diverges (i.e., exceeds any given number), so there must be infinitely many primes.
1740	8473	Another example of the richness of the zeta function and a glimpse of modern algebraic number theory is the following identity (Basel problem), due to Euler,
1741	8474	The unproven Riemann hypothesis, dating from 1859, states that except for s = −2, −4, ..., all zeroes of the ζ-function have real part equal to 1/2.
1741	8475	The connection to prime numbers is that it essentially says that the primes are as regularly distributed as possible.
1741	8476	[clarification needed] From a physical viewpoint, it roughly states that the irregularity in the distribution of primes only comes from random noise.
1741	8477	From a mathematical viewpoint, it roughly states that the asymptotic distribution of primes (about x/log x of numbers less than x are primes, the prime number theorem) also holds for much shorter intervals of length about the square root of x (for intervals near x).
1741	8478	This hypothesis is generally believed to be correct.
1741	8479	In particular, the simplest assumption is that primes should have no significant irregularities without good reason.
1742	8480	In addition to the Riemann hypothesis, many more conjectures revolving about primes have been posed.
1742	8481	Often having an elementary formulation, many of these conjectures have withstood a proof for decades: all four of Landau's problems from 1912 are still unsolved.
1742	8482	One of them is Goldbach's conjecture, which asserts that every even integer n greater than 2 can be written as a sum of two primes.
1742	8483	As of February 2011[update], this conjecture has been verified for all numbers up to n = 2 · 1017.
1742	8484	Weaker statements than this have been proven, for example Vinogradov's theorem says that every sufficiently large odd integer can be written as a sum of three primes.
1742	8485	Chen's theorem says that every sufficiently large even number can be expressed as the sum of a prime and a semiprime, the product of two primes.
1742	8486	Also, any even integer can be written as the sum of six primes.
1742	8487	The branch of number theory studying such questions is called additive number theory.
1743	8488	A third type of conjectures concerns aspects of the distribution of primes.
1743	8489	It is conjectured that there are infinitely many twin primes, pairs of primes with difference 2 (twin prime conjecture).
1743	8490	Polignac's conjecture is a strengthening of that conjecture, it states that for every positive integer n, there are infinitely many pairs of consecutive primes that differ by 2n.
1743	8491	It is conjectured there are infinitely many primes of the form n2 + 1.
1743	8492	These conjectures are special cases of the broad Schinzel's hypothesis H. Brocard's conjecture says that there are always at least four primes between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2.
1743	8493	Legendre's conjecture states that there is a prime number between n2 and (n + 1)2 for every positive integer n. It is implied by the stronger Cramér's conjecture.
1744	8494	For a long time, number theory in general, and the study of prime numbers in particular, was seen as the canonical example of pure mathematics, with no applications outside of the self-interest of studying the topic with the exception of use of prime numbered gear teeth to distribute wear evenly.
1744	8495	In particular, number theorists such as British mathematician G. H. Hardy prided themselves on doing work that had absolutely no military significance.
1744	8496	However, this vision was shattered in the 1970s, when it was publicly announced that prime numbers could be used as the basis for the creation of public key cryptography algorithms.
1744	8497	Prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators.
1745	8498	Giuga's conjecture says that this equation is also a sufficient condition for p to be prime.
1745	8499	Another consequence of Fermat's little theorem is the following: if p is a prime number other than 2 and 5, 1/p is always a recurring decimal, whose period is p − 1 or a divisor of p − 1.
1745	8500	The fraction 1/p expressed likewise in base q (rather than base 10) has similar effect, provided that p is not a prime factor of q. Wilson's theorem says that an integer p > 1 is prime if and only if the factorial (p − 1)!
1745	8501	+ 1 is divisible by p. Moreover, an integer n > 4 is composite if and only if (n − 1)!
1746	8502	Several public-key cryptography algorithms, such as RSA and the Diffie–Hellman key exchange, are based on large prime numbers (for example, 512-bit primes are frequently used for RSA and 1024-bit primes are typical for Diffie–Hellman.).
1746	8503	RSA relies on the assumption that it is much easier (i.e., more efficient) to perform the multiplication of two (large) numbers x and y than to calculate x and y (assumed coprime) if only the product xy is known.
1746	8504	The Diffie–Hellman key exchange relies on the fact that there are efficient algorithms for modular exponentiation, while the reverse operation the discrete logarithm is thought to be a hard problem.
1747	8505	The evolutionary strategy used by cicadas of the genus Magicicada make use of prime numbers.
1747	8506	These insects spend most of their lives as grubs underground.
1747	8507	They only pupate and then emerge from their burrows after 7, 13 or 17 years, at which point they fly about, breed, and then die after a few weeks at most.
1747	8508	The logic for this is believed to be that the prime number intervals between emergences make it very difficult for predators to evolve that could specialize as predators on Magicicadas.
1747	8509	If Magicicadas appeared at a non-prime number intervals, say every 12 years, then predators appearing every 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12 years would be sure to meet them.
1747	8510	Over a 200-year period, average predator populations during hypothetical outbreaks of 14- and 15-year cicadas would be up to 2% higher than during outbreaks of 13- and 17-year cicadas.
1747	8511	Though small, this advantage appears to have been enough to drive natural selection in favour of a prime-numbered life-cycle for these insects.
1748	8512	The concept of prime number is so important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches of mathematics.
1748	8513	Generally, "prime" indicates minimality or indecomposability, in an appropriate sense.
1748	8514	For example, the prime field is the smallest subfield of a field F containing both 0 and 1.
1748	8515	It is either Q or the finite field with p elements, whence the name.
1748	8516	Often a second, additional meaning is intended by using the word prime, namely that any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components.
1748	8517	For example, in knot theory, a prime knot is a knot that is indecomposable in the sense that it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots.
1748	8518	Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots.
1748	8519	Prime models and prime 3-manifolds are other examples of this type.
1749	8520	Prime numbers give rise to two more general concepts that apply to elements of any commutative ring R, an algebraic structure where addition, subtraction and multiplication are defined: prime elements and irreducible elements.
1749	8521	An element p of R is called prime element if it is neither zero nor a unit (i.e., does not have a multiplicative inverse) and satisfies the following requirement: given x and y in R such that p divides the product xy, then p divides x or y.
1749	8522	An element is irreducible if it is not a unit and cannot be written as a product of two ring elements that are not units.
1749	8523	In the ring Z of integers, the set of prime elements equals the set of irreducible elements, which is
1750	8524	The fundamental theorem of arithmetic continues to hold in unique factorization domains.
1750	8525	An example of such a domain is the Gaussian integers Z[i], that is, the set of complex numbers of the form a + bi where i denotes the imaginary unit and a and b are arbitrary integers.
1750	8526	Its prime elements are known as Gaussian primes.
1750	8527	Not every prime (in Z) is a Gaussian prime: in the bigger ring Z[i], 2 factors into the product of the two Gaussian primes (1 + i) and (1 − i).
1750	8528	prime elements in Z) of the form 4k + 3 are Gaussian primes, whereas rational primes of the form 4k + 1 are not.
1751	8529	In ring theory, the notion of number is generally replaced with that of ideal.
1751	8530	Prime ideals, which generalize prime elements in the sense that the principal ideal generated by a prime element is a prime ideal, are an important tool and object of study in commutative algebra, algebraic number theory and algebraic geometry.
1751	8531	The prime ideals of the ring of integers are the ideals (0), (2), (3), (5), (7), (11), … The fundamental theorem of arithmetic generalizes to the Lasker–Noether theorem, which expresses every ideal in a Noetherian commutative ring as an intersection of primary ideals, which are the appropriate generalizations of prime powers.
1752	8532	Prime ideals are the points of algebro-geometric objects, via the notion of the spectrum of a ring.
1752	8533	Arithmetic geometry also benefits from this notion, and many concepts exist in both geometry and number theory.
1752	8534	For example, factorization or ramification of prime ideals when lifted to an extension field, a basic problem of algebraic number theory, bears some resemblance with ramification in geometry.
1752	8535	Such ramification questions occur even in number-theoretic questions solely concerned with integers.
1752	8536	For example, prime ideals in the ring of integers of quadratic number fields can be used in proving quadratic reciprocity, a statement that concerns the solvability of quadratic equations
1753	8537	In particular, this norm gets smaller when a number is multiplied by p, in sharp contrast to the usual absolute value (also referred to as the infinite prime).
1753	8538	While completing Q (roughly, filling the gaps) with respect to the absolute value yields the field of real numbers, completing with respect to the p-adic norm |−|p yields the field of p-adic numbers.
1753	8539	These are essentially all possible ways to complete Q, by Ostrowski's theorem.
1753	8540	Certain arithmetic questions related to Q or more general global fields may be transferred back and forth to the completed (or local) fields.
1753	8541	This local-global principle again underlines the importance of primes to number theory.
1754	8542	Prime numbers have influenced many artists and writers.
1754	8543	The French composer Olivier Messiaen used prime numbers to create ametrical music through "natural phenomena".
1754	8544	In works such as La Nativité du Seigneur (1935) and Quatre études de rythme (1949–50), he simultaneously employs motifs with lengths given by different prime numbers to create unpredictable rhythms: the primes 41, 43, 47 and 53 appear in the third étude, "Neumes rythmiques".
1754	8545	According to Messiaen this way of composing was "inspired by the movements of nature, movements of free and unequal durations".
1755	8546	The Rhine (Romansh: Rein, German: Rhein, French: le Rhin, Dutch: Rijn) is a European river that begins in the Swiss canton of Graubünden in the southeastern Swiss Alps, forms part of the Swiss-Austrian, Swiss-Liechtenstein border, Swiss-German and then the Franco-German border, then flows through the Rhineland and eventually empties into the North Sea in the Netherlands.
1755	8547	The biggest city on the river Rhine is Cologne, Germany with a population of more than 1,050,000 people.
1755	8548	It is the second-longest river in Central and Western Europe (after the Danube), at about 1,230 km (760 mi),[note 2][note 1] with an average discharge of about 2,900 m3/s (100,000 cu ft/s).
1756	8549	The variant forms of the name of the Rhine in modern languages are all derived from the Gaulish name Rēnos, which was adapted in Roman-era geography (1st century BC) as Greek Ῥῆνος (Rhēnos), Latin Rhenus.
1756	8550	[note 3] The spelling with Rh- in English Rhine as well as in German Rhein and French Rhin is due to the influence of Greek orthography, while the vocalisation -i- is due to the Proto-Germanic adoption of the Gaulish name as *Rīnaz, via Old Frankish giving Old English Rín, Old High German Rīn, Dutch Rijn (formerly also spelled Rhijn)).
1756	8551	The diphthong in modern German Rhein (also adopted in Romansh Rein, Rain) is a Central German development of the early modern period, the Alemannic name Rī(n) retaining the older vocalism,[note 4] as does Ripuarian Rhing, while Palatine has diphthongized Rhei, Rhoi.
1756	8552	Spanish is with French in adopting the Germanic vocalism Rin-, while Italian, Occitan and Portuguese retain the Latin Ren-.
1757	8553	The length of the Rhine is conventionally measured in "Rhine-kilometers" (Rheinkilometer), a scale introduced in 1939 which runs from the Old Rhine Bridge at Constance (0 km) to Hoek van Holland (1036.20 km).
1757	8554	The river length is significantly shortened from the river's natural course due to number of canalisation projects completed in the 19th and 20th century.
1757	8555	[note 7] The "total length of the Rhine", to the inclusion of Lake Constance and the Alpine Rhine is more difficult to measure objectively; it was cited as 1,232 kilometres (766 miles) by the Dutch Rijkswaterstaat in 2010.
1758	8556	Near Tamins-Reichenau the Anterior Rhine and the Posterior Rhine join and form the Rhine.
1758	8557	The river makes a distinctive turn to the north near Chur.
1758	8558	This section is nearly 86 km long, and descends from a height of 599 m to 396 m. It flows through a wide glacial alpine valley known as the Rhine Valley (German: Rheintal).
1758	8559	Near Sargans a natural dam, only a few metres high, prevents it from flowing into the open Seeztal valley and then through Lake Walen and Lake Zurich into the river Aare.
1758	8560	The Alpine Rhine begins in the most western part of the Swiss canton of Graubünden, and later forms the border between Switzerland to the West and Liechtenstein and later Austria to the East.
1759	8561	The mouth of the Rhine into Lake Constance forms an inland delta.
1759	8562	The delta is delimited in the West by the Alter Rhein ("Old Rhine") and in the East by a modern canalized section.
1759	8563	Most of the delta is a nature reserve and bird sanctuary.
1759	8564	It includes the Austrian towns of Gaißau, Höchst and Fußach.
1759	8565	The natural Rhine originally branched into at least two arms and formed small islands by precipitating sediments.
1759	8566	In the local Alemannic dialect, the singular is pronounced "Isel" and this is also the local pronunciation of Esel ("Donkey").
1759	8567	Many local fields have an official name containing this element.
1760	8568	A regulation of the Rhine was called for, with an upper canal near Diepoldsau and a lower canal at Fußach, in order to counteract the constant flooding and strong sedimentation in the western Rhine Delta.
1760	8569	The Dornbirner Ach had to be diverted, too, and it now flows parallel to the canalized Rhine into the lake.
1760	8570	Its water has a darker color than the Rhine; the latter's lighter suspended load comes from higher up the mountains.
1760	8571	It is expected that the continuous input of sediment into the lake will silt up the lake.
1760	8572	This has already happened to the former Lake Tuggenersee.
1761	8573	Lake Constance consists of three bodies of water: the Obersee ("upper lake"), the Untersee ("lower lake"), and a connecting stretch of the Rhine, called the Seerhein ("Lake Rhine").
1761	8574	The lake is situated in Germany, Switzerland and Austria near the Alps.
1761	8575	Specifically, its shorelines lie in the German states of Bavaria and Baden-Württemberg, the Austrian state of Vorarlberg, and the Swiss cantons of Thurgau and St. Gallen.
1761	8576	The Rhine flows into it from the south following the Swiss-Austrian border.
1761	8577	It is located at approximately 47°39′N 9°19′E﻿ / ﻿47.650°N 9.317°E﻿ / 47.650; 9.317.
1762	8578	The flow of cold, gray mountain water continues for some distance into the lake.
1762	8579	The cold water flows near the surface and at first doesn't mix with the warmer, green waters of Upper Lake.
1762	8580	But then, at the so-called Rheinbrech, the Rhine water abruptly falls into the depths because of the greater density of cold water.
1762	8581	The flow reappears on the surface at the northern (German) shore of the lake, off the island of Lindau.
1762	8582	The water then follows the northern shore until Hagnau am Bodensee.
1762	8583	A small fraction of the flow is diverted off the island of Mainau into Lake Überlingen.
1762	8584	Most of the water flows via the Constance hopper into the Rheinrinne ("Rhine Gutter") and Seerhein.
1762	8585	Depending on the water level, this flow of the Rhine water is clearly visible along the entire length of the lake.
1763	8586	The Rhine emerges from Lake Constance, flows generally westward, as the Hochrhein, passes the Rhine Falls, and is joined by its major tributary, the river Aare.
1763	8587	The Aare more than doubles the Rhine's water discharge, to an average of nearly 1,000 m3/s (35,000 cu ft/s), and provides more than a fifth of the discharge at the Dutch border.
1763	8588	The Aare also contains the waters from the 4,274 m (14,022 ft) summit of Finsteraarhorn, the highest point of the Rhine basin.
1763	8589	The Rhine roughly forms the German-Swiss border from Lake Constance with the exceptions of the canton of Schaffhausen and parts of the cantons of Zürich and Basel-Stadt, until it turns north at the so-called Rhine knee at Basel, leaving Switzerland.
1764	8590	In the centre of Basel, the first major city in the course of the stream, is located the "Rhine knee"; this is a major bend, where the overall direction of the Rhine changes from West to North.
1764	8591	Legally, the Central Bridge is the boundary between High and Upper Rhine.
1764	8592	The river now flows North as Upper Rhine through the Upper Rhine Plain, which is about 300 km long and up to 40 km wide.
1764	8593	The most important tributaries in this area are the Ill below of Strasbourg, the Neckar in Mannheim and the Main across from Mainz.
1764	8594	In Mainz, the Rhine leaves the Upper Rhine Valley and flows through the Mainz Basin.
1765	8595	The Upper Rhine region was changed significantly by a Rhine straightening program in the 19th Century.
1765	8596	The rate of flow was increased and the ground water level fell significantly.
1765	8597	Dead branches dried up and the amount of forests on the flood plains decreased sharply.
1765	8598	On the French side, the Grand Canal d'Alsace was dug, which carries a significant part of the river water, and all of the traffic.
1765	8599	In some places, there are large compensation pools, for example the huge Bassin de compensation de Plobsheim in Alsace.
1766	8600	The Rhine is the longest river in Germany.
1766	8601	It is here that the Rhine encounters some more of its main tributaries, such as the Neckar, the Main and, later, the Moselle, which contributes an average discharge of more than 300 m3/s (11,000 cu ft/s).
1766	8602	Northeastern France drains to the Rhine via the Moselle; smaller rivers drain the Vosges and Jura Mountains uplands.
1766	8603	Most of Luxembourg and a very small part of Belgium also drain to the Rhine via the Moselle.
1766	8604	As it approaches the Dutch border, the Rhine has an annual mean discharge of 2,290 m3/s (81,000 cu ft/s) and an average width of 400 m (1,300 ft).
1767	8605	Between Bingen and Bonn, the Middle Rhine flows through the Rhine Gorge, a formation which was created by erosion.
1767	8606	The rate of erosion equaled the uplift in the region, such that the river was left at about its original level while the surrounding lands raised.
1767	8607	The gorge is quite deep and is the stretch of the river which is known for its many castles and vineyards.
1767	8608	It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site (2002) and known as "the Romantic Rhine", with more than 40 castles and fortresses from the Middle Ages and many quaint and lovely country villages.
1768	8609	Until the early 1980s, industry was a major source of water pollution.
1768	8610	Although many plants and factories can be found along the Rhine up into Switzerland, it is along the Lower Rhine that the bulk of them are concentrated, as the river passes the major cities of Cologne, Düsseldorf and Duisburg.
1768	8611	Duisburg is the home of Europe's largest inland port and functions as a hub to the sea ports of Rotterdam, Antwerp and Amsterdam.
1768	8612	The Ruhr, which joins the Rhine in Duisburg, is nowadays a clean river, thanks to a combination of stricter environmental controls, a transition from heavy industry to light industry and cleanup measures, such as the reforestation of Slag and brownfields.
1768	8613	The Ruhr currently provides the region with drinking water.
1768	8614	It contributes 70 m3/s (2,500 cu ft/s) to the Rhine.
1768	8615	Other rivers in the Ruhr Area, above all, the Emscher, still carry a considerable degree of pollution.
1769	8616	The dominant economic sectors in the Middle Rhine area are viniculture and tourism.
1769	8617	The Rhine Gorge between Rüdesheim am Rhein and Koblenz is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
1769	8618	Near Sankt Goarshausen, the Rhine flows around the famous rock Lorelei.
1769	8619	With its outstanding architectural monuments, the slopes full of vines, settlements crowded on the narrow river banks and scores of castles lined up along the top of the steep slopes, the Middle Rhine Valley can be considered the epitome of the Rhine romanticism.
1770	8620	The Lower Rhine flows through North Rhine-Westphalia.
1770	8621	Its banks are usually heavily populated and industrialized, in particular the agglomerations Cologne, Düsseldorf and Ruhr area.
1770	8622	Here the Rhine flows through the largest conurbation in Germany, the Rhine-Ruhr region.
1770	8623	One of the most important cities in this region is Duisburg with the largest river port in Europe (Duisport).
1770	8624	The region downstream of Duisburg is more agricultural.
1770	8625	In Wesel, 30 km downstream of Duisburg, is located the western end of the second east-west shipping route, the Wesel-Datteln Canal, which runs parallel to the Lippe.
1770	8626	Between Emmerich and Cleves the Emmerich Rhine Bridge, the longest suspension bridge in Germany, crosses the 400 m wide river.
1770	8627	Near Krefeld, the river crosses the Uerdingen line, the line which separates the areas where Low German and High German are spoken.
1771	8628	From here, the situation becomes more complicated, as the Dutch name Rijn no longer coincides with the main flow of water.
1771	8629	Two thirds of the water flow volume of the Rhine flows farther west, through the Waal and then, via the Merwede and Nieuwe Merwede (De Biesbosch), merging with the Meuse, through the Hollands Diep and Haringvliet estuaries, into the North Sea.
1771	8630	The Beneden Merwede branches off, near Hardinxveld-Giessendam and continues as the Noord, to join the Lek, near the village of Kinderdijk, to form the Nieuwe Maas; then flows past Rotterdam and continues via Het Scheur and the Nieuwe Waterweg, to the North Sea.
1771	8631	The Oude Maas branches off, near Dordrecht, farther down rejoining the Nieuwe Maas to form Het Scheur.
1772	8632	The other third of the water flows through the Pannerdens Kanaal and redistributes in the IJssel and Nederrijn.
1772	8633	The IJssel branch carries one ninth of the water flow of the Rhine north into the IJsselmeer (a former bay), while the Nederrijn carries approximately two ninths of the flow west along a route parallel to the Waal.
1772	8634	However, at Wijk bij Duurstede, the Nederrijn changes its name and becomes the Lek.
1772	8635	It flows farther west, to rejoin the Noord River into the Nieuwe Maas and to the North Sea.
1773	8636	The name Rijn, from here on, is used only for smaller streams farther to the north, which together formed the main river Rhine in Roman times.
1773	8637	Though they retained the name, these streams no longer carry water from the Rhine, but are used for draining the surrounding land and polders.
1773	8638	From Wijk bij Duurstede, the old north branch of the Rhine is called Kromme Rijn ("Bent Rhine") past Utrecht, first Leidse Rijn ("Rhine of Leiden") and then, Oude Rijn ("Old Rhine").
1773	8639	The latter flows west into a sluice at Katwijk, where its waters can be discharged into the North Sea.
1773	8640	This branch once formed the line along which the Limes Germanicus were built.
1773	8641	During periods of lower sea levels within the various ice ages, the Rhine took a left turn, creating the Channel River, the course of which now lies below the English Channel.
1774	8642	The Rhine-Meuse Delta, the most important natural region of the Netherlands begins near Millingen aan de Rijn, close to the Dutch-German border with the division of the Rhine into Waal and Nederrijn.
1774	8643	Since the Rhine contributes most of the water, the shorter term Rhine Delta is commonly used.
1774	8644	However, this name is also used for the river delta where the Rhine flows into Lake Constance, so it is clearer to call the larger one Rhine-Meuse delta, or even Rhine–Meuse–Scheldt delta, as the Scheldt ends in the same delta.
1775	8645	The shape of the Rhine delta is determined by two bifurcations: first, at Millingen aan de Rijn, the Rhine splits into Waal and Pannerdens Kanaal, which changes its name to Nederrijn at Angeren, and second near Arnhem, the IJssel branches off from the Nederrijn.
1775	8646	This creates three main flows, two of which change names rather often.
1775	8647	The largest and southern main branch begins as Waal and continues as Boven Merwede ("Upper Merwede"), Beneden Merwede ("Lower Merwede"), Noord River ("North River"), Nieuwe Maas ("New Meuse"), Het Scheur ("the Rip") and Nieuwe Waterweg ("New Waterway").
1775	8648	The middle flow begins as Nederrijn, then changes into Lek, then joins the Noord, thereby forming Nieuwe Maas.
1775	8649	The northern flow keeps the name IJssel until it flows into Lake IJsselmeer.
1775	8650	Three more flows carry significant amounts of water: the Nieuwe Merwede ("New Merwede"), which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Boven to Beneden Merwede; the Oude Maas ("Old Meuse"), which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Beneden Merwede into Noord, and Dordtse Kil, which branches off from Oude Maas.
1776	8651	Before the St. Elizabeth's flood (1421), the Meuse flowed just south of today's line Merwede-Oude Maas to the North Sea and formed an archipelago-like estuary with Waal and Lek.
1776	8652	This system of numerous bays, estuary-like extended rivers, many islands and constant changes of the coastline, is hard to imagine today.
1776	8653	From 1421 to 1904, the Meuse and Waal merged further upstream at Gorinchem to form Merwede.
1776	8654	For flood protection reasons, the Meuse was separated from the Waal through a lock and diverted into a new outlet called "Bergse Maas", then Amer and then flows into the former bay Hollands Diep.
1777	8655	The hydrography of the current delta is characterized by the delta's main arms, disconnected arms (Hollandse IJssel, Linge, Vecht, etc.)
1777	8656	Many rivers have been closed ("dammed") and now serve as drainage channels for the numerous polders.
1777	8657	The construction of Delta Works changed the Delta in the second half of the 20th Century fundamentally.
1777	8658	Currently Rhine water runs into the sea, or into former marine bays now separated from the sea, in five places, namely at the mouths of the Nieuwe Merwede, Nieuwe Waterway (Nieuwe Maas), Dordtse Kil, Spui and IJssel.
1778	8659	The Rhine-Meuse Delta is a tidal delta, shaped not only by the sedimentation of the rivers, but also by tidal currents.
1778	8660	This meant that high tide formed a serious risk because strong tidal currents could tear huge areas of land into the sea.
1778	8661	Before the construction of the Delta Works, tidal influence was palpable up to Nijmegen, and even today, after the regulatory action of the Delta Works, the tide acts far inland.
1778	8662	At the Waal, for example, the most landward tidal influence can be detected between Brakel and Zaltbommel.
1779	8663	In southern Europe, the stage was set in the Triassic Period of the Mesozoic Era, with the opening of the Tethys Ocean, between the Eurasian and African tectonic plates, between about 240 MBP and 220 MBP (million years before present).
1779	8664	The present Mediterranean Sea descends from this somewhat larger Tethys sea.
1779	8665	At about 180 MBP, in the Jurassic Period, the two plates reversed direction and began to compress the Tethys floor, causing it to be subducted under Eurasia and pushing up the edge of the latter plate in the Alpine Orogeny of the Oligocene and Miocene Periods.
1779	8666	Several microplates were caught in the squeeze and rotated or were pushed laterally, generating the individual features of Mediterranean geography: Iberia pushed up the Pyrenees; Italy, the Alps, and Anatolia, moving west, the mountains of Greece and the islands.
1779	8667	The compression and orogeny continue today, as shown by the ongoing raising of the mountains a small amount each year and the active volcanoes.
1780	8668	From the Eocene onwards, the ongoing Alpine orogeny caused a N–S rift system to develop in this zone.
1780	8669	The main elements of this rift are the Upper Rhine Graben, in southwest Germany and eastern France and the Lower Rhine Embayment, in northwest Germany and the southeastern Netherlands.
1780	8670	By the time of the Miocene, a river system had developed in the Upper Rhine Graben, that continued northward and is considered the first Rhine river.
1780	8671	At that time, it did not yet carry discharge from the Alps; instead, the watersheds of the Rhone and Danube drained the northern flanks of the Alps.
1781	8672	Through stream capture, the Rhine extended its watershed southward.
1781	8673	By the Pliocene period, the Rhine had captured streams down to the Vosges Mountains, including the Mosel, the Main and the Neckar.
1781	8674	The northern Alps were then drained by the Rhone.
1781	8675	By the early Pleistocene period, the Rhine had captured most of its current Alpine watershed from the Rhône, including the Aar.
1781	8676	Since that time, the Rhine has added the watershed above Lake Constance (Vorderrhein, Hinterrhein, Alpenrhein; captured from the Rhône), the upper reaches of the Main, beyond Schweinfurt and the Vosges Mountains, captured from the Meuse, to its watershed.
1782	8677	Around 2.5 million years ago (ending 11,600 years ago) was the geological period of the Ice Ages.
1782	8678	Since approximately 600,000 years ago, six major Ice Ages have occurred, in which sea level dropped 120 m (390 ft) and much of the continental margins became exposed.
1782	8679	In the Early Pleistocene, the Rhine followed a course to the northwest, through the present North Sea.
1782	8680	During the so-called Anglian glaciation (~450,000 yr BP, marine oxygen isotope stage 12), the northern part of the present North Sea was blocked by the ice and a large lake developed, that overflowed through the English Channel.
1782	8681	This caused the Rhine's course to be diverted through the English Channel.
1782	8682	Since then, during glacial times, the river mouth was located offshore of Brest, France and rivers, like the Thames and the Seine, became tributaries to the Rhine.
1782	8683	During interglacials, when sea level rose to approximately the present level, the Rhine built deltas, in what is now the Netherlands.
1783	8684	The last glacial ran from ~74,000 (BP = Before Present), until the end of the Pleistocene (~11,600 BP).
1783	8685	In northwest Europe, it saw two very cold phases, peaking around 70,000 BP and around 29,000–24,000 BP.
1783	8686	The last phase slightly predates the global last ice age maximum (Last Glacial Maximum).
1783	8687	During this time, the lower Rhine flowed roughly west through the Netherlands and extended to the southwest, through the English Channel and finally, to the Atlantic Ocean.
1783	8688	The English Channel, the Irish Channel and most of the North Sea were dry land, mainly because sea level was approximately 120 m (390 ft) lower than today.
1784	8689	Most of the Rhine's current course was not under the ice during the last Ice Age; although, its source must still have been a glacier.
1784	8690	A tundra, with Ice Age flora and fauna, stretched across middle Europe, from Asia to the Atlantic Ocean.
1784	8691	Such was the case during the Last Glacial Maximum, ca.
1784	8692	22,000–14,000 yr BP, when ice-sheets covered Scandinavia, the Baltics, Scotland and the Alps, but left the space between as open tundra.
1784	8693	The loess or wind-blown dust over that tundra, settled in and around the Rhine Valley, contributing to its current agricultural usefulness.
1785	8694	As northwest Europe slowly began to warm up from 22,000 years ago onward, frozen subsoil and expanded alpine glaciers began to thaw and fall-winter snow covers melted in spring.
1785	8695	Much of the discharge was routed to the Rhine and its downstream extension.
1785	8696	Rapid warming and changes of vegetation, to open forest, began about 13,000 BP.
1785	8697	By 9000 BP, Europe was fully forested.
1785	8698	With globally shrinking ice-cover, ocean water levels rose and the English Channel and North Sea re-inundated.
1785	8699	Meltwater, adding to the ocean and land subsidence, drowned the former coasts of Europe transgressionally.
1786	8700	Since 7500 yr ago, a situation with tides and currents, very similar to present has existed.
1786	8701	Rates of sea-level rise had dropped so far, that natural sedimentation by the Rhine and coastal processes together, could compensate the transgression by the sea; in the last 7000 years, the coast line was roughly at the same location.
1786	8702	In the southern North Sea, due to ongoing tectonic subsidence, the sea level is still rising, at the rate of about 1–3 cm (0.39–1.18 in) per century (1 metre or 39 inches in last 3000 years).
1787	8703	At the begin of the Holocene (~11,700 years ago), the Rhine occupied its Late-Glacial valley.
1787	8704	As a meandering river, it reworked its ice-age braidplain.
1787	8705	As sea-level continued to rise in the Netherlands, the formation of the Holocene Rhine-Meuse delta began (~8,000 years ago).
1787	8706	Coeval absolute sea-level rise and tectonic subsidence have strongly influenced delta evolution.
1787	8707	Other factors of importance to the shape of the delta are the local tectonic activities of the Peel Boundary Fault, the substrate and geomorphology, as inherited from the Last Glacial and the coastal-marine dynamics, such as barrier and tidal inlet formations.
1788	8708	Since ~3000 yr BP (= years Before Present), human impact is seen in the delta.
1788	8709	As a result of increasing land clearance (Bronze Age agriculture), in the upland areas (central Germany), the sediment load of the Rhine has strongly increased and delta growth has sped up.
1788	8710	This caused increased flooding and sedimentation, ending peat formation in the delta.
1788	8711	The shifting of river channels to new locations, on the floodplain (termed avulsion), was the main process distributing sediment across the subrecent delta.
1788	8712	Over the past 6000 years, approximately 80 avulsions have occurred.
1788	8713	Direct human impact in the delta started with peat mining, for salt and fuel, from Roman times onward.
1788	8714	This was followed by embankment, of the major distributaries and damming of minor distributaries, which took place in the 11–13th century AD.
1788	8715	Thereafter, canals were dug, bends were short cut and groynes were built, to prevent the river's channels from migrating or silting up.
1789	8716	At present, the branches Waal and Nederrijn-Lek discharge to the North Sea, through the former Meuse estuary, near Rotterdam.
1789	8717	The river IJssel branch flows to the north and enters the IJsselmeer, formerly the Zuider Zee brackish lagoon; however, since 1932, a freshwater lake.
1789	8718	The discharge of the Rhine is divided among three branches: the River Waal (6/9 of total discharge), the River Nederrijn – Lek (2/9 of total discharge) and the River IJssel (1/9 of total discharge).
1789	8719	This discharge distribution has been maintained since 1709, by river engineering works, including the digging of the Pannerdens canal and since the 20th century, with the help of weirs in the Nederrijn river.
1790	8720	The Rhine was not known to Herodotus and first enters the historical period in the 1st century BC in Roman-era geography.
1790	8721	At that time, it formed the boundary between Gaul and Germania.
1790	8722	The Upper Rhine had been part of the areal of the late Hallstatt culture since the 6th century BC, and by the 1st century BC, the areal of the La Tène culture covered almost its entire length, forming a contact zone with the Jastorf culture, i.e.
1790	8723	the locus of early Celtic-Germanic cultural contact.
1790	8724	In Roman geography, the Rhine formed the boundary between Gallia and Germania by definition; e.g.
1790	8725	Maurus Servius Honoratus, Commentary on the Aeneid of Vergil (8.727) (Rhenus) fluvius Galliae, qui Germanos a Gallia dividit "(The Rhine is a) river of Gaul, which divides the Germanic people from Gaul."
1791	8726	From the death of Augustus in AD 14 until after AD 70, Rome accepted as her Germanic frontier the water-boundary of the Rhine and upper Danube.
1791	8727	Beyond these rivers she held only the fertile plain of Frankfurt, opposite the Roman border fortress of Moguntiacum (Mainz), the southernmost slopes of the Black Forest and a few scattered bridge-heads.
1791	8728	The northern section of this frontier, where the Rhine is deep and broad, remained the Roman boundary until the empire fell.
1791	8729	The upper Rhine and upper Danube are easily crossed.
1791	8730	The frontier which they form is inconveniently long, enclosing an acute-angled wedge of foreign territory between the modern Baden and Württemberg.
1791	8731	The Germanic populations of these lands seem in Roman times to have been scanty, and Roman subjects from the modern Alsace-Lorraine had drifted across the river eastwards.
1792	8732	The Romans kept eight legions in five bases along the Rhine.
1792	8733	The actual number of legions present at any base or in all, depended on whether a state or threat of war existed.
1792	8734	Between about AD 14 and 180, the assignment of legions was as follows: for the army of Germania Inferior, two legions at Vetera (Xanten), I Germanica and XX Valeria (Pannonian troops); two legions at oppidum Ubiorum ("town of the Ubii"), which was renamed to Colonia Agrippina, descending to Cologne, V Alaudae, a Celtic legion recruited from Gallia Narbonensis and XXI, possibly a Galatian legion from the other side of the empire.
1793	8735	Germanic tribes crossed the Rhine in the Migration period, by the 5th century establishing the kingdoms of Francia on the Lower Rhine, Burgundy on the Upper Rhine and Alemannia on the High Rhine.
1793	8736	This "Germanic Heroic Age" is reflected in medieval legend, such as the Nibelungenlied which tells of the hero Siegfried killing a dragon on the Drachenfels (Siebengebirge) ("dragons rock"), near Bonn at the Rhine and of the Burgundians and their court at Worms, at the Rhine and Kriemhild's golden treasure, which was thrown into the Rhine by Hagen.
1794	8737	By the 6th century, the Rhine was within the borders of Francia.
1794	8738	In the 9th, it formed part of the border between Middle and Western Francia, but in the 10th century, it was fully within the Holy Roman Empire, flowing through Swabia, Franconia and Lower Lorraine.
1794	8739	The mouths of the Rhine, in the county of Holland, fell to the Burgundian Netherlands in the 15th century; Holland remained contentious territory throughout the European wars of religion and the eventual collapse of the Holy Roman Empire, when the length of the Rhine fell to the First French Empire and its client states.
1794	8740	The Alsace on the left banks of the Upper Rhine was sold to Burgundy by Archduke Sigismund of Austria in 1469 and eventually fell to France in the Thirty Years' War.
1794	8741	The numerous historic castles in Rhineland-Palatinate attest to the importance of the river as a commercial route.
1795	8742	Since the Peace of Westphalia, the Upper Rhine formed a contentious border between France and Germany.
1795	8743	Establishing "natural borders" on the Rhine was a long-term goal of French foreign policy, since the Middle Ages, though the language border was – and is – far more to the west.
1795	8744	French leaders, such as Louis XIV and Napoleon Bonaparte, tried with varying degrees of success to annex lands west of the Rhine.
1795	8745	The Confederation of the Rhine was established by Napoleon, as a French client state, in 1806 and lasted until 1814, during which time it served as a significant source of resources and military manpower for the First French Empire.
1795	8746	In 1840, the Rhine crisis, prompted by French prime minister Adolphe Thiers's desire to reinstate the Rhine as a natural border, led to a diplomatic crisis and a wave of nationalism in Germany.
1796	8747	At the end of World War I, the Rhineland was subject to the Treaty of Versailles.
1796	8748	This decreed that it would be occupied by the allies, until 1935 and after that, it would be a demilitarised zone, with the German army forbidden to enter.
1796	8749	The Treaty of Versailles and this particular provision, in general, caused much resentment in Germany and is often cited as helping Adolf Hitler's rise to power.
1796	8750	The allies left the Rhineland, in 1930 and the German army re-occupied it in 1936, which was enormously popular in Germany.
1796	8751	Although the allies could probably have prevented the re-occupation, Britain and France were not inclined to do so, a feature of their policy of appeasement to Hitler.
1797	8752	In World War II, it was recognised that the Rhine would present a formidable natural obstacle to the invasion of Germany, by the Western Allies.
1797	8753	The Rhine bridge at Arnhem, immortalized in the book, A Bridge Too Far and the film, was a central focus of the battle for Arnhem, during the failed Operation Market Garden of September 1944.
1797	8754	The bridges at Nijmegen, over the Waal distributary of the Rhine, were also an objective of Operation Market Garden.
1797	8755	In a separate operation, the Ludendorff Bridge, crossing the Rhine at Remagen, became famous, when U.S. forces were able to capture it intact – much to their own surprise – after the Germans failed to demolish it.
1797	8756	This also became the subject of a film, The Bridge at Remagen.
1797	8757	Seven Days to the River Rhine was a Warsaw Pact war plan for an invasion of Western Europe during the Cold War.
1798	8758	Until 1932 the generally accepted length of the Rhine was 1,230 kilometres (764 miles).
1798	8759	In 1932 the German encyclopedia Knaurs Lexikon stated the length as 1,320 kilometres (820 miles), presumably a typographical error.
1798	8760	After this number was placed into the authoritative Brockhaus Enzyklopädie, it became generally accepted and found its way into numerous textbooks and official publications.
1798	8761	The error was discovered in 2010, and the Dutch Rijkswaterstaat confirms the length at 1,232 kilometres (766 miles).
1799	8762	Following a referendum in 1997, in which the Scottish electorate voted for devolution, the current Parliament was convened by the Scotland Act 1998, which sets out its powers as a devolved legislature.
1799	8763	The Act delineates the legislative competence of the Parliament – the areas in which it can make laws – by explicitly specifying powers that are "reserved" to the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
1799	8764	The Scottish Parliament has the power to legislate in all areas that are not explicitly reserved to Westminster.
1799	8765	The British Parliament retains the ability to amend the terms of reference of the Scottish Parliament, and can extend or reduce the areas in which it can make laws.
1799	8766	The first meeting of the new Parliament took place on 12 May 1999.
1800	8767	For the next three hundred years, Scotland was directly governed by the Parliament of Great Britain and the subsequent Parliament of the United Kingdom, both seated at Westminster, and the lack of a Parliament of Scotland remained an important element in Scottish national identity.
1800	8768	Suggestions for a 'devolved' Parliament were made before 1914, but were shelved due to the outbreak of the First World War.
1800	8769	A sharp rise in nationalism in Scotland during the late 1960s fuelled demands for some form of home rule or complete independence, and in 1969 prompted the incumbent Labour government of Harold Wilson to set up the Kilbrandon Commission to consider the British constitution.
1800	8770	One of the principal objectives of the commission was to examine ways of enabling more self-government for Scotland, within the unitary state of the United Kingdom.
1800	8771	Kilbrandon published his report in 1973 recommending the establishment of a directly elected Scottish Assembly to legislate for the majority of domestic Scottish affairs.
1801	8772	During this time, the discovery of oil in the North Sea and the following "It's Scotland's oil" campaign of the Scottish National Party (SNP) resulted in rising support for Scottish independence, as well as the SNP.
1801	8773	The party argued that the revenues from the oil were not benefitting Scotland as much as they should.
1801	8774	The combined effect of these events led to Prime Minister Wilson committing his government to some form of devolved legislature in 1974.
1801	8775	However, it was not until 1978 that final legislative proposals for a Scottish Assembly were passed by the United Kingdom Parliament.
1802	8776	Under the terms of the Scotland Act 1978, an elected assembly would be set up in Edinburgh provided that the majority of the Scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 March 1979 that represented at least 40% of the total electorate.
1802	8777	The 1979 Scottish devolution referendum to establish a devolved Scottish Assembly failed.
1802	8778	Although the vote was 51.6% in favour of a Scottish Assembly, this figure did not equal the 40% of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure, as 32.9% of the eligible voting population did not, or had been unable to, vote.
1803	8779	Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, demand for a Scottish Parliament grew, in part because the government of the United Kingdom was controlled by the Conservative Party, while Scotland itself elected relatively few Conservative MPs.
1803	8780	In the aftermath of the 1979 referendum defeat, the Campaign for a Scottish Assembly was initiated as a pressure group, leading to the 1989 Scottish Constitutional Convention with various organisations such as Scottish churches, political parties and representatives of industry taking part.
1803	8781	Publishing its blueprint for devolution in 1995, the Convention provided much of the basis for the structure of the Parliament.
1804	8782	Since September 2004, the official home of the Scottish Parliament has been a new Scottish Parliament Building, in the Holyrood area of Edinburgh.
1804	8783	The Scottish Parliament building was designed by Spanish architect Enric Miralles in partnership with local Edinburgh Architecture firm RMJM which was led by Design Principal Tony Kettle.
1804	8784	Some of the principal features of the complex include leaf-shaped buildings, a grass-roofed branch merging into adjacent parkland and gabion walls formed from the stones of previous buildings.
1804	8785	Throughout the building there are many repeated motifs, such as shapes based on Raeburn's Skating Minister.
1804	8786	Crow-stepped gables and the upturned boat skylights of the Garden Lobby, complete the unique architecture.
1804	8787	Queen Elizabeth II opened the new building on 9 October 2004.
1805	8788	Whilst the permanent building at Holyrood was being constructed, the Parliament's temporary home was the General Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland on the Royal Mile in Edinburgh.
1805	8789	Official photographs and television interviews were held in the courtyard adjoining the Assembly Hall, which is part of the School of Divinity of the University of Edinburgh.
1805	8790	This building was vacated twice to allow for the meeting of the Church's General Assembly.
1805	8791	In May 2000, the Parliament was temporarily relocated to the former Strathclyde Regional Council debating chamber in Glasgow, and to the University of Aberdeen in May 2002.
1806	8792	In addition to the General Assembly Hall, the Parliament also used buildings rented from the City of Edinburgh Council.
1806	8793	The former administrative building of Lothian Regional Council on George IV Bridge was used for the MSP's offices.
1806	8794	Following the move to Holyrood in 2004 this building was demolished.
1806	8795	The former Midlothian County Buildings facing Parliament Square, High Street and George IV Bridge in Edinburgh (originally built as the headquarters of the pre-1975 Midlothian County Council) housed the Parliament's visitors' centre and shop, whilst the main hall was used as the Parliament's principal committee room.
1807	8796	After each election to the Scottish Parliament, at the beginning of each parliamentary session, Parliament elects one MSP to serve as Presiding Officer, the equivalent of the speaker (currently Tricia Marwick), and two MSPs to serve as deputies (currently Elaine Smith and John Scott).
1807	8797	The Presiding Officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 MSPs, which is the only secret ballot conducted in the Scottish Parliament.
1807	8798	Principally, the role of the Presiding Officer is to chair chamber proceedings and the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body.
