2021	9892	Newton's Second Law asserts the direct proportionality of acceleration to force and the inverse proportionality of acceleration to mass.
2021	9893	Accelerations can be defined through kinematic measurements.
2021	9894	However, while kinematics are well-described through reference frame analysis in advanced physics, there are still deep questions that remain as to what is the proper definition of mass.
2021	9895	General relativity offers an equivalence between space-time and mass, but lacking a coherent theory of quantum gravity, it is unclear as to how or whether this connection is relevant on microscales.
2021	9896	With some justification, Newton's second law can be taken as a quantitative definition of mass by writing the law as an equality; the relative units of force and mass then are fixed.
2022	9897	Newton's Third Law is a result of applying symmetry to situations where forces can be attributed to the presence of different objects.
2022	9898	The third law means that all forces are interactions between different bodies,[Note 3] and thus that there is no such thing as a unidirectional force or a force that acts on only one body.
2022	9899	Whenever a first body exerts a force F on a second body, the second body exerts a force −F on the first body.
2022	9900	F and −F are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.
2022	9901	This law is sometimes referred to as the action-reaction law, with F called the "action" and −F the "reaction".
2022	9902	The action and the reaction are simultaneous:
2023	9903	This means that in a closed system of particles, there are no internal forces that are unbalanced.
2023	9904	That is, the action-reaction force shared between any two objects in a closed system will not cause the center of mass of the system to accelerate.
2023	9905	The constituent objects only accelerate with respect to each other, the system itself remains unaccelerated.
2023	9906	Alternatively, if an external force acts on the system, then the center of mass will experience an acceleration proportional to the magnitude of the external force divided by the mass of the system.
2024	9907	Since forces are perceived as pushes or pulls, this can provide an intuitive understanding for describing forces.
2024	9908	As with other physical concepts (e.g.
2024	9909	temperature), the intuitive understanding of forces is quantified using precise operational definitions that are consistent with direct observations and compared to a standard measurement scale.
2024	9910	Through experimentation, it is determined that laboratory measurements of forces are fully consistent with the conceptual definition of force offered by Newtonian mechanics.
2025	9911	Forces act in a particular direction and have sizes dependent upon how strong the push or pull is.
2025	9912	Because of these characteristics, forces are classified as "vector quantities".
2025	9913	This means that forces follow a different set of mathematical rules than physical quantities that do not have direction (denoted scalar quantities).
2025	9914	For example, when determining what happens when two forces act on the same object, it is necessary to know both the magnitude and the direction of both forces to calculate the result.
2025	9915	If both of these pieces of information are not known for each force, the situation is ambiguous.
2025	9916	For example, if you know that two people are pulling on the same rope with known magnitudes of force but you do not know which direction either person is pulling, it is impossible to determine what the acceleration of the rope will be.
2025	9917	The two people could be pulling against each other as in tug of war or the two people could be pulling in the same direction.
2025	9918	In this simple one-dimensional example, without knowing the direction of the forces it is impossible to decide whether the net force is the result of adding the two force magnitudes or subtracting one from the other.
2025	9919	Associating forces with vectors avoids such problems.
2026	9920	Historically, forces were first quantitatively investigated in conditions of static equilibrium where several forces canceled each other out.
2026	9921	Such experiments demonstrate the crucial properties that forces are additive vector quantities: they have magnitude and direction.
2026	9922	When two forces act on a point particle, the resulting force, the resultant (also called the net force), can be determined by following the parallelogram rule of vector addition: the addition of two vectors represented by sides of a parallelogram, gives an equivalent resultant vector that is equal in magnitude and direction to the transversal of the parallelogram.
2026	9923	The magnitude of the resultant varies from the difference of the magnitudes of the two forces to their sum, depending on the angle between their lines of action.
2026	9924	However, if the forces are acting on an extended body, their respective lines of application must also be specified in order to account for their effects on the motion of the body.
2027	9925	As well as being added, forces can also be resolved into independent components at right angles to each other.
2027	9926	A horizontal force pointing northeast can therefore be split into two forces, one pointing north, and one pointing east.
2027	9927	Summing these component forces using vector addition yields the original force.
2027	9928	Resolving force vectors into components of a set of basis vectors is often a more mathematically clean way to describe forces than using magnitudes and directions.
2027	9929	This is because, for orthogonal components, the components of the vector sum are uniquely determined by the scalar addition of the components of the individual vectors.
2027	9930	Orthogonal components are independent of each other because forces acting at ninety degrees to each other have no effect on the magnitude or direction of the other.
2027	9931	Choosing a set of orthogonal basis vectors is often done by considering what set of basis vectors will make the mathematics most convenient.
2027	9932	Choosing a basis vector that is in the same direction as one of the forces is desirable, since that force would then have only one non-zero component.
2027	9933	Orthogonal force vectors can be three-dimensional with the third component being at right-angles to the other two.
2028	9934	Pushing against an object on a frictional surface can result in a situation where the object does not move because the applied force is opposed by static friction, generated between the object and the table surface.
2028	9935	For a situation with no movement, the static friction force exactly balances the applied force resulting in no acceleration.
2028	9936	The static friction increases or decreases in response to the applied force up to an upper limit determined by the characteristics of the contact between the surface and the object.
2029	9937	A static equilibrium between two forces is the most usual way of measuring forces, using simple devices such as weighing scales and spring balances.
2029	9938	For example, an object suspended on a vertical spring scale experiences the force of gravity acting on the object balanced by a force applied by the "spring reaction force", which equals the object's weight.
2029	9939	Using such tools, some quantitative force laws were discovered: that the force of gravity is proportional to volume for objects of constant density (widely exploited for millennia to define standard weights); Archimedes' principle for buoyancy; Archimedes' analysis of the lever; Boyle's law for gas pressure; and Hooke's law for springs.
2029	9940	These were all formulated and experimentally verified before Isaac Newton expounded his Three Laws of Motion.
2030	9941	Dynamic equilibrium was first described by Galileo who noticed that certain assumptions of Aristotelian physics were contradicted by observations and logic.
2030	9942	Galileo realized that simple velocity addition demands that the concept of an "absolute rest frame" did not exist.
2030	9943	Galileo concluded that motion in a constant velocity was completely equivalent to rest.
2030	9944	This was contrary to Aristotle's notion of a "natural state" of rest that objects with mass naturally approached.
2030	9945	Simple experiments showed that Galileo's understanding of the equivalence of constant velocity and rest were correct.
2030	9946	For example, if a mariner dropped a cannonball from the crow's nest of a ship moving at a constant velocity, Aristotelian physics would have the cannonball fall straight down while the ship moved beneath it.
2030	9947	Thus, in an Aristotelian universe, the falling cannonball would land behind the foot of the mast of a moving ship.
2030	9948	However, when this experiment is actually conducted, the cannonball always falls at the foot of the mast, as if the cannonball knows to travel with the ship despite being separated from it.
2030	9949	Since there is no forward horizontal force being applied on the cannonball as it falls, the only conclusion left is that the cannonball continues to move with the same velocity as the boat as it falls.
2030	9950	Thus, no force is required to keep the cannonball moving at the constant forward velocity.
2031	9951	A simple case of dynamic equilibrium occurs in constant velocity motion across a surface with kinetic friction.
2031	9952	In such a situation, a force is applied in the direction of motion while the kinetic friction force exactly opposes the applied force.
2031	9953	This results in zero net force, but since the object started with a non-zero velocity, it continues to move with a non-zero velocity.
2031	9954	Aristotle misinterpreted this motion as being caused by the applied force.
2031	9955	However, when kinetic friction is taken into consideration it is clear that there is no net force causing constant velocity motion.
2032	9956	The notion "force" keeps its meaning in quantum mechanics, though one is now dealing with operators instead of classical variables and though the physics is now described by the Schrödinger equation instead of Newtonian equations.
2032	9957	This has the consequence that the results of a measurement are now sometimes "quantized", i.e.
2032	9958	This is, of course, difficult to imagine in the context of "forces".
2032	9959	However, the potentials V(x,y,z) or fields, from which the forces generally can be derived, are treated similar to classical position variables, i.e., .
2033	9960	However, already in quantum mechanics there is one "caveat", namely the particles acting onto each other do not only possess the spatial variable, but also a discrete intrinsic angular momentum-like variable called the "spin", and there is the Pauli principle relating the space and the spin variables.
2033	9961	Depending on the value of the spin, identical particles split into two different classes, fermions and bosons.
2033	9962	electrons) have a symmetric spin function (e.g.
2033	9963	parallel spins) the spatial variables must be antisymmetric (i.e.
2033	9964	they exclude each other from their places much as if there was a repulsive force), and vice versa, i.e.
2033	9965	for antiparallel spins the position variables must be symmetric (i.e.
2033	9966	the apparent force must be attractive).
2033	9967	Thus in the case of two fermions there is a strictly negative correlation between spatial and spin variables, whereas for two bosons (e.g.
2033	9968	quanta of electromagnetic waves, photons) the correlation is strictly positive.
2034	9969	In modern particle physics, forces and the acceleration of particles are explained as a mathematical by-product of exchange of momentum-carrying gauge bosons.
2034	9970	With the development of quantum field theory and general relativity, it was realized that force is a redundant concept arising from conservation of momentum (4-momentum in relativity and momentum of virtual particles in quantum electrodynamics).
2034	9971	The conservation of momentum can be directly derived from the homogeneity or symmetry of space and so is usually considered more fundamental than the concept of a force.
2034	9972	Thus the currently known fundamental forces are considered more accurately to be "fundamental interactions".
2034	9973	:199–128 When particle A emits (creates) or absorbs (annihilates) virtual particle B, a momentum conservation results in recoil of particle A making impression of repulsion or attraction between particles A A' exchanging by B.
2034	9974	This description applies to all forces arising from fundamental interactions.
2034	9975	While sophisticated mathematical descriptions are needed to predict, in full detail, the accurate result of such interactions, there is a conceptually simple way to describe such interactions through the use of Feynman diagrams.
2034	9976	In a Feynman diagram, each matter particle is represented as a straight line (see world line) traveling through time, which normally increases up or to the right in the diagram.
2034	9977	Matter and anti-matter particles are identical except for their direction of propagation through the Feynman diagram.
2034	9978	World lines of particles intersect at interaction vertices, and the Feynman diagram represents any force arising from an interaction as occurring at the vertex with an associated instantaneous change in the direction of the particle world lines.
2034	9979	Gauge bosons are emitted away from the vertex as wavy lines and, in the case of virtual particle exchange, are absorbed at an adjacent vertex.
2035	9980	All of the forces in the universe are based on four fundamental interactions.
2035	9981	The strong and weak forces are nuclear forces that act only at very short distances, and are responsible for the interactions between subatomic particles, including nucleons and compound nuclei.
2035	9982	The electromagnetic force acts between electric charges, and the gravitational force acts between masses.
2035	9983	All other forces in nature derive from these four fundamental interactions.
2035	9984	For example, friction is a manifestation of the electromagnetic force acting between the atoms of two surfaces, and the Pauli exclusion principle, which does not permit atoms to pass through each other.
2035	9985	Similarly, the forces in springs, modeled by Hooke's law, are the result of electromagnetic forces and the Exclusion Principle acting together to return an object to its equilibrium position.
2035	9986	Centrifugal forces are acceleration forces that arise simply from the acceleration of rotating frames of reference.
2036	9987	The development of fundamental theories for forces proceeded along the lines of unification of disparate ideas.
2036	9988	For example, Isaac Newton unified the force responsible for objects falling at the surface of the Earth with the force responsible for the orbits of celestial mechanics in his universal theory of gravitation.
2036	9989	Michael Faraday and James Clerk Maxwell demonstrated that electric and magnetic forces were unified through one consistent theory of electromagnetism.
2036	9990	In the 20th century, the development of quantum mechanics led to a modern understanding that the first three fundamental forces (all except gravity) are manifestations of matter (fermions) interacting by exchanging virtual particles called gauge bosons.
2036	9991	This standard model of particle physics posits a similarity between the forces and led scientists to predict the unification of the weak and electromagnetic forces in electroweak theory subsequently confirmed by observation.
2036	9992	The complete formulation of the standard model predicts an as yet unobserved Higgs mechanism, but observations such as neutrino oscillations indicate that the standard model is incomplete.
2036	9993	A Grand Unified Theory allowing for the combination of the electroweak interaction with the strong force is held out as a possibility with candidate theories such as supersymmetry proposed to accommodate some of the outstanding unsolved problems in physics.
2036	9994	Physicists are still attempting to develop self-consistent unification models that would combine all four fundamental interactions into a theory of everything.
2036	9995	Einstein tried and failed at this endeavor, but currently the most popular approach to answering this question is string theory.
2037	9996	What we now call gravity was not identified as a universal force until the work of Isaac Newton.
2037	9997	Before Newton, the tendency for objects to fall towards the Earth was not understood to be related to the motions of celestial objects.
2037	9998	Galileo was instrumental in describing the characteristics of falling objects by determining that the acceleration of every object in free-fall was constant and independent of the mass of the object.
2037	9999	Today, this acceleration due to gravity towards the surface of the Earth is usually designated as  and has a magnitude of about 9.81 meters per second squared (this measurement is taken from sea level and may vary depending on location), and points toward the center of the Earth.
2037	10000	This observation means that the force of gravity on an object at the Earth's surface is directly proportional to the object's mass.
2037	10001	Thus an object that has a mass of  will experience a force:
2038	10002	Newton came to realize that the effects of gravity might be observed in different ways at larger distances.
2038	10003	In particular, Newton determined that the acceleration of the Moon around the Earth could be ascribed to the same force of gravity if the acceleration due to gravity decreased as an inverse square law.
2038	10004	Further, Newton realized that the acceleration due to gravity is proportional to the mass of the attracting body.
2038	10005	Combining these ideas gives a formula that relates the mass () and the radius () of the Earth to the gravitational acceleration:
2039	10006	In this equation, a dimensional constant  is used to describe the relative strength of gravity.
2039	10007	This constant has come to be known as Newton's Universal Gravitation Constant, though its value was unknown in Newton's lifetime.
2039	10008	Not until 1798 was Henry Cavendish able to make the first measurement of  using a torsion balance; this was widely reported in the press as a measurement of the mass of the Earth since knowing  could allow one to solve for the Earth's mass given the above equation.
2039	10009	Newton, however, realized that since all celestial bodies followed the same laws of motion, his law of gravity had to be universal.

2040	10011	It was only the orbit of the planet Mercury that Newton's Law of Gravitation seemed not to fully explain.
2040	10012	Some astrophysicists predicted the existence of another planet (Vulcan) that would explain the discrepancies; however, despite some early indications, no such planet could be found.
2040	10013	When Albert Einstein formulated his theory of general relativity (GR) he turned his attention to the problem of Mercury's orbit and found that his theory added a correction, which could account for the discrepancy.
2040	10014	This was the first time that Newton's Theory of Gravity had been shown to be less correct than an alternative.
2041	10015	Since then, and so far, general relativity has been acknowledged as the theory that best explains gravity.
2041	10016	In GR, gravitation is not viewed as a force, but rather, objects moving freely in gravitational fields travel under their own inertia in straight lines through curved space-time – defined as the shortest space-time path between two space-time events.
2041	10017	From the perspective of the object, all motion occurs as if there were no gravitation whatsoever.
2041	10018	It is only when observing the motion in a global sense that the curvature of space-time can be observed and the force is inferred from the object's curved path.
2041	10019	Thus, the straight line path in space-time is seen as a curved line in space, and it is called the ballistic trajectory of the object.
2041	10020	For example, a basketball thrown from the ground moves in a parabola, as it is in a uniform gravitational field.
2041	10021	Its space-time trajectory (when the extra ct dimension is added) is almost a straight line, slightly curved (with the radius of curvature of the order of few light-years).
2041	10022	The time derivative of the changing momentum of the object is what we label as "gravitational force".
2042	10023	Through combining the definition of electric current as the time rate of change of electric charge, a rule of vector multiplication called Lorentz's Law describes the force on a charge moving in a magnetic field.
2042	10024	The connection between electricity and magnetism allows for the description of a unified electromagnetic force that acts on a charge.
2042	10025	This force can be written as a sum of the electrostatic force (due to the electric field) and the magnetic force (due to the magnetic field).
2042	10026	Fully stated, this is the law:
2043	10027	The origin of electric and magnetic fields would not be fully explained until 1864 when James Clerk Maxwell unified a number of earlier theories into a set of 20 scalar equations, which were later reformulated into 4 vector equations by Oliver Heaviside and Josiah Willard Gibbs.
2043	10028	These "Maxwell Equations" fully described the sources of the fields as being stationary and moving charges, and the interactions of the fields themselves.
2043	10029	This led Maxwell to discover that electric and magnetic fields could be "self-generating" through a wave that traveled at a speed that he calculated to be the speed of light.
2043	10030	This insight united the nascent fields of electromagnetic theory with optics and led directly to a complete description of the electromagnetic spectrum.
2044	10031	However, attempting to reconcile electromagnetic theory with two observations, the photoelectric effect, and the nonexistence of the ultraviolet catastrophe, proved troublesome.
2044	10032	Through the work of leading theoretical physicists, a new theory of electromagnetism was developed using quantum mechanics.
2044	10033	This final modification to electromagnetic theory ultimately led to quantum electrodynamics (or QED), which fully describes all electromagnetic phenomena as being mediated by wave–particles known as photons.
2044	10034	In QED, photons are the fundamental exchange particle, which described all interactions relating to electromagnetism including the electromagnetic force.
2045	10035	It is a common misconception to ascribe the stiffness and rigidity of solid matter to the repulsion of like charges under the influence of the electromagnetic force.
2045	10036	However, these characteristics actually result from the Pauli exclusion principle.
2045	10037	[citation needed] Since electrons are fermions, they cannot occupy the same quantum mechanical state as other electrons.
2045	10038	When the electrons in a material are densely packed together, there are not enough lower energy quantum mechanical states for them all, so some of them must be in higher energy states.
2045	10039	This means that it takes energy to pack them together.
2045	10040	While this effect is manifested macroscopically as a structural force, it is technically only the result of the existence of a finite set of electron states.
2046	10041	The strong force only acts directly upon elementary particles.
2046	10042	However, a residual of the force is observed between hadrons (the best known example being the force that acts between nucleons in atomic nuclei) as the nuclear force.
2046	10043	Here the strong force acts indirectly, transmitted as gluons, which form part of the virtual pi and rho mesons, which classically transmit the nuclear force (see this topic for more).
2046	10044	The failure of many searches for free quarks has shown that the elementary particles affected are not directly observable.
2046	10045	This phenomenon is called color confinement.
2047	10046	The weak force is due to the exchange of the heavy W and Z bosons.
2047	10047	Its most familiar effect is beta decay (of neutrons in atomic nuclei) and the associated radioactivity.
2047	10048	The word "weak" derives from the fact that the field strength is some 1013 times less than that of the strong force.
2047	10049	Still, it is stronger than gravity over short distances.
2047	10050	A consistent electroweak theory has also been developed, which shows that electromagnetic forces and the weak force are indistinguishable at a temperatures in excess of approximately 1015 kelvins.
2047	10051	Such temperatures have been probed in modern particle accelerators and show the conditions of the universe in the early moments of the Big Bang.
2048	10052	The normal force is due to repulsive forces of interaction between atoms at close contact.
2048	10053	When their electron clouds overlap, Pauli repulsion (due to fermionic nature of electrons) follows resulting in the force that acts in a direction normal to the surface interface between two objects.
2048	10054	:93 The normal force, for example, is responsible for the structural integrity of tables and floors as well as being the force that responds whenever an external force pushes on a solid object.
2048	10055	An example of the normal force in action is the impact force on an object crashing into an immobile surface.
2049	10056	Tension forces can be modeled using ideal strings that are massless, frictionless, unbreakable, and unstretchable.
2049	10057	They can be combined with ideal pulleys, which allow ideal strings to switch physical direction.
2049	10058	Ideal strings transmit tension forces instantaneously in action-reaction pairs so that if two objects are connected by an ideal string, any force directed along the string by the first object is accompanied by a force directed along the string in the opposite direction by the second object.
2049	10059	By connecting the same string multiple times to the same object through the use of a set-up that uses movable pulleys, the tension force on a load can be multiplied.
2049	10060	For every string that acts on a load, another factor of the tension force in the string acts on the load.
2049	10061	However, even though such machines allow for an increase in force, there is a corresponding increase in the length of string that must be displaced in order to move the load.
2049	10062	These tandem effects result ultimately in the conservation of mechanical energy since the work done on the load is the same no matter how complicated the machine.
2050	10063	Newton's laws and Newtonian mechanics in general were first developed to describe how forces affect idealized point particles rather than three-dimensional objects.
2050	10064	However, in real life, matter has extended structure and forces that act on one part of an object might affect other parts of an object.
2050	10065	For situations where lattice holding together the atoms in an object is able to flow, contract, expand, or otherwise change shape, the theories of continuum mechanics describe the way forces affect the material.
2050	10066	For example, in extended fluids, differences in pressure result in forces being directed along the pressure gradients as follows:
2051	10067	where  is the relevant cross-sectional area for the volume for which the stress-tensor is being calculated.
2051	10068	This formalism includes pressure terms associated with forces that act normal to the cross-sectional area (the matrix diagonals of the tensor) as well as shear terms associated with forces that act parallel to the cross-sectional area (the off-diagonal elements).
2051	10069	The stress tensor accounts for forces that cause all strains (deformations) including also tensile stresses and compressions.
2052	10070	Torque is the rotation equivalent of force in the same way that angle is the rotational equivalent for position, angular velocity for velocity, and angular momentum for momentum.
2052	10071	As a consequence of Newton's First Law of Motion, there exists rotational inertia that ensures that all bodies maintain their angular momentum unless acted upon by an unbalanced torque.
2052	10072	Likewise, Newton's Second Law of Motion can be used to derive an analogous equation for the instantaneous angular acceleration of the rigid body:
2053	10073	where  is the mass of the object,  is the velocity of the object and  is the distance to the center of the circular path and  is the unit vector pointing in the radial direction outwards from the center.
2053	10074	This means that the unbalanced centripetal force felt by any object is always directed toward the center of the curving path.
2053	10075	Such forces act perpendicular to the velocity vector associated with the motion of an object, and therefore do not change the speed of the object (magnitude of the velocity), but only the direction of the velocity vector.
2053	10076	The unbalanced force that accelerates an object can be resolved into a component that is perpendicular to the path, and one that is tangential to the path.
2053	10077	This yields both the tangential force, which accelerates the object by either slowing it down or speeding it up, and the radial (centripetal) force, which changes its direction.
2054	10078	A conservative force that acts on a closed system has an associated mechanical work that allows energy to convert only between kinetic or potential forms.
2054	10079	This means that for a closed system, the net mechanical energy is conserved whenever a conservative force acts on the system.
2054	10080	The force, therefore, is related directly to the difference in potential energy between two different locations in space, and can be considered to be an artifact of the potential field in the same way that the direction and amount of a flow of water can be considered to be an artifact of the contour map of the elevation of an area.
2055	10081	For certain physical scenarios, it is impossible to model forces as being due to gradient of potentials.
2055	10082	This is often due to macrophysical considerations that yield forces as arising from a macroscopic statistical average of microstates.
2055	10083	For example, friction is caused by the gradients of numerous electrostatic potentials between the atoms, but manifests as a force model that is independent of any macroscale position vector.
2055	10084	Nonconservative forces other than friction include other contact forces, tension, compression, and drag.
2055	10085	However, for any sufficiently detailed description, all these forces are the results of conservative ones since each of these macroscopic forces are the net results of the gradients of microscopic potentials.
2056	10086	The connection between macroscopic nonconservative forces and microscopic conservative forces is described by detailed treatment with statistical mechanics.
2056	10087	In macroscopic closed systems, nonconservative forces act to change the internal energies of the system, and are often associated with the transfer of heat.
2056	10088	According to the Second law of thermodynamics, nonconservative forces necessarily result in energy transformations within closed systems from ordered to more random conditions as entropy increases.
2057	10089	The pound-force has a metric counterpart, less commonly used than the newton: the kilogram-force (kgf) (sometimes kilopond), is the force exerted by standard gravity on one kilogram of mass.
2057	10090	The kilogram-force leads to an alternate, but rarely used unit of mass: the metric slug (sometimes mug or hyl) is that mass that accelerates at 1 m·s−2 when subjected to a force of 1 kgf.
2057	10091	The kilogram-force is not a part of the modern SI system, and is generally deprecated; however it still sees use for some purposes as expressing aircraft weight, jet thrust, bicycle spoke tension, torque wrench settings and engine output torque.
2057	10092	Other arcane units of force include the sthène, which is equivalent to 1000 N, and the kip, which is equivalent to 1000 lbf.
